output: Mr President, I very much welcome the approach we describe in the White Paper, namely that we are tracking the causes of malnutrition, obesity and the resulting diseases.
Unfortunately, in food policy in Europe, whether we are talking about net profiles, about food labelling or even in some places in the White Paper, we are falling short of a very one-sided approach.
We are trying to solve the problems we have in Europe through product policy.
And I think it's fundamentally the wrong policy approach to assume that there are good and bad foods.
Many amendments show that this does not exist.
There are only good and bad or even balanced and unbalanced diets.
That should be our approach.
The causes of malnutrition are many.
To remedy them by trying to guide the consumer through product labelling or even by introducing advertising bans or regulations or by introducing different VAT rates will not lead us to the goal.

I think everything we're doing here, I don't want to get ahead of the labeling regulation debate, but everything we're doing here should be a little bit under the heading What can we do to motivate the consumer to think about his eating habits?
A sign that suggests to him that I am now facing a good or bad product is, in my view, more an instrument of discharge than an instrument of education and enlightenment.
That is why I wish for a balanced approach and the recognition that the path of product policy alone will not take us any further.
Mr President, Madam Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, budgetary control is not a new subject.
We are satisfied with the old and would also be satisfied with progress on the old issues.
Five points in the first place Our urgent request for support for Romania and Bulgaria in building the rule of law, justice and financial control.
We do not want to be where we are today in two years' time, and that is why this point is very, very important to us.
The second point is the declaration of reliability for the overall budget according to the graded control procedure including the national accounts.
It would be nice if, in the last six months, which are left to the Commission, we could make decisive progress here or at least agree on a common path.
You're going to be modest as a budget controller.
The third point would be simplification.
We need to help the lower levels of administration in the Member States to implement EU law.
It turns out that they are completely overburdened with large parts of EU law, which is why the high error rates are there.
The fourth point is external aid, and here I would like to address above all Kosovo and the question of cooperation with the United Nations.
The Committee on Budgetary Control has been in Kosovo, and I would now like to announce that Kosovo will play a certain role in the budgetary discharge.
I believe that we have so far fallen far short of the European Union's capabilities and that we urgently need to work on this.
The fifth point would be to improve cooperation between Member States in the fight against fraud.
We have homework here, especially for the ladies and gentlemen of the council.
Parliament will vote on the legal basis, the anti-fraud regulation, in November, and then we will have to think together about how to proceed if we want to achieve better results in this area.
That was our common wish until now.
Mr President, India and Europe need more and better contacts with each other at all levels, especially at the level of so-called normal people.
A brief remark to this effect is also important for the Commission's legislative programme, which we discussed earlier.
In global air traffic, we need good safety regulations, ones that do something, not just alibi measures.
It would therefore be a reasonable and really necessary measure to finally lift the pointless liquidity regulations and come up with something better.
Mr President, I voted in favour of the resolution because it is a clear call on the Belarusian government to finally respect human rights.

It is disappointing that the hopes for a democratic development for the people of this last European dictatorship have not been fulfilled with the questionable and falsified parliamentary elections in September.
The same applies to the strategic oppression of the opposition, the sovereign civil society.

At the same time, we have today called on the Council and the Commission to facilitate and intensify contacts between peoples and to democratise the country by seriously considering the possibility of
to reduce the visa fees for Belarusian citizens entering the Schengen area and thereby prevent the increasing isolation of Belarus and its citizens.
I would like to be the first to guard against the spirit of a statement heard a few minutes ago that foreigners would flood our labour market.
And secondly, I would have liked a clearer, more unambiguous report from the Employment Committee.
Trust in the social binding power of the European Union can only be achieved if fundamental social rights are defined as European primary law.

We should send a stronger signal to the Council, the Commission, the Member States and the ECJ and not be satisfied with merely demanding a balance between fundamental rights and internal market freedoms and freedom of movement.
We are not changing anything by doing so. Social fundamental rights are, like freedoms, human rights which must not be restricted by the free movement of the internal market.
It is about defending and improving the European social model, and it is high time to introduce a social progress clause as a binding protocol to the existing EU treaties.
And it is time to change the dispatch directive so that minimum wage and minimum standards are not limited to minimum requirements.
Mr President, I would like to join in thanking the rapporteur, Doris Pack, who has already been rightly expressed by many of my colleagues.
We have with her someone who hopefully doesn't actually shed the blood of the heart, but invests a lot of heart blood in this room.
I am pleased with you and the colleagues who have also said that there has been some progress, also in the area of police cooperation.
This is important so that real life on the ground can also function in a reasonable way.

But I still believe that we must repeatedly point out to our interlocutors in Bosnia and Herzegovina that there is still a great deal to be done by them themselves, perhaps even more than is being done in some areas at the moment.
Internal cooperation, the willingness to cooperate internally within ethnic groups, is something we must constantly demand.
It's not like everybody's trying to go their own way.
And also the integration into regional cooperation in the Western Balkans is important.
Madam President, the distance between the European Union and its citizens must not be as great as it has become.
We have to make sure it's reduced.
In this context, the Ombudsman has an important task to perform, especially when and where he does it well.
It is also about the commitment and the eyes of the Ombudsman.
The point is that we don't raise expectations that are too high and that no one can meet.

But on the other hand, it is also about the fact that wherever there have been irregularities in the administration of the European institutions, they are actually addressed and, if possible, reasonable solutions are sought here, which can then secure and satisfy the citizen.
The practice so far has shown that the Ombudsman takes this task seriously and well.
We can hope that this will continue to be the case, and we thank him and the rapporteur for this report.
It's a little bit of a stretch.
Ladies and gentlemen, ten years after the establishment of monetary union, Europe is in a serious crisis.
Banks are collapsing or being supported with billions of dollars from the state budget, the sales are collapsing, and millions of people are fearing for their jobs and their future.
But it is not only the market that has failed, it is also the ruling politics that seem incapable of learning from their mistakes.

We are of the opinion that even with such interim remarks you do not want to make a special profile, we are of the opinion that serious mistakes have been made in the construction of economic and monetary union.

One such mistake is the structural disintegration of monetary and fiscal policy, and it is impossible to create a common currency without at the same time harmonising tax and spending policies at least in terms of approaches.
I think the economic imbalances in the euro area have worsened enormously.
What we need now is actually better coordination of the economy and, above all, of tax policy.
We need effective measures against tax dumping, and we also need to close tax havens and finally get capital traffic under control again.
The second serious error is in the construction of the Stability and Growth Pact.
Whoever considers it necessary to consolidate the budgets in times like these apparently lives in a different world.
The Stability Pact has clearly demonstrated its failure.
It should be replaced by an integrated European strategy for solidarity and sustainable development.
We believe that an investment offensive is needed to renew public infrastructure and improve the situation of the socially disadvantaged in Europe.
A third mistake we see in the design of the European Central Bank itself, which is not subject to democratic control and is solely committed to the objective of price stability.

We are in favour of democratic control of the European Central Bank and we also call for a correction of the ECB's monetary policy mandate, which must promote growth and employment at least on an equal footing with price stability in the future.
The current crisis also offers an opportunity for profound reforms of the European monetary and financial architecture.
This opportunity should not be taken lightly.
Madam President, Commissioner, President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, the automotive industry is indeed in crisis, and there are many reasons for this.
In particular, the financial crisis has once again exacerbated the crisis in this sector, and solutions are currently being worked out in the Member States.
The European automotive industry is a key industry.
And that is why we need European solutions for this key European industry to deal with the crisis.
Almost all car companies have European structures.

And in order to make the necessary investments in environmentally friendly cars, which have been mentioned here several times today, in order to be able to operate in environmentally friendly and low-cost technologies, car manufacturers need public guarantees or interest-free loans from the European Investment Bank.
But the supply industry, which is very important to me, must not be forgotten.
Especially in the supply industry, it is small and medium-sized enterprises that create jobs and where innovation takes place.
But what can the European Union do to protect this key industry?
At the last plenary session, the President of the Council made a proposal to protect key industries.
A good proposal, as I see it, is a Volkswagen law for the entire European automotive industry.
And this would certainly be a good instrument.
But this protection instrument is currently being fought by the European Commission.
And that is my question to the Commission: will the European Commission stick to a lawsuit despite the crisis in the automotive industry, or will it now change course in the face of the crisis?

Mr President, Mr President of the European Court of Auditors, Mr Vice-President of the European Commission, ladies and gentlemen, it has indeed become a tradition to establish that the European Parliament is the institution of the European Union.
We must ensure that a declaration of reliability cannot be issued repeatedly in the relationship between expenditure at European level and administration at national level.

I can remember conversations with the former President of the Court of Auditors, Professor Friedmann, who once told me that because of the structures, it is not at all possible to give a declaration of reliability.
That is why we should think together about how this instrument can also be filled with life in such a way that the objective of the declaration of reliability, if justified, can also be achieved.
And then, of course, we have to distinguish a few things.
Firstly, a budget with around 95% subsidies is much more prone to fraud than a national budget or a regional or a municipal budget.

A subsidy budget, which is essentially administered by the Member States, which in the new financial period have demanded a lot more independence from us, because the reproach of the last funding period was that it would be too centrally controlled.
This, of course, also means that the responsibility for the money must be taken over regionally and nationally.
And the third area I just want to talk about briefly.
We also have to learn to distinguish between fraud and waste.
These are also things that are always thrown together.
I am also annoyed when EU money is used to promote things that are not necessarily necessary.
But that wasn't fraud, that was waste.

That is why those who are responsible for the projects, in particular in the field of structural policy, the Member States, are also responsible for ensuring that money is not wasted and that only those projects are supported which really add value to the region.
That is why I think we should also think about converting parts of structural policy into interest-free loans.
If Member States have to pay back, then they are only supporting what they really need.
It is not only difficult for me to agree with this emerging self-praise of European decision-makers when it comes to tackling the financial market crisis.
Because if this EU were a functioning democracy, one would first have to ask the question of responsibility and how all this could have happened.
It's just not true that with all the problems that we have now, it would be a tsunami, something natural, but it's man-made.
And with all the regulatory fury that this Union has unleashed, one wonders why action was not taken when, to a considerable extent, banks have begun to cross national borders.
Why, despite the warnings, did they not act when the derivatives were so infiltrated?
I remember well that the Nobel Prize winner, Josef Stiglitz, was here and addressed all these points.
There was a silence, there was a taboo.
That's where you have to start, because in recognizing your own mistakes, there's only the key to the solution in the future.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, my question relates to what you would think if Iceland and Hungary introduced the euro as a secondary currency.
Do you think that would solve the problem of these two countries?
The second question is do you think it would be possible to introduce a risk premium for derivatives, which would then be used to strengthen the equity of banks?
My third question is do you not believe that a reduction in VAT would support imports, especially from China and India, accordingly?
Wouldn't it be more reasonable for our companies and our workers to think about tax cuts, to pay investment premiums, to deduct the progressive deduction accordingly?
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has already made a number of proposals to the Council and the European Parliament on this subject.
Madam President, the comprehensive report illustrates how many human rights violations are taking place in the world on a daily basis.
This is particularly frightening 60 years after the declaration of the Charter of Human Rights and calls for us to step up our efforts.
That is also why I would like to advocate the establishment of the current subcommittee on human rights as the main committee.
Today we awarded the Sakharov Prize to Hu Jia, who is working for human rights and the environment in China.
But because he's in prison, he couldn't take him in person.
It is a disgrace to China, and tomorrow there will be a debate on human rights violations in Russia.
In our relations with these two countries, we must give greater importance not only to economic interests but above all to human rights.
We call for freedom for Hu Jia in China and freedom for Mikhail Khodorkovsky in Russia.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen of the Council, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, as rapporteur for the Office for the Prevention of Fraud, you have had interesting experiences, such as the fact that everyone talks about combating fraud and then no one does anything.
Or the experience that the Member States use a sharp handle to calculate their payments to the European Union, but wear spending pants when spending that money?
For example, it still takes an average of 36 months for irregularities to be reported to the European Union in the first place.
The European Parliament does not agree with this.
We want an efficient fight against fraud, which also includes prevention.
We want the Member States to make fraud prevention a topic and for us to discuss the needs and problems of this together.
We want greater interest on the part of the national judicial authorities in the further prosecution of OLAF's mediation results.
With crooked tours, there can no longer be free spaces like there used to be.
We need an equalization of European money with national money.
We want an independent authority with the necessary resources and legal basis to carry out its tasks.
And we want an office that can work with the Member States in a quiet and efficient way.
Our opinion on the legal basis 1079 provides for all these points.
We are in favour of developing this regulation as a cornerstone of the Anti-Fraud Office together with the Council.
We call on the Council to take a position, we call on the Council to start the discussions on the further development of this regulation.
We want to solve OLAF's problems.
I thank all the groups in the House for supporting this in a resolution which we will be voting on tomorrow.
I appeal to the French and Czech Presidencies of the Council to take up the ball of Parliament and play it back.
We have also taken up solutions developed and introduced by the Council's working group in our proposals.
On our part, I can assure you of our interest in the speedy conclusion of this regulation and of our constructive willingness to discuss our proposals.
A consolidation of all OLAF legal bases, as provided for by the Council, would mean a further considerable loss of time with an uncertain outcome.
OLAF will soon be celebrating its tenth birthday.
Consolidation means another ten years without an improved legal basis.
We are too serious about combating fraud.
That is why we want to make the feasible happen now in cooperation with the Council.
Thank you very much!
Mr President, I would like to take up a remark made earlier by my Austrian colleague, Paul RÃ¼big.
We spend less than 1% of Europe's gross domestic product on Europe, and at the same time we demand that more and more tasks for more and more Member States be handled by the European Union.
This bill cannot be paid, so it is really unbelievable that we have been pursuing a savings rate for many years, but not just in the savings
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter, and if so, what is the Commission's position?
We'd have enough new tasks to spend our money on.
We also have tasks that we haven't really budgeted for in years.
I believe that the European Union's information funds should be significantly increased if we really want to bind European citizens to Europe.
And there are a lot of tasks in the field of student and apprentice exchanges that Europe could do here.
The Commission is also promoting a traditionally state-reserved area in the justice sector.
This corresponds to the changed living conditions of the people in our Union.
But this remark has already been made on several occasions: integration must not go too far into traditionally grown and, above all, functioning structures.
Not everything can be overstated.
Public documents and public persons are designed differently in many Member States.
In Austria, but not only in our country, the notary office as a public document office has a long tradition and a high level of security and trust.
This must not be put at risk without necessity, just because such occupational groups do not exist elsewhere.
So integration and mutual openness, yes, but with eyes.
Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, plant protection products have been and will remain essential to the agricultural industry.
Farmers need a minimum selection of plant protection products, because it is about protecting the local cultural landscape, high-quality nutrition and protecting resources.
We have too many discussions about chemicals on a very irrational level.
But in order to get reasonable results, we must think and act rationally.
The effects of the original parliamentary position would have been fatal: a broad ban on plant protection products, thus reducing agricultural yields and ultimately increasing food prices.
That is why I am pleased that a compromise that is still acceptable has been found in the trilogue negotiations.
It is welcome that we have maintained the three-zone regulation, albeit with considerable exceptions for the Member States.

A bold step towards a consistent internal market solution would look different at this point. e acceptable compromises should not be preceded by a final definition of endocrine-disrupting substances, but should actually give the EU Commission four years to come up with a scientifically based definition.
Otherwise, we are exaggerating the precautionary principle.
And lastly, I regret that we have not been persuaded to carry out an impact assessment of the agreement now reached.
Mr President, when the President of this House made a statement on the last visit of a head of government or a head of state, the President of this House intervened most massively.
At that time it was a matter that was one of his own, namely the Treaty of Lisbon.
If today the president, the sovereignly elected president of a country, speaks and is massively interrupted and disturbed by the socialist side, the president does not intervene.
Do you know what this is?
This is not democracy, this is arbitrariness, and I call for appropriate action to be taken.
Mr President, children and politics are rarely so far apart in the interests of citizens and politicians.
The issue of children is at the top of the agenda for citizens across Europe.
For politicians, children are arranged and live far away, as we can see here again.
I do not know of any country in which there is a Ministry for Children, nor is there a representative of the Commission for the interests of our youngest citizens.
In Parliament, the subject of children is scattered throughout all committees.
That is why I would like to emphasize in particular to the Commission that it is dealing today with childcare facilities and the Barcelona objectives.
Mr President, in our parliamentary working group we have found the following: Our children live in a very complex world.
The future of a person who is a child here, now and today is completely uncertain.
A child today can climb all the way to the top or fall all the way down on the social scale.
It can stay in its own cultural circle or look for a new one.
He can take a similar course to his parents or do just the opposite.
It can marry someone of the opposite sex or of their own sex.
All this was completely different more than 50 years ago, when we brought the United Europe out of the baptism.
The diversity that distinguishes us Europeans has become a determining factor in the lives of children.
The concept of diversity must therefore find its way into the pedagogy of educators and teachers.
This is still far too little taken into account at the moment.
Europe's childcare facilities and schools are breaking down the challenge of integration.
So in integration issues, we have to press the reset button back to start.
So let us approach this issue once again with complete impartiality, in accordance with the motto "Unity through diversity".

And beyond that, I ask all the Members of the European Parliament who follow me to not only stand up for gender mainstreaming, but also to fight for child mainstreaming, especially now in the time of the global financial crisis, because otherwise we are burdening our children with unimaginable debts.
Mr President, I want to make this very brief.
I thank you very much for these constructive contributions to the debate that I have heard here.

I would like to conclude by sending only two messages. Firstly, I would like to express my gratitude to the Commissioner for not having spoken in principle against the concept of the minimum requirements of the safety net.
This proposal is not a devil's work, and it is not a bureaucratic monster.
There is an instrument for solving problems that we should give a chance to.
That's why I'd like to advertise it again.
And the second thing I would like to say, and this is addressed to my British friends, is cross all the parties.
My dear British friends, I understand Caroline, I understand your problem.
I can understand that the energy security of a country is being put above the compliance with an air pollution limit for a certain period of time.
I have a great understanding of that.
I am also the last person who would not give Her Majesty additional time when it comes to building new coal-fired power plants.
We can talk about it.
The problem is, that's exactly what we didn't do.
This conversation has never taken place in the last four months.
I would like to ask you, this is now the outlook for the second reading, to be open-minded at this point again and to say let us talk about a compromise at this point.
I am in favour of abandoning the fundamental opposition to the minimum standards, which in my view is completely irrational, unjustifiable in terms of competition policy and environmental policy.
I think that's where you can reach a compromise, which I hope we'll get at the end of the second reading.
By the way, I do not think that we should not seek a compromise at first reading.
This legislation is too complex for that.
I do not want to end this legislature as rapporteur and leave it to the next Parliament to legislate on a text of law which is not consistent, which is illogical and contradictory.
That is why I ask for support for the compromises if we vote on them in an hour.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I think the crucial question in all the economic programmes that are now being implemented throughout Europe is, of course, who will ultimately get the money?
More blank checks are issued to banks, although the rapid nationalization would ultimately be much cheaper for the taxpayer.
Should corporations and high-income earners be further relieved of their burden, even though they have been fed tax gifts throughout Europe for years?

The more money is wasted for such purposes, the more likely it is that such programmes will fail, and the more likely it is that the European economy will continue to sink into a very dangerous downward spiral.

The years of privatization, deregulation and liberalization have concentrated income more and more in the top ten thousand, and it is this policy that is responsible for the current crisis in which we find ourselves today.
And whoever believes that he can overcome this crisis by continuing to pursue precisely this policy with minor modifications, I think he simply doesn't understand anything.
The exact opposite is necessary.
Instead of buying up lazy papers from the banks, taxpayers' money should be used to repair schools, hospitals and to rebuild the European economy in an ecological way.

If private companies receive public funds, there must be no tax money without employment guarantees and, above all, no tax money without the acquisition of public ownership rights, so that the state and, above all, the general public can later also be involved in future revenues.
The very best economic recovery program that exists today would be a radical redistribution of income and wealth from the top down.
The hunger wage sector in Europe must be pushed back instead of being promoted further and further.
We need higher minimum wages, we need better social services in Europe.

And we need taxes to ensure that the millionaires and the profiteers of the past financial market party now also bear the immense losses that have arisen, and not the vast majority of citizens who have never gotten anything out of the whole financial boom.
I think that social justice is currently the only sensible economic policy.
And it's the only way to break through the devastating crisis dynamic.

Mr President, at the beginning of March, the political prisoners Mikhail Khodorkovsky and Platon Lebedev were transferred from Chita in Siberia to Moscow to be charged again on grounds of unsubstantiated accusations.
The first public hearing was scheduled for 31 March.
On the same day, human rights consultations between the EU and Russia were to take place.
These important talks have now been postponed indefinitely by the Russian side.
Russia is showing very clearly the low value it attaches to human rights.
Justice continues to be used not only for justice, but also to eliminate opponents of the regime, and the EU is thus duped.
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I am particularly grateful to Commissioner Verheugen for once again referring to the ban on animal testing.

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has already made a number of proposals to the Council and the European Parliament on the subject of cosmetic products.
And we did manage to ban animal experiments.
We've managed to get consumers to know, for example, how long a product is still viable by seeing a small box with a number in it that says how long it's still valid.
I say this also to the address of some colleagues, especially to Mrs Reutova, who unfortunately was not able to be present at the beginning.
Every product on this European market must be safe and sound.
But the labelling gives consumers the opportunity to choose.
That's democracy, and that's your freedom of choice.
I think we have very good legislation.
I have tried to make the procedure very transparent.
I have tried, as Mrs Cosette has said, to bring together different opinions.

Because it is important to me that we make legislation that is good for everyone, for the consumers in the European Union, for the industry that has to work with this legislation and ultimately for all those who benefit from it.
I would like to say to Mr Schnellhardt that yes, the DEO works differently for everyone, but the statement "keep it sweat-free" is still made.
That is why it is important that the statements about my folding depth around the eyes after a week in Strasbourg are also somewhat real and reliable.
I would like to thank the Commissioner again, including for the statements he has made, my colleagues and my colleague who has done most of the work.
Thank you very much.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Van Nistelrooij's report on the Green Paper and the future form of cohesion policy is certainly one of the most important reports of the Committee on Regional Development in recent years.
We agree with the basic concept of the Green Paper, which is that territorial cohesion is about the polycentric development of the EU.
In general, as well as to ensure the sustainable development of the sovereignty areas with various characteristics and peculiarities and at the same time to preserve their diversity.
It is right that in the next planning period a more comprehensive system of gradual aid for transition regions, the threshold of 75
It is necessary to create a system that exceeds the gross domestic product, so that these regions receive a clear status and thus have more security in their development.
In the report by Mrs Crewe on obstacles to the introduction of the Structural Funds, the most significant shortcomings are rightly listed, ahead of those by applicants.
The structural funds can be used, for example, to finance excessive administrative expenditure, too many complex regulations, slow and cumbersome centralised administration in the Member States.
A number of recommendations will be made to the Commission on the effective measures to be taken to remove these obstacles.
I would just like to highlight and confirm two such measures.
Firstly, project managers currently have to keep their project documents for a period of ten years in order to have them on hand for checks, which may be carried out by the Commission.
This is an excessive bureaucratic effort, especially for smaller projects.
It is right that this should now be reduced to a period of three years, and secondly, the EU Commission's assessment criteria for innovative projects pose considerable problems.
Innovative projects must not be subject to the same evaluation criteria as other projects.
It is simply necessary that something else be done here.

Madam President, if Europe is taking money in hand and if, above all, the Member States are taking a lot of money in hand to help the automotive industry in its crisis situation, then it cannot just be about securing the stock and the status quo and preventing bankruptcy, but it is about a number of other issues.
The most important have been mentioned.
It's about people looking for jobs, and they need to secure those jobs in the long run.
And to do that, we need to promote new technologies, innovation and, above all, sustainability in the transport system more than we have done so far.
We should therefore link all our measures to these objectives so that we do not have to let ourselves be blamed in a few years' time.
Madam President, it would be nice if you would also grant me the half minute which my Green colleague, Mrs Breyer, has just received.
The Commission had put forward a good proposal to update the regulation on novel foods.

Unfortunately, some amendments seek to supplement this proposal by providing for provisions which are incompatible with the objectives of the regulation or which even seek to interfere with existing legislation.
The obligation of food business owners to monitor new foods with a view to the health and welfare of animals would simply overwhelm traders.

And once again there is an attempt to undermine the existing GMO laws, namely the demand for a special labelling of such novel foods obtained from animals that have been fed with genetically modified feed.
We just heard it.
In principle, everything that affects GVO legislation should not be covered by the Noble Food Regulation.
I say this despite the fact that I myself, for example, had proposed that the definition of novel foods should be targeted at new plant species.
But it cannot be that interested circles in this House are abusing the Novel Food Regulation for election purposes.
Such an attempt is also apparently the case with Amendments 62 and 90, for which the Greens have requested a roll-call vote.
Who, dear colleagues, do you want to accuse?
My group has always advocated the right of the consumer to know what is in food.
So why shouldn't the declaration of ingredients point to a nano-derivative?
And although Amendment No 62 is trying to go a little clumsy with my report on food labelling, I have to tell you that I think this labelling of novel foods is quite compatible with my report.

I therefore recommend to my group that these requests be approved, and I will include in my report on the food labelling regulation references to the part of the Noble Food Regulation dealing with labelling.
This is possible because we have postponed the first reading on food labelling to the next parliamentary term against the will of the Greens.
But now it is clear to everyone how beneficial this postponement was.
Short on cloning, that is animal cruelty.
We're against it.
Nevertheless, foodstuffs must be included in this regulation accordingly, because otherwise they would be in a
Madam President, it is quite simple.
If you do not want this man to preside over the opening ceremony of the European Parliament, you should agree to my request to amend the Rules of Procedure.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, one thing is clear: the supply of food to the needy, especially in these economically difficult times, is not up for debate in the forthcoming vote on our colleague Mr Csikerski's report.
That is why I would like to make it clear at the outset that it was not easy to find a common line within our group.
I therefore respect the personal decision of any colleague in the group to deviate from this and not to agree to the rejection of the report which we have in mind.
Why can I not agree to the outcome of the committee vote in this form?
There are a number of reasons for this, none of which have anything to do with helping the needy in the European Union in these economically difficult times.

On the contrary, the amendments tabled by my colleague, Mr Nils Busk, on behalf of the ALDE Group, but unfortunately not considered to be admissible, should serve to put the existing system on a viable basis.
Because the current system is an anachronism from the days of agricultural overproduction, which, fortunately, belongs to the past.
Thanks to the successful decoupling of direct payments, intervention stocks have steadily decreased in recent years, so that today up to 85% of food must be bought on the free market.
However, this has fundamentally changed the nature of the programme and has led to the loss of the agricultural policy dimension.
But now that we are dealing with a social programme, we must create a legal basis for this.
We hereby share the assessment of the Council's Legal Service, which, instead of Article 37 of the EC Treaty on the common agricultural policy, merely
Article 308 as a legal basis for the possibility, because otherwise it is clearly an interference with the national competences of the Member States.
The only solution, in view of the inadmissibility of our amendments, can only be a new draft by the European Commission.

It should also continue to apply the principle of co-financing, because only on the ground can such programmes be judged to be meaningless and nonsensical in the sense that they are all part of peace.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all we welcome the proposal of the European Commission and this Green Paper on the principle of subsidiarity.
There is, and this is not a topic, a mass phenomenon that has been described by the various speakers, where relatively small damage occurs in a large number of affected people.
The damage to the person concerned itself is small, but in total it is large.
We need an instrument to deal with this problem.
I think it's right to think about something like that.

I also welcome, to remain positive, the fact that the Directorate-General for Consumer Protection has also placed a very decisive emphasis in its Green Paper on the question of alternative dispute settlement mechanisms.

This is a big difference from the White Paper on competition, which was also discussed here yesterday, and which has so far completely ignored this possibility of out-of-court dispute settlement mechanisms.
I think the Consumer Protection Directorate is further along in its Green Paper than its competitors.
But I would also like to make two things quite clear, which I think are quite understandable as critical remarks.
Parliament will adopt my report on the White Paper on competition from the Directorate-General in a few minutes' time at 12 o'clock.
We shall be asking the European Commission, by an overwhelming majority in this House, to adopt a horizontal approach in dealing with this question.
It cannot be that in the end we have sectoral instruments, one for consumer protection, one for cartel law, one for the capital market and perhaps one for the environment.

Perhaps one more for social, and they all contradict each other, they all interfere with the legal order of the Member States and eventually lead to a legal political confusion that can no longer be handled by any practitioner.
We've had examples like this many times in the past.
I am only thinking of the debate on the vocational qualification directive, which we later summarised in one instrument because this fragmentation was no longer possible.
The Commission should not make the same mistake here.
It should promote a horizontal approach from the outset.
That is Parliament's clear position, and in a few months, in a few minutes, it will be clear.

And last but not least, I also very much welcome the fact that we have reached a consensus that we do not want a US-style lawsuit industry with a turnover of 240 billion US dollars a year, which in the end only benefits lawyers and the consumer has nothing to do with it.
We want a genuine rule of law in Europe and to remain in our traditional systems and in our legal understanding.
Ladies and gentlemen, there are many ways of dealing with the lasting consequences of the unexpected financial and economic crisis.

This revision package, this legislative measure under the European Economic Recovery Programme, is conceived as a good answer, albeit not entirely sufficient, but it is first and foremost a good answer to this temporary, albeit extremely critical situation.
This includes, inter alia, the promotion of greater simplification of procedures and greater flexibility in the application of existing

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the European Parliament has repeatedly called for the introduction of these provisions in the framework of the Structural Funds Regulation.
It is also welcome, and I would like to emphasise this in particular, that an amendment to Article 7 on the eligibility of expenditure should enable the Member States and regions of the EU to:
Structural policy funding for energy efficiency and renewable energy in housing construction and that these measures should not only apply to low-income households.
The amendment in this respect therefore rightly deletes the line 'households with low incomes' and instead puts a ceiling of 4 of the total EFSF allocation for each Member State for such expenditure.
This is just one of the many improvements proposed.
In short, this overall package is being implemented, is an acceleration of expenditure and thus further liquidity for the implementation of necessary
There are guidelines on the use of the Structural Funds, the ESF and the Cohesion Fund, and a simplification of the provisions allowing the programmes to be implemented quickly.
A contribution, I believe, effective, though not yet sufficient, to the management of the current crisis situation.
Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I generally welcome the European environmental label.
It is right that we take a new approach to spreading this environmental sign to the community.
And I also think it's right that in the future we stick to volunteering.
In the future, the sign will only prevail if there are clear criteria and standards that require the acquisition of this sign.
Here I appeal to the EU Commission to draw up reasonable, clear and understandable criteria.
The idea of incentives must be at the forefront.
It would be unfortunate if the establishment of the environmental sign fails bureaucratic hurdles.
Success or failure is ultimately up to the consumer, because it has to be accepted.

Even if I personally am very much attached to the blue angel that we have in Germany, it must not be a matter of taste in the end, but it is important that the consumer is informed at a glance what special properties a product has.
A surplus value for the consumer arises only if the Member States give up their own signs and there is ultimately a uniform sign at European level.
A confusion of symbols unsettles the consumer and does not inform him.
A sign, a statement, for which we should work together.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I think that in this legislative period we have put a lot of things in place together in terms of the discharge procedure for the European institutions.

But I regret that it has taken so long, because in principle we have only now worked out all that has already been achieved with the resignation of the Commission in 1999, that is to say, ten years ago.

This shows that we still need to improve our working methods and procedures and ensure that the necessary transparency is restored more quickly when it comes to ensuring that citizens know what the tax money is being used for.
I should like to thank Mr Casaca in particular, with whom I had the honour of working on Parliament's discharge for the EPP Group.

I very much regret that a colleague who speaks very intensively through the press on various issues in the European Parliament does not take part in the committee's deliberations, votes or the plenary debate here.
And I want to make that very clear at this point, so that it is preserved and will remain preserved for posterity, because we know very well that there have been a number of problems here.
It is the Members who have been here for the last five years who have ensured that the necessary reforms have been achieved in the interests of Members in a number of areas.
And for that, we all have a very heartfelt thank you. We have done what is necessary, and we have not made sure that everything is widely reported in the media, but not co-worked.
Thank you very much for your serious cooperation.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the ODI report, thank you very much to the rapporteur, really takes us further because it contains innovative elements, such as naming and shaming, a milestone in budgetary control.
Targeted criticism instead of blanket accusations.
The fact that the Socialist Group is now making a retreat and preferring to turn the truth under the carpet is a scandal and a bearish service to our control tasks.
But the credibility of Parliament is at stake, and I appeal to my colleagues not to allow this.
A word to our greatest caring children, Romania and Bulgaria.
The Commission's failure to prepare for accession will be most tangible here.
We lost a lot of money.
The Commission has been watching for a long time and only froze funds in 2008 for Bulgaria, now over one billion euros, for Romania around 142 million euros.
Freezing money is not a solution to the problems.
The cooperation and verification mechanism for which the President of the Commission is responsible is a piece of paper, and the progress reports deserve the name.
Here the Audy report makes suggestions on how things could be better.
The EU Commission has deceived Parliament about the maturity of these countries' accession, and in fact the enlargement commissioner would have to draw consequences from this.
But for us it is about the management of future memberships, and that is why this issue remains on the agenda.
Our group will share the burden with the Commission, but I will personally refuse the Commission the burden.
Unfortunately, the Commission's zeal for reform, which was foreshadowed last year, has already been extinguished.
There is no stopping the fight against fraud, nothing on prevention, no more ethics, nothing desirable, etc.
One thing the Commission and Commissioner Kallas in particular should be clear about is that those who want to be part of the new Commission must rely on Parliament's support.
Mr President, yes, we have a problem with copyright, and we have a problem with the remuneration of artists.
That's right, and we have to be active and do something about it.
But when we become active, it's about really responding to the challenges of the digital age and not saddling dead horses.
I'll explain to you why I'm using that word.
The proposal before us actually fulfils only one promise, and that is the promise to promote the music industry.
Because if we look at what happens to the artists themselves and their income, and we calculate that, then we get
So low an average amount that it's by no means the livelihood of an artist to make something out of it.
Besides, this money doesn't go directly to the artists.
And the fund is too small to achieve anything.
An artist I discussed this with told me that there is an unfolding of the living to the dead.
I have to contradict him, it's a redistribution from the artists to the producers, to the music industry, and only to the big ones.
All in all, Commissioner, this proposal is not appropriate.
We have to find better ones.
We have to create something like a flat rate, for example.
The proposals you make in relation to the use it or loose it clause also remain theoretical.
Please let us do something wise and well-founded, as the artists have recommended and requested in our hearing in the Legal Affairs Committee.
Mr President, I regret, along with the rapporteur, Mr Gilles Sabary, that the Commission has not continued to pursue its original plan for an integrated action plan.
There are many good reasons why all stakeholders, from the municipalities to the European Union, are working to improve urban transport conditions.
We know that most people in Europe live in cities and that the current traffic conditions are anything but optimal.
It is therefore essential that the agreement to the plan and to Mr Savary's report be based on Parliament's initiative to draw up appropriate integrated proposals.
I thank him for his commitment and also for the concrete proposals.
At the same time, however, I would like to make it very clear that what many people fear or believe they have to fear will not happen.
No one wants to take away the right of the municipalities, the local and regional authorities to determine their traffic conditions.
We on the European side only want to help to ensure that this is done according to reasonable common rules, if a municipality, if a city, if a regional unit thinks it is reasonable.
The principle of subsidiarity is not at risk.
What we want to do here is to protect this principle.
It remains therefore in the interest of the citizens that we do not allow a citizen to travel within 10 kilometres.
As he travels through Europe, he encounters a traffic-free zone that he believes he knows from his home community, and there he finds completely different rules for it.
No one wants to impose city tolls or other regulations on any municipality, but if they are actually used here, then they should also be made for the citizens within a recognizable framework.
For more than a hundred years, we have agreed on the usefulness of common approaches to the issue of road signs.
This should also be the case in the future.
Mr President, we have been dealing with urban transport in the EU for a long time.
Why is that?

We are not responsible at all, because the responsibility was originally constructed, because about 80 percent of the population lives in urban areas, and because of the climate debate, they want to take over the matter now.
Fortunately, we were able to reduce these ambitions of the European Commission by protesting against an action plan on urban transport.
And I thank Commissioner Tajani for his insight.
Subsidiary actually means supporting rather than prescribing, but of course he knows that better than I do as an Italian, as a German with only a large Latin.
It is first and foremost important to me that our report, the Parliament's report, emphasises strict compliance with the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality.
Legislative measures at European level are unacceptable for urban transport.
Supporting measures, that's our job.
A collection of ideas and the promotion of the exchange of best practices is meaningful.
Not everyone has to reinvent the wheel.
Our cities need tailor-made solutions, but they can only be worked out by the actors on the ground, because only they know what is necessary.
The municipalities have to cope with very different situations, so they need sufficient room for manoeuvre, also to keep the inner-city trade alive.
That's important for the attractiveness of a city.
It is therefore important not to block motorised individual traffic and to take better care of the logistics in the city.
I would therefore like to see research on urban fine distribution promoted.
That relieves a city.
It is also important to take into account demographic change.
Our society is getting older and older.
Mobility needs and housing requirements are changing.
We need a housing-friendly supply of goods for the daily needs of the population if we are to reduce traffic, and this is also a challenge to retail trade.
Everything else would only require the green meadow.
Finally, we do not need an observation post for urban traffic.
Such a place would cost a lot of money and produce a lot of paper that would only be seized in Brussels.
Madam President, I fully support the Commission's aim of creating a legal framework for the coordinated introduction and use of intelligent transport systems in road transport.

My years of personal struggle for the serial introduction of eCall, the electronic emergency call system, make the urgency clear to me almost daily, but intelligent transport systems can do much more.
They serve environmental sustainability, efficiency improvement, safety gains and non-discriminatory competitiveness in road goods and passenger transport.

In addition, they support commodity, inter alia, by developing interfaces to other modes of transport such as rail, waterways and air transport, where the introduction of intelligent transport systems has long since begun.
All this cannot be achieved by the Member States alone, but only as a matter for the Community.

Intelligent transport systems, based on EU-wide binding basic standards and minimum quality regulations, improve the environment for innovation and create planning security, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises.
In particular, I welcome the planned open vehicle-integrated platform for intelligent transport system services.
The action plan finally includes a timetable for the introduction of individual systems, a for road safety such as ESP and eCall, b for continuity in traffic management, for example information
C. The use of road, transport and travel data in real time will not only enrich professional drivers, but also all road users.
The Directive sets out detailed requirements for the uniform, binding and coordinated introduction of intelligent transport systems and their application in the Member States.
It also ensures the handling of personal data.
But attention, the introduction of intelligent transport systems is costly, as infrastructure and vehicles must first be equipped with the necessary information and communication technologies.
We still know too little about the willingness and ability to pay of potential users.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we clearly support aid for people with rare diseases.
But Amendment No 15 is ethically completely unacceptable.
There must never again be a debate in Europe about life and death.
There must be no political or social pressure on parents in Europe to deliberately oppose a disabled child.
The selection of embryos would be a major ethical breakthrough.
That is why this amendment must be rejected, and it is not enough if we simply erase the word which, unfortunately, is in fact a fascist idiom.
But there would still be talk of an embryo selection.
And it would be unbearable if this amendment, which speaks of a selection of embryos, were to become a stepping stone to a new ethic in Europe.
We must resolutely oppose genetic discrimination.
That is why Amendment No 15 must be rejected in its entirety, otherwise our group would unfortunately also be forced to vote against this report, which is otherwise quite positive.

Mr President, I voted against the discharge for the Commission in the discharge vote for the first time since I have been a member of this House, and I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is prepared to accept it.
I would like to explain my reasons. For me, it is mainly a question of the way in which the European Commission has handled and managed the accession of the two new countries, Romania and Bulgaria.
We are dealing in Romania and Bulgaria with a lot of problems, with a high corruption rate, with a lot of money, with a lot of European money that has disappeared.
The European Commission did not start freezing these funds until 2008.
We lost a lot of money in 2007 and now we are dealing with hardly any control systems or control systems that only work with gaps.
In Romania, we are dealing with a high corruption rate and problems with the judiciary.
All this is to be blamed on the pre-accession process.

I am also going to send a signal to the European Commission that it must do otherwise for future accessions and that, if it has already been observed in other countries, it could be more successful if it so wishes.
I would like to ask the Commission to help the two countries in building financial control systems that deserve this name and to help eliminate the systemic weaknesses in these two countries.
Otherwise, we have a permanent problem and a permanent concern for the whole of Europe.

Madam President, I would like to draw your attention to the fact that behind me in the field of right-wing radicals are people who are not Members of Parliament, and as far as I can see, they are very well represented on the ballot.
Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I expressly welcome the draft report by Mr Horst Schnellhardt and thank him for his good work.
After the numerous crises of recent years in connection with products of animal origin which pose a danger to the health of humans and animals, comprehensive legal regulation is essential.
A revision of the current regulations has become necessary.
We still need to ensure a high level of security.
Although we agree with the report in principle, I see some points that make me think.
The regulation was made less stringent in many respects, thus loosening the traffic in animal by-products somewhat.
There are some examples of a permit for the use of certain category 1 materials in pet food.
Materials of category 2 or 3 may be disposed of more easily, regardless of their risk, under official supervision, with a small amount of waste per week.
However, the risk of animal by-products of any category is only partially determined by the quantity.
It remains to be seen whether the European Commission will adopt the implementing regulation, and the draft contains, as in the previous one, many empowerments for the Commission.

This means that the Commission can make comprehensive and fundamental arrangements for the handling of animal by-products in the comitology procedure, which means that Parliament, as is unfortunately often the case, is outside.
Mr President, Mr Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, Afghanistan has a difficult history.
I believe that it is the families who are very close together and that women play an important role in the family.
That is why economic development is also very important, namely the support of small and mediumsized enterprises should be particularly encouraged.
And, of course, we also need a modern infrastructure that simply helps the country to develop better.

And I believe that infrastructure projects in particular could help to create a greater understanding between each other here, and of course, through the means of information and communication technology, a different worldview could slowly take place there with full adherence to the identity.

The pollution of the seas is always at the centre of attention only when there has been another spectacular incident, and then the threat to our seas from this continuing pollution is also hotly debated.
Unfortunately, in the meantime, this is becoming very, very far behind.
The constant and repeated violations, which contribute just as much and dramatically to the threat to not only our seas but also to our coasts, were to be taken seriously by us.
I would like to thank my colleagues with whom we have been able to discuss this, because we have all consistently stood for the line that our sea must be protected.
I am speaking here as a member of a home country, but I still feel, as a European, that our seas are responsible for the continuing pollution from cheap economic
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter, and if so, what is the Commission's position?
Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Obiol Sigama, on his very good report.
Mr President, in many countries around the world, respect for human rights is very poor.
But also here in Europe, if we think of Belarus, for example.
The European Union must therefore step up its efforts by implementing human rights policy in all areas and setting clear standards.
In our understanding, human rights are indivisible.
This can be done, for example, during the negotiations on a new agreement with Russia through a binding human rights clause which has an influence in all areas of negotiation.
Furthermore, I would like to call once again for the Subcommittee on Human Rights to become a main committee.
Mr President, the EPP Group calls on the government and the Communist Party of China to conduct the upcoming human rights dialogue in a constructive manner.
This would significantly relax relations between the EU and China.
We have a genuine interest in improving bilateral relations.
But this dialogue must also be conducted honestly.
That is why we will have to maintain our legitimate demands on China.
So, from our point of view, the right of citizens to be released immediately.
So the conversations with the Dalai Lama as the religious leader of Tibet are resumed.
And so the Chinese region of Tibet must be made immediately accessible to journalists and UN human rights experts.
In my opinion, the People's Republic of China has shown before the Olympic Games that it can grant more freedom of the press, for example, without jeopardizing the stability of the country.
Now she should have the courage to embark on new reforms, reforms on re-education camps, the rights of the accused, the death penalty, freedom of religion, freedom of assembly.
She should really address these human rights and engage in dialogue with us.
Madam President, Madam Vice-President, I would also like to congratulate the Czech Senate on its decision today, which we welcome with great pleasure and warmly congratulate.
President Klaus responded, among other things, by claiming that the Treaty of Lisbon was still dead, because it had been rejected by the referendum in Ireland.

In doing so, he is acting as a political zombie, attacking the majority decisions of his own parliament and the Senate, and confirming his disgraceful and sectarian attitude in other areas of politics.
Fortunately, after the positive votes, he only makes himself ridiculous.
We Greens are positive and constructive about the European integration process, of course with critical remarks where necessary.
Once again, thank you very much to the Czech Senate, Parliament and the Government.
Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, last week we heard Mr Machmalbach in a foreign policy committee which, to my delight, has been appointed as a new Member.
An Iranian film director who made it very clear to us that before this election there was 20 democracies in Iran, after this election, which was a coup for him, there is no democracy at all.
I too agree with this description. It was a coup d'Ã©tat, which with massive electoral fraud took away the right of the majority of the Iranian people who spoke out for change.

Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I am particularly interested in the fact that in mid-August there will be an inauguration of Mr Ahmadinejad, who has been re-elected under the guise of a leader.
What is currently being discussed in the Council and also with the Member States?
Will there be an official, formal representation of the European Union and also of the Member States?
I hope that this will not happen, because I believe that after this election coup there must be no official representation of the European Union or the European Parliament.
I am very much in favour of further dialogue, but I think that no one should be officially represented by the European Union at this inauguration.
What is your position on this?
How is this being handled at the moment?
Mr President, Mr Giegold, the crisis in Europe was not caused by unethical behaviour on the financial markets alone, Mr Barroso.
There is the growing social inequality, there are the dangerous and unsolidarity macroeconomic imbalances between the Member States, and there is Europe's dependence on rising resource prices.

The citizens of Europe deserve a Commission which puts these deeper causes on the agenda again and again, instead of tabooing them, instead of doing the opposite, instead of shifting the responsibility to the Member States.
We need genuine European coordination of economic and fiscal policy.
We need tax cooperation in Europe to end tax dumping.
Only then will it be possible to stop the social divide and finance the necessary ecological investments.
We need a policy that promotes green technologies and lifestyles so consistently that the EU's dependence on endless resources is sharply declining.
This is an ecological green revolution, and I do not find that in your programme, Mr Barroso.
That's why I can't vote for you.
Mr Barroso, imagine that you are a politician and that you are a politician.
You would be running for office in Europe, just you, all alone, no other candidate.
What would the citizens do?
I think they would have listened to you today and seen that you promised everyone everything.
Hopefully, they'll also get the information they did five years ago.
You've promised most of them a lot.
Then you have to compare what you've already promised, what you're promising now, with what's to be expected.
I think that's very, very little.
They stand for the old, for the failed Europe, for the contribution to the financial crisis, because the Commission has failed, for the lack of commitment to climate issues and so on and so forth.
I would take the side of the majority of European citizens, because I believe that they would not get more than 10 or 12 or 15 votes.
Mr President, I would like to speak in favour of maintaining the new proposal, because it is clear that the negotiations in Honduras have failed.
There is no common proposal for this election.
This election is illegitimate because the current president came to power through a coup.
That is to say, I ask the plenary to give its consent to the proposal of the Bureau to amend this amendment, to exclude the elections.
Mr President, democracy needs a revolution, and it is never wrong, Mr Dartmouth, to speak out for transparency, Mr Verhofstadt.
And it is precisely you, now in the Swedish Presidency of the Council, who could be a shining example and then really tell us how it went.
It is about the very unworthy post-checker in the top positions for the European project and also, Mr Barroso, could go ahead with the appointment of the Commissioner.
Germany and Austria are providing a negative example, but unfortunately others are also providing a negative example.
Qualified people are sitting in this room, but they don't have access.

Please be so brave now that the Lisbon Treaty has been adopted, and be honest and say that we need much clearer decision-making structures, transparent decision-making structures for the Commission and the opposition.
It would have to be possible to find the good people here in the European Parliament with so much expertise and not to bring them up in any of the federal states.
Mr President, the subject we are discussing here this evening has been on the agenda of the European Parliament on several occasions.
As is well known, the Commission is guided by the conditions of the International Monetary Fund when granting aid.
That's been said a few times.
It is against this background that the EP has repeatedly asked the Commission for its opinion.
In November 2008, the EP asked the Commission to present an analysis of the impact of the behaviour of banks that had transferred their assets from the Member States which had recently joined.
On 24 April of this year, the EP repeated this demand.

Furthermore, the EP has called for information to be given on the declarations of intent, which are concluded in detail between the Commission and the Member States receiving aid and in which the conditions for aid are set out in detail.
As far as I know, these questions have not been answered to date.
My first question is therefore: Is it true that these questions have not been answered so far?
If that is true, then my second question is why these questions have not been answered so far.
My third question is when can we expect an answer to these questions?
Ladies and gentlemen, the GUE NGL will not agree to this resolution.
The Stockholm Programme is completely overlooking the real challenges of the present.
The main mistake is that a Europe of rights is being established, which is to be granted to EU citizens, not to other people living in Europe.
The same citizens and human rights should not be preserved.
On the one hand, the EU wants to join the Charter of Human Rights, which we welcome, but on the other hand, migrants are being sorted out legally or illegally.
This is how Frontex is being equipped for the massive fight against so-called illegal migration, and I tell you, it is completely distorting the view of an unprecedented immigration policy.
This is where Stockholm fails.
Another problem is the completely unbalanced relationship between security and freedom.
Yes, there is no freedom without security, but there is also no security without freedom.

Stockholm, on the other hand, symbolizes the EU's security frenzy by creating huge supranational databases without adequate control capabilities, combining information services and police data across Europe.
This makes the right to information self-determination of people, to the makulature and vision of a glass-like human being, a reality.
In conclusion, as an East German Member of Parliament, let me say that 20 years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, it is unbearable for me to see Europe become more and more of a fortress.
Mr President, Commissioner, you are right, the railway system is a very safe system compared to other modes of transport.

However, in addition to many positive aspects, liberalisation in the form of the fragmentation of individual companies, the separation of infrastructure and operations, the outsourcing of maintenance work and the leasing of material and staff has led to a number of uncertainties.
In my view, it must be ensured that the national security authorities issue the safety certificates and authorisations as prescribed by the ERA, according to the railway agency.
Are there enough controls?
For example, it is ensured that the training of staff, certification and working conditions are properly controlled.
What is the situation in this context with the introduction of a uniform Community certificate?
What about the European driver's license?
The efforts concerning ERTS need to be further increased.
The implementation plan recently drawn up and indicated by you must be binding and must not be dragged by financial or national considerations.
Efforts to introduce the technical specifications of the TSI must be continued and extended.
This would be a huge step forward, especially with the homologation of the material, and a higher level of safety with the maintenance of the material.
Many of the recent railway accidents and near-accidents are due to poor maintenance.
For cost reasons, the intensity is particularly neglected and the intervals between maintenance work are extended.
What about a Europe-wide certification system for maintenance workshops?
In my view, everything must be done to prevent each Member State from returning to its old rules and acting differently and independently again.
In particular, border crossings between individual Member States pose a security risk.
How does the Commission intend to deal with this problem in the short term?
And in the balance sheet that you are drawing up, I would like you to take into account the social aspects that have not been forgotten.
We need a revolution of democracy. Mr President, Commissioner, good morning in this new world of the Treaty of Lisbon. This is an opportunity for you.
For eleven years now, I have been following your reports in this House, first as a journalist, and finally as a journalist, and they are very similar.
But now you have the opportunity to look ahead.
I see colleagues SÃ¶ndergaard, I see colleagues Tchaikovsky, there is Mr Staes, there is my colleague Mr Ehrenhauser from our list, and put the work of the Court of Auditors back on.
Look at what else works in Germany, where you can check the cost-effectiveness and the usefulness of the expenditure in Austria and work out

I would like to ask you for a concept, perhaps in the context of an initiative report which is now before Parliament, on how to make what you are doing much better so that you can actually do your job.
We need a revolution of democracy.
I remember very well that the debates as we hear them today began ten years ago in this House.
I would urge you, Madam Commissioner, to write in the genealogy, above all, what comes from ALDE, but also from the Greens and some left-wing Members.
Do you not realize that with the approach that the European Union has taken in the negotiations, and that is that we cannot, as honest brokers, eliminate the distortion?
The developing countries are in many ways what they are today no longer developing countries.
We are very confident in the development of the countries.
If the European side fails to dare to start a new state with fair rules, then we will end up where we do not want to end up, namely in protectionism and, in 1933, in Europe.
Mr President, I would just like to use the blue card for a correct position.
Support in Austria is not only granted to one person.

Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a microfinance instrument for the unemployed, those at risk of unemployment and, above all, for people who do not have access to normal credit markets is a good intention and is supported by our group on principle.
However, what the Commission and the Council have done in this procedure so far is simply inadequate, partly wrong and cannot be supported by our group.
The first point of criticism is the question of financial equipment.
What is on the table in terms of financial equipment is not financial equipment for a programme to combat unemployment, it cannot be called a microfinance programme, it is at most nanofinance.
Secondly, we are fundamentally opposed to making such tricks without any effect, which are detrimental to other programmes and thus endlessly wasteful.
Thirdly, the view that the sustainability and success of such a programme must involve organic mentoring and coaching.
Many new start-ups, especially in the microfinance sector, are failing, which is why this must also be ensured within the programme.
Fourthly, it must be ensured that social security benefits in the Member States are not abolished for the purpose of applying for this programme, otherwise they will be ineffective.
This cannot be used to combat unemployment in a sustainable way.
We will reject it in this form.
Mr President, today, after eight years, we all know that the previous military-based strategy in Afghanistan has failed.
The mismatch between military operations on the one hand and the insufficient resources for civilian purposes on the other is a real obstacle to improving the living conditions in Afghanistan.
And that is why our most important message as the UN is that a radical change of strategy must come.
We need a radical change of strategy away from the military and above all towards the people.
This means that 40 percent of Afghans are unemployed, more than half of them live in really bitter poverty, have no health care, no adequate education.
The social issue must be put at the forefront, and we expect this from the Council, from the Commission and from all those involved.
This, of course, includes strengthening responsible government action, strengthening agriculture, integrating former Taliban fighters.
But I'll tell you honestly, if you go halfway down this road and go back to military adventure, you'll miss every chance.
It's five minutes to 12:00.
Madam President, my question goes in the direction of Is it not sensible to prevent unemployment at all?
Do you see public tasks that could be handed over to the unemployed?
And above all, how can we strengthen small and medium-sized enterprises so that new ones can be established?
Is there any possibility of applying cross-country methods and best practices to create more and new enterprises?
We need a revolution of democracy.
Especially as an admirer of so many Swedish traditions, I was all the more disappointed in the balance sheet of their activities.
Unfortunately, it was not a Volksheim presidency, but a council presidency and also a large investor presidency of all Wallstreams.
I know you, Madam Member of the European Parliament, from exactly the time when you were still here.
Now they were something else.
I very much hope that when you come back, you will join us where you were once, inspired by parliamentarism.
Why did you pass it too late?
So why are we now dealing with a quasi-directorate at EU level, and that is among the objectives of Sweden with its transparency?
Please use your future to return to where you once were.
Mr President, the current debate is a central debate on the nature of the European Union.
The question is market or social policy?
The Commission's previous considerations on the future of cohesion policy are unacceptable.
The Structural Funds must be strengthened, not reduced.
Europe must not do less, but do more to overcome the differences in economic and social development.
I say this quite openly: the renationalization of parts of the current cohesion policy would have serious consequences for disadvantaged regions, including Germany, for example in East Germany.
After the last round of enlargement of the European Union, the differences between the regions of the Union have also actually increased.
It is also important to me that particularly socioeconomic conditions are recognised in the regions just above the 75 per cent threshold per capita.
A sudden cessation of support after 2013 would be devastating for these regions.
Of course, the strengthening of specific urban support, city-based support by the European Union is also extremely important.
This is important because there are great powers for the economy and for finance, and because the crisis has also hit there in particular.
One last word on the border regions.
As East German Members of Parliament, I tell you that we have to invest very, very much, do a lot.
And that is why I am very concerned that the Commission is failing.
