Mr President, regional structural support is an essential instrument in European integration, and in the past, people have seen target 2 support as the engine of structural and economic development on the ground in many regions.
It is an important element in tackling structural change in the regions and also in the municipalities.
Here, too, Europe is really experienced by the citizens on the ground, because it also works on the ground.
But we need simpler, clearer and more transparent structures for the cohesion funds and better controls so that the funds are used in a sustainable and efficient way.
Cohesion, convergence in social and economic development is a key objective of the EU, and that is why we must not weaken this instrument in the future, but strengthen it.
Cohesion policy in Europe needs more clarity, more transparency, efficiency and also the self-responsibility of the individual Member States.
And that is why it is important to stick to the system of additive support.
But we do not want to renationalize structural support.
That is why I would like to ask the Commission to meet these requirements for the funding criteria from 2013 onwards.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have two motions for a resolution to put to the House.
First of all, I have a request to the whole house.
It refers to an urgency which we are discussing this afternoon.
This is the case of Mrs. Amitu Haidar.
We have an urgent matter on the agenda this afternoon.
I ask my colleagues for confidence in the following procedure, as some of the colleagues who have dealt intensively with this case know.
I have no more details to say now, but I am one of those who know that we will soon have a solution to this case in the course of the day.
Prominent EU government representatives are working on a positive solution.
It would therefore make sense to remove this urgency from the agenda this afternoon, because any further debate would only hinder the work that some diplomatic channels are doing there.
That is why I would ask the House to agree that we take this urgency off the agenda, because we are helping to resolve the case more than we are discussing it.
That would be my first request, Mr. President.
I will then put forward the second request immediately afterwards.

Madam President, it seems to me to be a bit symptomatic for us, for the EU in general, but also for Parliament in particular, that we are having reflex discussions about situations in countries whose situation is not new.
Unfortunately, it is very often that overnight events lead us here to suddenly pour ourselves into political demands, which I sometimes find somewhat questionable.
I believe that it is not in our interest to cause a failed plane bombing alone to provoke a general debate on Yemen.
I think we should be aware that it is in our best interest to consider a strategy for dealing with this situation.

I also believe that the situation in Yemen needs to be analysed in detail, namely that it is a failed state in which a government is acting that no longer controls large parts of the country, and we should analyse for ourselves the risks to Europe that this poses.
The risks seem to be that terrorists are being trained there, and the risks seem to be on the coast of Yemen, where piracy is obviously taking place.
That is why it is up to us and perhaps also up to Mrs Ashton to consider what we can do about these risks.
For my purposes, the answer can be, above all, how can we strengthen the back of the government in Yemen to regain control of the country and contain these risks?

All other discussions on the long-term development of the country must of course also be conducted, but I do not think that it really makes sense and that we will be taken seriously if we now start a catalogue of demands across all policy areas, from media freedom to women's rights here in Parliament.
I do not think that this will lead to the goal in Yemen, but we should concentrate on what kind of help we can provide in the immediate situation to solve an acute problem.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the massacre on 23 November last year in the province of Maguindanao in the Philippines was a black day for human rights and a barbaric act of terrorism.
57 dead, raped, women, injured, they speak a bloody language.
As a journalist, I am particularly struck by the fact that 30 journalists were among the dead.
According to the renowned International Crisis Group, no more journalists have ever been murdered in a single attack in any documented case.
That is why it is appropriate for the European Parliament to find clear words, as we do today in the draft resolution.

However, we as the EPP call for the text to be deleted in three places by means of separate elections, because we should support the Philippine government in its fight against terrorism and violence and therefore refrain from making accusatory remarks to the government.
That is why, on behalf of the EPP, I ask that we vote on Recital F in particular, which calls on the Philippines to show all the signs of a non-functioning legal system.
In paragraph 2, we would like to remove the assumption of so-called initial delays in the investigation.
Finally, paragraph 6 states that there are missing persons in Philippine prisons.
This too is currently an unproven assumption and should be removed in our view.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I think it is good that the Social Democratic Group is dealing intensively with this report.

But I would like to point out that in December 2008 we, as a Parliament, adopted an almost unanimous resolution calling on the European Commission to put forward exactly the kind of proposal that we are discussing here.
And Parliament must somewhere let itself be held to what it has decided and what has been the declared will of this House for years.
We have, of course, always resolved the open questions by a compromise in the Legal Affairs Committee, because there are always concerns about any legislative proposal here or there.
This compromise is, I may say, decisive.
Nevertheless, I understand that it may make sense to extend the circle of supporters of this report.
And if Mr Schulz's efforts are aimed at widening the circle of supporters, I have no objection to postponing the next plenary session in March.
That's my personal position.
I do not believe the attitude of the groups who have decided on this this morning in a very different way.
But I think we should give the Socialists a chance to come to their senses so that they too can do something for the middle class, for the relief of the middle class and the reduction of bureaucracy.
I understand that.

You are most welcome here in this house.
The loss of trust in Copenhagen was, in my view, one of the major problems.

My question to you is, how are the instruments we adopted last year going?
I am already worried about ETS because I am not entirely sure how the Commission is dealing with benchmarking, for example, but also with carbon leakage, because of the decision in Copenhagen.
And the second question is there is a proposal from the French government to importers from the
In the third world, wherever we go, to integrate into the ITS system to make the market bigger and then let these countries participate in that system.

Madam President, the point here is that we as the European Union have to have a clear strategy and prevent a gold or oil rush.
Europe must intervene actively here.
Here Europe can prove its strength as a partner by speaking with one voice.
It's about shipping over and underwater, it's about fishing, it's about resources in the form of primary energy carriers and raw materials.
Here we need, together with the other partners in the Arctic, viable and reliable agreements.
We need cooperation instead of confrontation.
We need dialogue on environmental protection to preserve natural resources and nature.
We need dialogue in the field of animal welfare to preserve biodiversity, we need protection and respect for the inhabitants and their human rights.
If we carry out positive resource management together with our partners in the Arctic, we will have the opportunity to take new paths here politically.
It will also be a first test for our common foreign policy, where we can prove that we as Europeans are pursuing common goals.
Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the G20 summit in Pittsburgh has provided a good example.
It has called for recovery plans to promote decent work that contributes to the security and creation of jobs and has given priority to employment growth.

Europe's labour ministers are therefore called upon to urge the G20 members not to reverse the economic recovery packages, but to use them more widely and more strongly to create jobs, and secondly, to ensure that short-term work is financially secured.
Thirdly, to use public investment to create jobs and sustainable ecological growth, and fourthly, to strengthen and expand social security measures to enable access.
This also ensures purchasing power in the internal market and employment and fights poverty.

Cooperation with the social partners is particularly important to the Ministers of Labour of Europe in order to strengthen the social dialogue even more vigorously, as the Commissioner would like to do.
Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank Mr Leichtfried for an excellent report which continues to convey sound and good content.
What is the ultimate goal?
It is about strengthening transparency, consumer protection, security and coordination, as well as quality management.
However, I warn you here that we are setting up a new authority to deal with these issues.
I see the subsidiarity in the report as a positive one, and it should certainly be maintained.
For me, a clear separation between taxes and fees and all tasks that are sovereignty is also very important.
All these measures, whether police, terrorist defence or the like, are clearly to be financed from taxpayers' money and not from user fees.
If individual national states have a vital interest in taking further security measures, then I also see them as costly in this area.
Whoever entrusts security to the sovereignty area pays for it.
Otherwise, I see it with certainty in the technical or personal area, which can certainly be to the detriment of the passenger if it is clearly declared what it is about.
However, it is also noteworthy that in the area of impact assessment, which the Commission has presented to us, an amount of about 0.1% of the total transport fee is charged for these measures.
So we shouldn't start too high.
I believe that we are also making a viable compromise with the Federal Republic of Germany, which has extraordinary concerns in the area of subsidiarity.
I hope that the final result is very close to our proposal.
Madam President, Commissioner, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, the evaluation of passenger data is, like Swift's, an attempt to combat global terrorism and terrorism.
to bring more serious crime into line with the fundamental rights of each individual to the protection of privacy and also to information self-determination.
But we must also be aware that in Europe and around the world, in the age of mobility, there will be no sufficient security without an effective and rapid exchange of data.
In the digital age, we also need to ensure special protection of information self-determination and privacy.
I therefore also think it is necessary to distinguish more precisely between data necessary for the fight against crime and data sensitive to the private sphere.
And for me, it is not really a question of having to integrate checks, legal remedies, information rights, claims for damages and the length of storage time into the agreement.
The push method must be tested to see whether there can or must be exceptions in urgent cases.
And with regard to the use of passenger data, we should also include serious crime.
And that includes, for me, crimes such as child pornography, human trafficking, murder, rape and even drug trafficking.
And I think that would also be a contribution to the protection of the personal rights of the persons concerned.
I think it is good that we are postponing the decision on the air passenger data agreements in question in order to have a basic model for all future agreements of this kind.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter, and if so, what is the Commission's position?
Perhaps in the future there will be room to think about jointly fighting terrorism and crime with our transatlantic partners in a common facility.
And that would certainly be a step towards tackling globalized crime globally as well.
Mr President, we have rightly pointed out the importance of the EIB in the speeches.
Mrs Cadenbach, for example, spoke of the necessary contribution to social convergence.
I would like to put this in a political context.
We are deeply concerned that more and more states, parties of the extreme right, are gaining ground.
And they do so because social convergence in the European Union is not working as we all wanted it to.
In doing so, they very, very often act as wolves in sheep's clothing, hiding a massive, cynical contempt for humanity behind them.
Last example, Mr President, I know your political attitude too, what Mr MÃ¶lzer has just done. He gives a very nice speech, but in the meantime he calls a political opponent a psychopath.
That's the language of Hitlerfascism, that's the way it works, and political opponents have already been labeled inhuman.

I ask you to take appropriate action against this, and I ask my colleagues from the EIB to continue their work, including in the area of transparency, to become even more transparent, because their approach is also an aid to the emerging new fascism.
Political coherence in the interest of development means that we do not take with one hand what we give with the other.
For example, it makes little sense to put subsidies into the development of agriculture in developing countries if we simultaneously destroy local markets through direct or indirect export subsidies.
We can also do even more to improve health care by stopping the trade in generics or by extending the patent to push drug prices to unbearable heights.

And agrofuels may reduce CO2 emissions in the EU a little bit, but in developing countries they lead to deforestation and land reclamation, and thus to more climate change, which we just wanted to avoid, not to mention the expulsion of indigenous populations, the loss of biodiversity and food crops.
At the moment, we, the EU as such, are not particularly coherent.
The EU has long recognized in theory that policy measures should not contradict each other.
The Treaty of Lisbon enshrines policy coherence in the interests of development.
Article 208 states that the Union shall take account of the objectives of development cooperation in the implementation of policy measures which may affect developing countries.
We must be measured by this demand.
This year we are reviewing progress in achieving the Millennium Development Goals.
It is clear that without political coherence we will not be able to fulfil our promises.

We must be aware of this responsibility, all of us who make and implement laws, and before we make a decision, there must be an impact assessment so that we can even see what negative impact European legislation can have on developing countries.
We need expertise in the Council, the Commission and Parliament, which recognizes inconsistencies.
The Commission's work programme on policy coherence is a good step in this direction.
And now it's up to how this plan is implemented.

Coherence in policy in the interests of development means that in the fisheries reform we must take more account of the interests of the people on the ground and not subordinate them to the interests of European fishing companies.
It means that we have to drain tax havens into which money flows from developing countries.
It means that we cannot agree to ACTA if there is a suspicion that this agreement could disrupt access to medicines or technologies in developing countries.
So far, the Commission has not been able to clear this suspicion.

Political coherence also means that, when creating the Foreign Service, development policy must remain a strong, independent policy field and the competences of the Commissioner for Development must be extended and not restricted.
And it is also part of the fact that we are, for example, enabling fair trade in the award of contracts in the municipalities, as my colleague Heide RÃ¼hle has proposed.
In many cases we Members of Parliament must look closely at the Commission and the Council to ensure that they formulate policies in a coherent way.
In many cases, however, it is also up to us Members of Parliament to be coherent in the interest of development.
We need to network better between the committees, and we need one or one permanent rapporteur.
The report, which was adopted unanimously by the Committee on Development, makes many good proposals and takes us a big step forward.
I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs, the Ombudsman and all the NGOs for their cooperation and cooperation, and I hope that our joint report can also be adopted by the plenary tomorrow.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have taken it from the list of votes that you, Mr President, intend to declare Amendment No 2 inadmissible.
I ask you to reconsider this.
It is indeed correct that Article 229 of the Treaty provides for a meeting of the European Parliament on the second Tuesday of March.
But this is not contrary to the proposal put forward by my group.
My group's proposal is to move the Strasbourg week from the tenth week to the eleventh week.
That does not prevent you from holding a plenary session on the second Tuesday in March.
But we want Strasbourg to be in the eleventh week, so I say there is no inadmissibility here.
I would ask you to reconsider this.

Mr President of the Commission, in response to the questions put by my colleague, Mr Manfred Weber, Commissioner MalmstrÃ¶m has informed the College that there are serious concerns about the current state of negotiations in this House.
Is the Commission aware that what it has decided today is certainly not what Parliament considers to be sufficient progress?

Are you aware, Mr President, that you have assumed today that if it is implemented in this way, it will lead to employees of a private company, the SWIFT company, for example, having more control rights than officials of the European Union?
Has Mrs MaimstrÃ¶m been informed about these things?
If so, how could you decide?
If not, why didn't Mrs. MalmstrÃ¶m tell you about it?
Thank you for the kind descriptions of your debate.
That wasn't the answer to my question.
That is why I am trying to be more precise, and I ask you to answer very precisely.

Did Mrs MalmstrÃ¶m tell you in the debate in the Commission before the decision of the College that there is a danger that Parliament will vote no to the text which you are now presenting as an agreement?
Or did Mrs MalmstrÃ¶m tell you that with this text we will get a parliamentary majority?
I repeat very precisely. Did Mrs MalmstrÃ¶m say that with this text we will get a parliamentary majority, or did she say that with this text the parliamentary majority is not safe?
I'd be grateful if you'd give me a more precise answer.
Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we have been discussing the question of these working hours and working hours in road transport for months.
And I wonder what arguments are being used to prove that what we've been discussing for months is all nonsense.
The latest argument is that something urgently needs to be changed here so that nothing changes.
Do you not realize, Mrs Bauer, how absurd this argument is now, how permeated it is by lies and half-truths?
This dispute is about nothing more than extending the working hours of the self-employed.
In principle, however, for 150 years the question of protecting people from overtime has been a matter of labour law.
This applies both to the selfemployed and to the employed.
It doesn't matter if it's an independent who's overcharging or an employer who's overcharging an employee driver.
It is about protecting people from themselves and from overtime, in part also from employers and contractors.
Secondly, in the area of road safety, it is said that nothing can happen here.
Ladies and gentlemen, we are not in the hobby building market, and we are not lay craftsmen, we cannot make laws according to the motto Let's see what comes out of it.
But everyone knows that overtime is designed to be hazardous, especially in road traffic, with major consequences.
Thirdly, who is going to control such a differentiated regulation that you imagine on our roads in the future?
Today, a national labour judge cannot check whether someone seems to be self-employed or self-employed without extensive file study.
Let's not talk about this nonsense. It's about fair competition.
It is not a question of setting a deadline for the future debate on the extension of working hours today or tomorrow.
Don't play games with this house. Thank you.
Madam President, today, as I have done for many years, I am committed to road safety, to improving the working conditions of our professional drivers and to improving their professional image.

First of all, it is clear that today it is not about the traffic safety regulations for driving and rest periods that all self-employed and employed professional drivers must comply with, but about the regulation of working hours.
It is primarily a worker protection scheme, so it serves only the social protection of drivers and not traffic safety at all.
We don't have to protect the self-employed from themselves.

Compliance with working hours is neither controllable for self-employed truck and bus drivers without considerable bureaucratic effort, nor is there any understandable reason why it should be controlled at all.
To restrict self-employed firefighters, as in the future perhaps also self-employed craftsmen, architects or Members of Parliament, in their permitted working hours is the wrong signal.
Rather, the Member States should ensure that the self-sufficiency of the Member States
We have to fight drivers.
Madam President, congratulations to the rapporteur, but also to our shadow rapporteur, I think a good report has been produced here.
The main statement for me is that both sides, which are currently making life difficult in Bosnia and Herzegovina, finally have insight and are backing away from their extreme positions.

One extreme position is to question Bosnia and the integrity of the country again and again and to threaten referendums that do nothing but can create mood and hatred, and the other extreme position is to question the basic structure of the Dayton.
It has to be adopted now.
and
It has already been adopted, but it still needs to be done.
And if on the one hand it is repeatedly said that the office of the High Commissioner should be dissolved, I agree.
But the side that demands this must create the conditions for it to happen so that the politicians in the country themselves take responsibility.
That must be our goal, but politicians must also take responsibility.
And hopefully the voters in the next elections will also vote for those politicians who are willing to take responsibility for their own country.
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, just a few days ago we saw with shock in the television pictures how vast areas of Poland and other Central European countries were flooded.
People have died in the floods, and our full sympathy goes to the families.
The images on television have already been replaced by other images, but the enormous damage has yet to be eliminated.
In order to eliminate the damage of this magnitude, these countries should also experience the solidarity of the countries of the European Union.
After the flood disaster of 1997, Poland and this time other Central European countries are again affected by a flood disaster.
We can't regulate the weather yet, and floods are a kind of river at certain times.
But the questions we have to ask are whether, in the awareness that these natural events can always happen, the right measures to prevent
the damage caused by such natural events and whether, for example, the issues of sustainable disaster protection were duly taken into account in landscape planning.
If aid is granted, it should first be used to help those directly affected by the natural disaster to survive.

But then, in international cooperation, natural disasters should also not stop at national borders, but should be done more for the prevention of damage caused by natural disasters by the Member States coordinated at European level.
The fact that joint precautions can provide protection shows the flood protection on the ODA, which has so far been jointly set up there by Polish and German authorities.
But we're not done yet.
We do not need European disaster protection.
The protection of a country from disasters should be the primary task of a country's government, including the drawing up of disaster plans.

But coordination of aid in the event of damage and incident should also be accompanied by efficient European coordination, and those organisations which provide aid on a voluntary basis, quickly and overly bureaucratically, should not be left to their own devices.
That is why I support Commissioner Georgieva's plans to have them implemented quickly.
Mr President, unfortunately my agonising illness has so far prevented me from speaking as clearly to the international public as I have done on other European issues.
But in a minute, Mr President of the Commission!
You are here in a historical time.
They will be measured in the area of financial markets in the most urgent concern whether they succeed in introducing regulations that actually close loopholes.
At present, everything that comes from the Commission and that we have in Parliament so far does not exclude this.

There are no necessary improvements, and you will go down in history as someone who, when the house burned down, did not provide the necessary fire extinguishing material and did not provide any new construction materials.
Point two, equity: if you fail to stop this disastrous, devastating shadow banking system and not just curb it, you will escape.
The real economy and also billions of citizens around the world not only have their own basis for action in the economic sphere, but also trust in everything that is called democracy.
Because then all of a sudden China and the totalitarians who are already looking to have their banks controlled are better off than the European Union.
And point three, of course, we need a system that minimizes systemic risks, that is, that is, that is implemented with progressive tax regulation, that if a bank gets too big, it has to close it.

In 2007 and 2008, Libya voted against the resolutions of the United Nations General Assembly calling for a moratorium on executions, and there was no official indication of the repeated request from human rights organizations.
That is why it is very important to us that it is finally officially explained which persons were executed.
Every execution is one too many.
We reject executions and the death penalty.
It's inhuman, inhuman, and each one is too much.
That is why we are very clear in our resolution that we are changing this, that we are making it clear, and that we are now working together to make a change here.

No more dark numbers, but open information about what is happening here and a humane punishment for real criminals, but not an exaggerated punishment for those who are critical of the regime in Tripoli.
Mr President, I wanted to support Mr Cohn Bendit's motion on behalf of our group.
Now it's exactly like this.
This is a highly sensitive, very delicate subject, on which it is certainly useful to find a broad parliamentary majority.
It would therefore be good if the report could be postponed and an attempt could be made to reach further possible consensus.
That's why we support this.
I would like to thank you, ladies and gentlemen, for your support, and in the short term I would like to limit myself to the Kanchan report.
It is undeniable that passenger rights, and thus consumer rights, must be implemented in the power bus transport.
However, I would like to emphasize once again the problems facing small and mediumsized enterprises at the moment, especially from the point of view of the Federal Republic of Germany.
Public transport and regional transport cannot be separated, especially in rural areas, as they often operate together over a radius of about 50 kilometres.
Secondly, it is not possible to advance payments of benefits to small and mediumsized enterprises that are not dependent on debt.
Here we have the principle of liability, which has so far proved very well and has thus also kept the price of the vehicle stable.
Thirdly, I cannot imagine that non-debt arrears have to be paid by the entrepreneur, just as liability can only apply to the circumstances for which the entrepreneur is responsible.
Mr President, first of all I would like to thank Mr Matthieu Grosch very much for this profound report and for the enormous work he has done on it.

Europe without separate borders is not achievable without a functioning transport system, and the European economy would not be successful, not even conceivable, without a viable transport system, without viable future-proof land, water and air transport systems.
In particular, with environmentally friendly rail transport, we need even more community and less national-state selfishness.
In order to ensure a sustainable future for transport, all transport providers must face the challenges of protecting the environment and the economy in society.
The report provides valuable and guiding indications.
However, there is only one point on which I cannot agree with the report: I cannot agree to the creation of a transport fund from the resources of cohesion policy.
Why?
Traffic is certainly a special carrier of cohesion in Europe, but a fund of its own, from the resources of cohesion policy, would not meet the expectations it raises.
We must unilaterally burden the Cohesion Fund and relieve the Member States, which are particularly called upon to ensure a sustainable future for transport, of too much burden.

And we have just set up a special committee in Parliament to debate what the cohesion and structural funds of the European Union will look like in the future, the work of which should not be prioritized.
That is why I ask you to vote in favour of the amendment to the report.
And beyond that, I think that when we talk about the sustainability and the future of transport systems, we should also give the magnetic levitation technology a future and a chance.
Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we do have a common internal market, but we have a fragmented supervision.
That this can't work is obvious.
We need strong central European structures which use the expertise and detailed knowledge of the Member States' bodies, but which also have the power of intervention in case of emergency.
I believe that the citizen alone expects that, against the background of the enormous tax burden imposed by this crisis, decisions will be taken swiftly, quickly and fairly.
The citizens are not interested in power games at the national level, where the question is exclusively about who decides.
What the citizen wants is for decisions to be made effectively, for problems to be solved.

And this is objectively so that when it comes to emergency measures, which must be centrally regulated and decided at European level, if the coordination between the Member States is not sufficient and does not work.
This is not in line with the decisions of the G20, the G8 heads of state and government, unfortunately not at the level of the Council.
The Council makes him small, small, small.
This is not an acceptable policy for the citizens.
We expect the Council to move.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, sometimes one wonders what we have been doing for over a year now, discussing and debating many sessions of the trilogue, where I could have imagined something more beautiful than spending them there.

And at the moment, more than a year after the European elections, when we have announced on the streets and squares how we want to curb the financial markets, we are actually faced with a very meagre to non-existent result.
And the problem has already been described.
We are dealing with markets that are now acting globally.
The Member States still believe that they are able to enforce the rules of the game with their national supervisory structures.
And just because it didn't work, it also contributed, not to the financial crisis, but to the fact that it also affected Europe.

And that is why I am wondering when this recognition, which is often expressed in Sunday's speeches, will also be translated into political action, where it is suddenly about protecting stock exchanges, where it is about protecting banking structures and no longer about protecting citizens.

We as the European Parliament have devoted ourselves to this task, and I hope that the Member States will also devote themselves to this task, because they are partly responsible for implementing proper supervision rules for citizens, which ensure that the savings of the individual are also permanently safe.
I would, of course, like the Commission to do everything in its power to ensure that we achieve a good result as soon as possible in the interests of the people of Europe.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we in this European Parliament have a responsibility to regulate financial markets strongly.
All that we have proposed has been greatly watered down in the trialogue.
The Council and the Government do not want strong intervention rights.
Giegold is right when he calls what is happening there at the moment "church tower thinking".
It does not seem to be the intention to regulate strictly, but only to design the system a little more freely.
We will have a fragmented supervisory structure which will not be able to carry out real control of the financial markets.
From this financial crisis, from this economic crisis, insufficient consequences are drawn and the next crisis is thus already being prepared.
Many national economies, including in Europe, will not survive the next blows with all the social and economic consequences for the people of Europe.
But you expect this predatory financial market capitalism to be recaptured and the primacy of politics to be restored.
When the chairman of the board of UniCredit Bank, Alessandro Profumo, said this weekend: 'We need strong and uniform European financial supervision and a common rule for all Member States.
If he is advocating stricter capital rules in the Member States, then this is an appeal to this Parliament to really constitute these rules.
It is up to this European Parliament to put pressure on the Council to urgently take effective regulation, which would only be the first step towards a status quo.
Let us finally follow through on the promises we have made, and my group is in favour of strong European regulation.
Anything else, no regulation would be a danger to the euro, to a common EU and to democracy.
Mr President, bad timing for this debate.
I would have liked to see the Dutch team win again and it would also be the last time of this World Cup.
Probably a bad omen, because we can't watch anymore and then they probably won't win.

But on the subject, Commissioner, you are giving the right signals. Commissioner, Mr President, we are concluding today, or more precisely tomorrow, a package of legislation which we have been discussing for more than two years.
This is not only the fault of the controversy, but also of an interim European election and the entry into force of a new EU treaty, which has led to some adjustments.

But I think that if we draw a conclusion from this debate today, I conclude that we are now voting on a compromise which is certainly worth saying yes to, even if you do it in one place or another with a clenched fist in your pocket.
I would like to highlight two aspects.
One is the environmental requirements for industrial plants.
It is about making the best available technology in Europe more widely available.
I believe that we have found an exceptional paragraph in the compromise now before us, which gives the EU Commission, Mr PotoÄnik, and I make that very clear to your address, the tool at hand.
In the next few years, we will have to make sure that the approximately 52 industrial plants in Europe are ultimately using the best available technology better than they are doing today.
I've heard a lot of arguments in this debate.
I would like to pick up on one of them and reflect on it here, because I cannot understand it at all.
I have often been told that the use of the best available technology is too expensive and that we are endangering the competitiveness of European industry in the midst of a crisis.
I don't like to remember my past, but I'm from the former GDR, from East Germany.
The economic and ecological collapse of the GDR was also due to the fact that over the decades investment in the latest technology has been dormant.

I believe that every industry, every industrial enterprise, is called upon to invest in the latest technology because of its existence, because otherwise it loses competitiveness and, of course, also reduces emissions.
I think we have a chance today to enact a law that will improve this initial situation.
The second part of the directive, and this is a bit of the ball and chain I mentioned, is the large-scale combustion plants.

We are talking once again, we have already done this in the last directive, about new exceptions until 2020, partly for large-scale heating plants that do not have to meet the environmental requirements, in particular the air pollution limits.
I am addressing the Council here, and perhaps a little bit all of us, that we have to think very carefully about how meaningful it is that we regularly

I would like to welcome the ambitious environmental objectives which are also being discussed and welcomed here, but whenever it comes to implementing them, to put them into concrete legislation, a mourning game begins in Europe.
Then the Member States will suddenly know what it costs, what bills to pay, and then, as a rule, those who have gone into arrears will also be punished.
There are a number of Member States which are already meeting the requirements today and which will be left in the rain at the end.
I say it again, both in the industrial plants and in the large-scale combustion plants, which are essentially coal-fired power plants, we are not talking about science fiction.
We're not talking about things that aren't available, but it's the latest in technology.
The best available techniques, what is available on the market in terms of competitiveness and cost, can be incorporated into these plants, and against this background we conclude that
I am voting today on a package of legislation which I believe is better than the one in force, and that is why I encourage all of us to agree with it.

I would also like to thank the colleagues who have worked with very hard bandages for the last two years for their support, for their work and, above all, for the fact that almost all the important groups have signed this compromise.
Mr President, three interesting things have happened during our debate. Firstly, it is clear that Europe will become the world football champion.
A good omen, I think.
We're going to have to work with a base.
I don't want to give any preferences.
Secondly, Germany gets compliments from the UK.
Chris Davis, thank you. It doesn't happen every day.
It's worth keeping that in mind.
And thirdly, the world is still fine, even with the Greens, football is more important than environmental protection.
Unfortunately, our colleague Bas Eikud is gone again.
But a hearty congratulations, of course, to our Dutch friends.
I wanted to say two things about the debate that I was allowed to follow.
First of all, I understand all the worries and needs of my Eastern European friends only too well.
As an East German, I am also half Eastern European.
I understand that not every environmental policy step that has been taken in the Western European countries in recent decades can now be immediately followed up in Eastern Europe.
Environmental protection at a high level must be affordable.
Yes, that's right.
But I believe that, even if this sentence is taken into account, it is worth agreeing to this compromise, because it will be in line with this different starting point, where many Member States are.
And secondly, the argument that the use of the best available techniques is endangering competitiveness, especially against China, is not only wrong, it is even dangerous.
We have to deal with the fact that industrial processes in Asia are definitely cheaper than in our country.
And we will only survive this competition if we use the best available technology in all possible industries.
If you don't, you lose competitiveness.
No one is demanding, not even this law, that an industrial plant be shut down tomorrow.
No one is asking for the jump from zero to 100 to reach any harmful limit value within a week.
We have sufficient transitional periods, but it is wrong to say that it should be avoided for reasons of competition.
I believe that with this directive we have not only achieved an environmental policy, but also an industrial policy, for which it is worth working in the coming years.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would first of all like to begin by thanking the colleagues from the other groups for drawing up my report on Kosovo, including Mrs Eva Mar, who has done a very valuable job in the secretariat here.

And I would also like to thank you, Commissioner, for the good cooperation, but also for what you said, that it was important for you to go to the north of Kosovo, to spend a night there, and to make it clear to the people that you are also there for the people.
You gave a speech at the university, the EU House there.
I think this was an important sign to clarify what this European Parliament has been expressing in the past and now, namely its support for independent Kosovo on its way to the European Union.
We are currently in a situation where there is once again an important crossroads for Kosovo, for the citizens, especially all the ethnic groups of Kosovo.
In a few weeks' time, the International Court of Justice will decide, give its opinion on the position on the Declaration of Independence just over two years ago.
I hope that this decision, this opinion, will then be an opportunity, something like what it is called in English, to put regional cooperation on a new basis, but from the point of view of statehood.

I would like to ask the President-in-Office of the Council whether he is aware of the fact that the Council of Ministers of the European Communities has adopted a resolution on the situation in Kosovo.
It is also the text of the resolution that makes it clear that the future of Kosovo lies in the European Union.

I am pleased that we have a majority in favour, which also calls on the five Member States which have not yet recognised to do so soon, and that the Commission is also called upon to start visa liberalisation as soon as possible.

Because the citizens of the country, especially the young, must not be allowed to have this impression that they live in an isolated state, that they cannot go out, while everyone else in the surrounding area will soon have this future.
I think that's the assignment.
I hope that I will also find a large majority in the plenary tomorrow.

I have also tabled a new amendment which highlights a strong regret at the violence of the last few days and hopes for a swift and independent inquiry, and does not take this as a basis for a surge of emotions in the coming days and weeks.
Madam President, Madam High Representative, Madam Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the latest events in Kyrgyzstan, the outbreaks of violence, the slaughter of people, the
The burning of houses and the floods of tens of thousands of refugees who left their homes and tried to flee violence have shocked me and caused me to feel sorry for the victims.
At the same time, these events in Kyrgyzstan are once again shedding light on the situation in Central Asia, which must not leave us untouched here in the European Parliament.
On the contrary, we should devote all our attention to the countries of this region.

In doing so, we should not only focus on those countries which are rich in natural resources and of particular economic interest to us in Europe, but should also look at all countries equally in the context of the Central Asian Strategy adopted in 2007.
That is our obligation.
The Central Asian states, which not even 20 years ago broke free from the once tsarist and later Soviet rule, bear a heavy legacy.
The borders arbitrarily drawn by Stalin, regardless of the home regions of the peoples living there, obviously make it difficult to live together within and outside the borders of these states.
Poverty, corruption, disregard for human and minority rights, authoritarian regimes, economic conditions, which, for example, in Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan, hundreds of thousands
Forcing labour immigration and, as we now admit in Kyrgyzstan, conflict resolution by force, leave the way for these countries to be questioned in the future.
We must not allow the European Union to just watch.
If we do not want to let these countries lead the way into fundamentalist structures that do not want to hand over people to dictatorial regimes in the long term, we must make every effort.
In addition to the urgently needed material aid, we need contact with these countries, active support for the democratic forces developing there.
If we give Prime Minister Rosa Otunbayeva a chance to pacify Kyrgyzstan and to stabilize the political situation, we will leave it to the debate here and to the vote tomorrow.

The outstanding resolution should also be followed by action so that the people of Kyrgyzstan and other Central Asian countries feel that we will not leave them alone or hand them over to undemocratic forces on their way to the future.
The expectations of us Europeans in these countries are high, we should not disappoint them.
The report was voted on for four reasons.
The architecture of the service has many weaknesses, the subtleties of which will cause us great concern.
The second point is that the European Ambassador will manage Commission funds in the future.
This puts the funds at risk of a number of risks, and the safeguards for these risks are still absolutely unclear.
The third point is the question of the rights of this Parliament in a Council regulation.
We are in this procedure in the de facto co-decision, and yet we have allowed the Council Regulation to take away parliamentary rights.
That is why I would like to say in my report on the budgetary procedure that I do not see myself bound by today's decisions.
The fourth point is the question of how we actually deal with each other in Parliament.
We have recently decided on a parliamentary reform and procedures which we have all now set in motion, with the approval of the Bureau and the approval of the President.
Why do we make a parliamentary reform that prescribes procedures when we, when it comes down to it, are already violating them and not complying with them?
That is why I cannot agree with this report.
Mr President, Commissioner, I am very much in favour of green genetic engineering, but cloning is something else.
You can't compare that to that.
Cloning is animal cruelty, and many colleagues have already said it here.
I also said this before the summer break in the discussion we had that only a fraction of the animal clones are actually viable.
And those who survive, many of whom die very, very early, very painfully.
They suffer from deformities of the extremities, of the organs.
They have immune deficiencies, they're susceptible to disease.
That means pain and suffering and this agonizing death sentence.
How can we be responsible?
We're going to do this for animal welfare, and then we're going to support this technology.
No, we don't want that, and that's why we decided in July that we don't want cloned meat or animal products from cloned animals.
And that's only consistent.

Yes, we know that the products of the cloned animals or their offspring are probably not harmful to health, and I personally assume that they would actually be suitable for human consumption, but there is actually no shortage of meat from conventional production.
Why should we get involved in this cloning?
It is completely unnecessary to carry out this animal cruelty, and the population does not want it either.
But the people don't want these products, and we don't need them either.
And that is why we want a very clear regulation explicitly for cloned animals and, yes, also for their offspring.
I want a ban on cloning and cloning products in the European Union, and I also believe that we can enforce that.
Of course, this must also apply to imports.
I want to make sure that I don't get cloned meat in secret because it's not labeled, like it's already happened here.
Scotland, and I don't think you can trace all the meat back.
With beef, it may be possible.
But in the case of pork, because of the mass produced, it will not be possible to trace back whether there was actually a clone in the duck family.
But basically, I think it's a matter of principle, it's an ethical matter.
And other colleagues have said that we must also deal with ethical issues, and we are also responsible for ethical issues.
Of course, this is a matter of animal welfare, but it is also a different matter.

Experience shows that I'm an animal breeder, I've studied this, experience shows that all reproductive techniques, once they really worked in animal breeding, were ultimately applied to humans as well.
So we have to ask ourselves today, do we want and can we accept cloning technology in the not-so-distant future, do we want and can we accept it in humans?
So I don't want to do that, and I can't do that.
And even if a replacement clone could give me a vital organ in the future, a clone of myself, I don't want that.
I don't think this is an exaggerated horror vision.
I believe that this would not be possible in the foreseeable future if we allowed cloning.
That is why we urgently need a ban not only on cloning, but also on cloned animals and their offspring throughout the EU.
I'm not afraid of the WTO.
We can enforce that.
We don't have to imitate everything the United States pretends to do to us in all transatlantic friendship.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is no coincidence that we cannot agree so easily in this case, because two incompatible matters are being mixed here.
We could probably have agreed on brand protection if we had focused on it.
But the mixing with the Internet is also factually wrong, because it requires new strategies other than material law.
This cannot be simply transferred.
You also have to be aware that we pay for every criminal prosecution online with interference in civil rights, because you can't see it or figure it out on your own.
And the third thing that's really clear to me is that if I'm already putting cultural enjoyment on the web under threat, so that I'm practically always putting my foot in it.
If I'm in prison, if I look into the Internet, I won't be able to take advantage of the opportunities that the Internet offers for art and cultural creativity.
That's why I'm calling for us to talk about it.
I'm not going to lie to you.
Mr President, property, whether intellectual or physical, is a cornerstone of the market economy.
That is why I think it is important that we think about how we can resolve this issue together in a good consensus.
We need a warning anyway.
It must be easier for consumers, for the self-employed, for small and mediumsized enterprises to obtain the appropriate licences.
And it is the availability of EU-wide licences for intellectual property rights that is of particular importance.
We need a single market for intellectual property.
We also need, above all, the original language to be available throughout Europe.
Every language is an important cultural asset, and it should be possible to grant licences for a language that are valid throughout Europe and can therefore be used by all citizens.
We need interoperability and technical neutrality in order to make appropriate use of this intellectual property.
And above all, we need sanctions for those who violate competition and trade law.
Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I have taken note that the Council does not want to discuss the multiannual financial framework.

I would like to inform the Council that the European Parliament wants to discuss it already and that the Council cannot behave like a kindergarten and say that it does not answer our questions or our proposals.
Secondly, in this context, I have to ask the Council whether it wants Lisbon or not.
Lisbon is not a purely technical change, but it means more tasks, it means more task fulfilment and also answering the relevant financial questions.
In addition, the Council has taken decisions leading to new financial expenditure.
This has been done by many colleagues.

If the Council wants this and if the Council wants no more money to be spent, then the Council must also say where it wants to save, how it wants to save, where it wants to shift exactly, and not just general
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter, and if so, what is the Commission's position?

However, the tasks you have given us in addition are so challenging that they do not involve small, secondary sums, but I am only mentioning the areas of financial solidity of our countries and their corresponding financial difficulties.
But if the programme has to be used, then these are not small sums that could be reallocated by the way.

The same applies to ITER, the same applies to internal security issues, the same applies to major research issues, the same applies to questions when I address the priority areas of Parliament, namely youth education and research.
We are dealing partly with a lack of implementation, and partly with a lack of transparency in the spending of funds.
All these questions must be dealt with and dealt with in a concrete way, and not be answered by the Council in silence.
Mr President, Commissioner Hahn, ladies and gentlemen, I have a problem with parts of the debate.
When we talk about mountains, islands and sparsely populated regions, I get the impression in individual contributions that they are ex territorially and directly subordinate to the European Union.
But that's not the case.
Each of these territories belongs to a Member State which is sovereign.
And the implementation of European decisions and objectives is still a matter for the Member States in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity.

And when I look at the European level, we have always paid particular attention to these areas, the mountainous regions, the sparsely populated areas, the islands, in the Commission's communication up to the Treaty of Lisbon.
And here in Parliament too, many decisions have been taken to support this region.
If I hear many complaints that there are still abuses in these areas, then the question arises for me: how have the Member States dealt with the impulses we have sent from the European level?
And what about how the regions themselves have acted and used the European funding opportunities?
I am sorry, but the officials of DG Regio are already demanding a new strategy to include in a strategy the many problems of islands, mountains and sparsely populated areas.

At the same time, we are experiencing an inflation of strategies, the Danube, the Baltic Sea, the Black Sea, climate change and things like that, and we need a strategy for the strategies so that we can keep an eye on it.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I think that what it is really about, and this has also been said today, and I am very grateful to Commissioner Hahn for mentioning this, is that we must fight for cohesion policy and regional policy at European level after 2013.
That is the focus of our work, and in that we should also convince our colleagues in Parliament that it will be the same.
And in a continuation of cohesion and regional policy beyond 2013, mountains, islands and other areas will also find their place.
But we should not get bogged down in individual motions for resolutions on the subject, which are not currently being discussed.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank the colleagues who have worked so hard on this project, in particular my colleague Mr Vilal Quadras.
Secondly, this is proof that European policy is able to respond to crises and offer solutions that help them to move forward.
We have had this security of supply situation on several occasions.
The problem of security of supply has become clearer and clearer.
We have been forced to act, and we have.

We have found solutions which were not easy, which also mean new instruments, and which I find interesting in creating not only infrastructure standards in Europe, not only common rules for prevention and emergency plans, not only the certainty, as the Commissioner has just said,
It has shown that in the future we can offer people 30 days of security, but it has also shown that we are able to make compromises, compromises that then lead to actionable solutions.

It's been a long journey, but it's now clear that both the role and the responsibility of companies is at the heart of building the networks that are responsible for the networks, but also the mobility of the policy that says we don't force things that don't count and don't make sense in the end.

For example, to strengthen the flexibility, not to say over everything and always and at any cost, but also the need or the possibility of being able to assess individual cases, as well as cooperation in the regional area.

It is equally important to point out that Member States must also assume their responsibilities, but if the solutions are not to be found, the Commission will have an additional task, the Commission, which is strengthened but which does not decide alone, but which then decides when other solutions are no longer possible or has the last word.
So flexibility, solutions that keep the burdens within reasonable limits, but at least make sure that there are solutions, and that is the good news from Brussels for the people of Europe.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I do not need to stress how important cohesion and regional policy is for living and growing together in Europe.
But I also believe that the regional policy and cohesion policy of the future must be more focused on cities.
Because cities are an important engine of Europe's development.
At the same time, however, they are currently experiencing ecological, economic and social problems in particular.
So my very specific question to Commissioner Hahn is what possibilities do you see to highlight the urban dimensions?

In particular, Commissioner, you had recently indicated at an event here in the House that you could imagine a certain percentage of the regional funds reserved specifically to highlight the urban dimension.
Are these considerations still relevant?
If so, how high could this percentage possibly be?

Mr President, first of all I would like to thank Commissioner Hahn for starting a new debate here as former Minister for Economic Affairs and Innovation, which I believe can make a great contribution to growth in Europe.
If every small and mediumsized enterprise in Europe created an additional job, we would have no more unemployed people in Europe.
So we should think about how we can enable small and mediumsized enterprises in particular to recruit new workers and thus become active on the international export markets.
But research infrastructure is also an important concern, as is transport infrastructure.
Here the Commission has, I believe, major tasks to perform, particularly to restructure the east-west link, for example Paris Budapest or North South.
This is where additional jobs can be created, which we urgently need in Europe at the moment.

Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there is no doubt that in recent years we have made progress in equality between men and women, yet there are still many women who are being pushed into low-skilled jobs.
This applies not only to activities traditionally carried out within the family.
In the deregulation of recent years, social security employment has often been transformed into atypical, precarious and uncertain working conditions.
Especially women.
European employment development from 2000 to 2010 includes 60 new precarious and atypical employment conditions, mainly two thirds of them women.
Women are often denied democratic participation through their part-time and precarious employment in businesses.
Today, however, women are much more engaged and better trained than in all previous generations.
They still earn 25 percent less than men on average.
We in the Employment Committee have dealt with this issue very intensively and have developed good proposals on the issue of women's employment, regardless of the status of their work.

Social security systems, the creation of childcare facilities, the orientation of pensions and social systems towards an independent way of life and the design of work according to the principles of good work.
All of this has been essentially taken up in the report on precarious employment of women.
The Employment Committee is satisfied with the outcome of this work and asks for approval of the report submitted.
Madam President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, landmines are probably going to be a major problem in the distant future.
Do you think it's possible to initiate your own research programs to detect landmines?
This is not just a European problem, it is a global problem.
Can you imagine finding suitable institutions here that are involved in research programmes in this area?

Ladies and gentlemen, in the transatlantic dialogue there is much that unites us, which are the fundamental values, the fundamental rights of freedom and democracy, but there is also something that separates us, namely the application and concretization of these rights when it comes to transatlantic relations.
Especially when it comes to security issues, this contradiction is always very clear.
Data protection is a source of constant misunderstandings, we've known that for a long time.
That is why the framework agreement, if we manage to get a very good one, will be a very big step forward.
We must find a solution here so that citizens on both sides of the Atlantic can also enforce their rights on the other partner.
A second important point, where we have similar foundations but very different approaches, is climate protection.
That is why I very much hope that it will be discussed and that it will be clearly discussed.
The European Union must not use the transatlantic dialogue to undermine its own promises and commitments.
With the investment fund manager, for the first time, there is a degree of transparency and rules in this opaque thickness of hedge funds and alternative investment funds.
Unfortunately, these rules have remained incomplete.
It is still possible to enter the common market with unregulated products in the context of passive distribution.
Basically, market access for these products is not effectively restricted.
Europe has thus given a chance to extend its rules internationally and to achieve uniform regulation.
Secondly, unfortunately, unlike Parliament, there was no effective debt brake at European level for the funds.
It is still up to national rules to limit the level of indebtedness of the funds, which means that the consequences of the crisis at this point will not be drawn.
There will be a national downward race in regulation.
What is crucial for us once again is that the plundering of companies by private equity funds is not effectively prevented.
Of course, there are private equity investments that make sense for companies.
But the rules that have now been adopted are unfortunately far from sufficient.
The information rights of workers, who rightly expect this, as well as the protection of small and mediumsized enterprises from this form of plunder, are also ineffective.
That is why it is very difficult to justify this to the voters in this case.
Unfortunately, the responsibility for this does not lie with Parliament, but in particular with an intensive lobbying of the relevant industry, which has been successful, especially in the UK.
We have had a representation of these lobbies in Parliament, rather in the form of the Liberal Group.
We cannot agree to this proposal because it would be a precedent for Parliament to fail to enforce effective rules.
It is not possible for us to stand with our heads held high before our voters and say that we have succeeded in effectively regulating this shadow kingdom.
We hope that we will then be able to move forward with the revision of the directive.
Thank you again, and above all for your cooperation with my colleagues in Parliament.
First of all, I would like to thank Mr Balz for his cooperation.
I can only emphasize that, even in different positions, it has been a good cooperation.
Many people believed, and I want to make this clear again, many people believed that the crisis in the euro area was over.
Ireland shows that this has not been the case.
Europe is still voluntarily surrendering to the financial markets.
The EU Member States must continue to sell their sovereign bonds on the financial markets and gain the confidence of speculators by saving themselves.
We had to observe again where this leads over the weekend.

This time it was not the allegedly all-deceiving Greeks, but the model student Ireland, who was driven into the European bailout fund to save his banking system, which was also considered exemplary for a long time, exemplary deregulated.
Meanwhile, the financial sector is already leaning towards the capitulation of Portugal, whose interest rates are rising steadily.
The ECB has a co-responsibility for this drama.
It has failed and continues to fail to offer a civilized alternative to the state casino through the imposition of Eurobonds.
While one half of Europe is recovering from the crisis, the ECB is watching calmly as the other half continues to fall into poverty and uncertainty.
The collapse of entire economies may be to the taste of the European fund and banking crises, but it has not helped Ireland, the Monetary Union or the ECB.
Mr Trichet, do not listen to Mrs Merkel's simple financial ABC.
I say if you want to save economic and monetary union, don't let European government bonds hang in the air.
So introduce Eurobonds before the next victim of speculation falls.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, if you consider how we have discussed this proposal from the Commission in the last parliamentary term, from the total rejection to the cheering that everything good is coming to us, then I must say that I am delighted with what is now before us.
And I would like to thank the rapporteur and his co-rapporteurs very much for making a proper opinion out of this wide range of opinions.
I think the sour word for this is patient orientation.
So you didn't take the many side effects and say, "What does the patient need?"
I think it's right that we've established that the patient can inform themselves in a variety of ways, and not just one.
But I would like to emphasize that the doctor will continue to be the confidant of the patient and will certainly also have an influence on crucial issues.
We guarantee this because we have banned advertising for it and the information that the patient receives has been examined and approved by an authority.
This is the first time that the information has been scientifically underestimated, and the patient can certainly deal with it.
Of course it's right, not everyone can figure it out.
We have different ways of doing this, and I think it's so widespread that we don't have to worry about it.
I just hope that the Council now finally has the courage to address this issue.
It is very important, it must be done quickly.
The patients expect it.
And I think we've done a good job of that.
Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, coal is part of the energy supply, and this is undeniable.
It is also undeniable that competitiveness must be ensured and that subsidisation cannot be the right way forward.
It is now a question of whether the 2014 or 2018 deadline is the right one.
Mr Rapka has made a number of wise arguments which I do not have to repeat.

My request to the Commission is simply that there is obviously a large majority in Parliament, in all the committees which were involved, in favour of the question of whether competitiveness must be a criterion.

But that in the matter of the deadline simply the necessary flexibility is created, which is safe, in order to create the possibility for the Member States to achieve it and to keep the burdens for people, for jobs, for economic structures manageable.
The only argument that has been made, which is also in contrast to the Commission's impact, which also seems to be the first to speak for 2018, was that climate policy reasons can play a role here.
I want to emphasize this point again: it does not change whether you burn foreign coal or your own coal for the sake of the climate.
My request to the Commissioner is to consider whether this four-year period in Parliament and in the Council can lead to such a new argument that the Commission can also become a bit more mobile.
I have just understood the reference in such a way that it will be considered in the Commission, and I thank you for that.

Mr President, Madam Minister, Madam Commissioner, if you have to draw a lesson from Copenhagen, where you, Madam Commissioner, have the presidency, it is that the European Union will have to speak with one voice at such conferences in the future.

We may have different opinions here and there, but if we as Europeans speak with different voices, then our weight will not be credible, and if we are not credible, then other people will not follow us.
Why should they?

That is why I think it is right that the figures we adopted at the end of 2002 under Chancellor Merkel, under Chancellor Merkel in 2007, must basically hold up and constitute the foundations of these negotiations.

I share your view that the ambitious 2Â°C targets should not be seriously questioned today on the basis of a substantially low degree, as this makes the achievement of these targets extremely difficult and makes people run away from us.
I'm very concerned that we're questioning our intellectual property.
So our industry invests money and manpower to develop things.
If we now loosen the fence around this intellectual property and leave the holes as they are at the moment, then we will run out of the valuable parts, namely our property.
I am very much in favour of the transfer of technology, but our companies must also see the point in investing in it, and that is why intellectual property must not be improved.
As far as commitments are concerned, I am also inclined to call on our partners worldwide to make serious commitments.
But they have to be credible, and they have to be feasible for these countries.
Otherwise, we're doing the exact opposite of what we want, which is that they're going to move away from us.
So to act credibly in Cancun is an important point.
The big decisions will be made later in Johannesburg, but in Cancun, I think, we should prepare the field.
I'm a farmer by profession.
If the field is not in order, there will be nothing with the harvest.
Let's focus on the good acreage.
Mr President, during the debate on the European Council this morning there was an incident which I myself do not want to go into because I was the target of an insult.
But I want to say that there are levels where I can't be offended, and where I don't feel offended, because to offend me, you have to have a certain degree of seriousness.
However, I would like to thank you very much for the countless signs of solidarity that I have received here in this House since then.
I would like to thank you very much, ladies and gentlemen from all the political groups.
I think this is a sign of our common democratic and pro-European conviction, which is shared by the overwhelming majority of this House.
Thank you very much for that.

Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, Mr GauzÃ¨s and colleagues, I am pleased that we have now taken the step of putting a sector of the European financial system under European direct supervision for the first time.
This is also a step towards a strong Europe in a single market, towards strong control over a sector which has contributed to the crisis.
I would like to make one more remark, Mr Barnier, because the selection processes for the new authorities are currently underway, and the new authorities are only as good as the staff.

I can only hope that in the selection of staff it will really be about expertise, about independence from the financial industry that they are supposed to control, about clear service to public interests, and that in the selection process we will not see national quotas again that go beyond these important criteria.
In addition, there is still much to be done in the field of rating agencies.

We still do not have the right transparency of the information with which the rating agencies work, we have far too much use of regulatory ratings in the financial industry and in the regulations on the financial industry.
We have serious conflicts of interest, we clearly have a market power of three major suppliers, and we have no liability for negligently created ratings.
That is why I ask you, Commissioner, it is good that the consultation is now under way and we are looking forward to the results.
I think that civil society in particular should be involved in this consultation, but then it must also be a question of making a bold proposal.
I'm looking forward to your proposal.
But be as brave as you have been, and let us make legislation together next year that really solves the problems that still exist in the rating market in Europe.
We owe it to the citizens.
Mr President, Mr Minister, Mr Barnier, ladies and gentlemen, the damage that rating agencies can do has been demonstrated in recent months since the beginning of this year.
So there is an urgent need for action.
That is why I welcome, or in this respect I welcome, the directive, in particular the transfer of the supervision and registration of rating agencies to ESMA.
I think this is an important and good step forward.
However, many good and forward-looking proposals have remained on the table in the negotiations on the report.
I would like to point this out again.
The commissioning of the ESMA therefore remains the only real and positive innovation.
The proposals for a public database for the creation of ratings have been dropped, and there is also no indication of the establishment of a public rating agency.
The consistent and continuous review of ratings by the supervisory authorities has also been put on the table.

The Commission had continued to propose the promotion of uncommissioned ratings in order to overcome the disastrous issuer orders for the evaluation of financial market products, and nothing of that remained.
I hope that these aspects will be taken into account in the forthcoming reports on this subject, of which Jean Paul Gauzet and you, Mr Barnier, have spoken.
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank those who have worked on this report, in particular Mr Benson.
I want to point out two points of view and perhaps make them a little more thoughtful.
We agree that energy efficiency, energy-efficient use is the simplest and most reasonable solution.
The question is, how do we achieve this goal?
And I would like to ask the question: what has it really brought about that we in Parliament have repeatedly approached the people with new and higher percentages?
Have we really achieved more and moved more?
Or why and where energy has been more economically used.
I'm learning that the industry that consumes a lot of energy is more energy-efficient because it saves money and because it's cheaper for it.
I'm learning that when people know that this device consumes more energy or less energy, so if they see that and can decide for themselves an advantage, then they're going to decide for themselves.
Perhaps the method is not to work with percentages properly, but to proceed correctly over incentives.
Secondly, the Commissioner has just made it very clear and very clear how complicated the description of the term alone is.
How different is that in the Member States?
The honourable Member has just pointed out that the Member States also have very different situations, economically and geographically, totally different.
Is that the right answer to working with a number, to working with a binding number, or do we not have to think about it anymore?

I think we have to get away from the debate of the past in energy policy, which with simple numbers, with binding guidelines and with such a miracle solution means that we can do something, because obviously we have not done enough.
Perhaps we should try the other way, the way of differentiated, different answers, which takes in the different situations, but then also produces an effect.
It's about the effects, it's not about our sensitivity.
Mr President, this regulation which is being discussed today has not received much attention in all the committees for a long time.
But now, at the end, when the result was in, some people in this house woke up.
Unfortunately, some of them have not yet appeared for the debate, and it would have been very, very exciting to hear their views.
As a former member of the Convention, I still remember the spirit of the Convention very, very clearly.
In many areas, it has made it very clear that the European Parliament must have certain rights in order to have and maintain its credibility, both within the institutions and with citizens.
In this respect, what the Convention has given us has not yet been given.
It was extremely difficult negotiations, led in particular by the Belgian Presidency with the Council, which made it possible to make some important progress.
I remember what Mr Lehne has already said, namely the question of the constant possibility of checking whether the Commission has exceeded its powers.
Of course, there are some not so ideal regulations, such as international trade agreements, but I can nevertheless agree with the result.
I thank the Belgian Presidency.
She really stood up for something that was happening and for our rapporteur, who negotiated with heart and mind.
