I would like to make the following statement on behalf of our group on paragraph 13 of the report: This is a request made by my colleague, Mr Goerens Ferme, on behalf of our group in the Committee on Budgets.
We have not tabled this amendment again, but the Green Group has tabled the motion again with 40 signatures from the Green Members.
We will abstain on this motion.
But I have reached an understanding with my colleagues in the Green Group on this matter.
But since we have said in principle that we are not bringing in any new amendments as a group, we shall abstain.

But I would like to say explicitly that we support this point on the financial transaction tax and hope that the colleagues on the other side of the House will support us in the votes in the coming days.
Mr President, I think it is important that we do not use national tax systems against the internal market.
This is particularly important in the case of cross-border services, where equal treatment is required.
We now have a negative example in Hungary, where retroactive price limits have been used for crisis taxation.
This is unacceptable, especially for the financial, insurance and trade sectors, but also for energy.
I hope that this will not be used in the field of health services in the future.
I would also like to ask President OrbÃ¡n to review these regulations, because they are in complete contradiction with the concept of the internal market.
It is important that the EU addresses the problems of migration and the right of asylum.
The Commission has made the appropriate proposals.
At present, there is no precise analysis of the implementation of the existing legal arrangements.
Even for the new proposals, there are hardly any mature calculations and analyses.
I should like to point out that the EPP unreservedly supports the right to asylum and the right to protection for those in need of protection.
However, unfortunately, the reality also leads us to the problem that the right to asylum is being exercised for entirely different reasons or even deliberately abused.
The right to asylum and subsidiary protection is not an instrument for the general immigration of these 27 Member States.
We must also ensure that the organised traffickers do not have a chance to make their fortunes in the billions through our right of asylum on the fate of people.
Asylum procedures must be carried out with qualification and care.
Persecuted people must have the guarantee of protection in the EU.
Therefore, the Commission has made appropriate commitments in the new regulations.
I think many of them are right, such as interpreters, proper health care, taking into account special needs for protection.
However, I would also like to mention points which I consider to be problematic.
The authorities of the Member States have far too few opportunities to prevent abuse.
The possibility of accelerated procedures and border procedures should be restricted beyond the fee.

On the contrary, if an applicant massively violates his obligations to participate, there are hardly any sanctions. If he disappears illegally, the Member State should no longer be able to terminate his proceedings in a negative way. If he reappears, he should have an extended range of procedural possibilities.
Even in the event of obvious unfoundedness, an accelerated procedure should be possible only after the second follow-up application.
This means significant cost increases.
Free legal advice in the form of a lawyer is also currently, according to the wording of the Commission's draft, a significant cost increase for the Member States.
I simply ask the Commission to reconsider the consequences of its proposals for the practical reality, the financial implications and the problems for the administrations of the Member States.
We want a high standard, but it must also be feasible and must not impose completely impossible tasks on particularly burdened Member States.
Mr President, thank you very much for allowing me to speak briefly again.
I have a great request to make of you, Commissioner FÃ¼le.
I want to start by saying that wrong assumptions lead to wrong cost estimates.
We do not currently have declining numbers in the area of asylum seekers, but clearly increasing numbers.
This has to do with visa facilitation, for example, to Serbia and Macedonia.
We are also currently experiencing a massive increase in the abuse of the right of asylum in an attempt to enter a country of the European Union.
If you assume that by contesting the first procedure in a higher qualified reform, costs would be saved in other instances, you automatically assume that all Member States have a bad first procedure.
But that's not the case.
If you raise the standards overall, it means that there will be cost increases.
An increase in quality standards for all together and also the complication of procedures, which I am willing to discuss in practical reality, leads to more costs.
That is why I am once again asking you to take the concerns of the countries seriously, because the practical reports from the countries are partly there and are also being given.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission's report is a successful example of competition policy.
However, it must not be forgotten that unregulated competition can also contribute to an increase in unemployment and an increase in the gap between the poor and the rich.
Unhindered competition still ranks ahead of people's social needs in the European Union.
The creed for free markets cannot be overstated, that they not only fail again and again, but are incapable of bringing about social justice in a lasting way.
A few proceedings for distortion of competition and price negotiations do not solve this problem.
A fair and at the same time social single market can only function with strong and fair regulation.
More is urgently needed.
For example, it is unacceptable to subject more and more public services to private competition.
The report sets out indications for the Commission's future competition policy.
Much stronger consumer protection, the exclusion of public subsistence from competition rules and the control of cartels are all urgently needed.
In addition, a contractual clause would be necessary for a guaranteed social progress which is at least on an equal footing with the rules of competition in Europe.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is a very important moment that we are commemorating the Holocaust of Roma and Sinti for the first time in the European Parliament today.
And let me start with the farewell letter that a 14-year-old boy, Robert Reinhardt, wrote to Auschwitz in 1943 before he was deported from a German orphanage.
He wrote, "I found my parents again.
We're on the way to the concentration camp.
But I've struggled so hard inside that I can endure death.
I thank you again for everything you've shown me.
Greetings to all, see you in heaven!
This is Aija Roebeck.

Ladies and gentlemen, this boy did not return, like 500 other Roma and Sinti, and although Roma and Sinti, together with Jews, became the first victims of factory massacres, today, 66 years later, the full truth about it is unspoken.
And the complicity of the majority society is also often obscured.
We need all the truth about this chapter of history.
The Holocaust of Roma and Sinti must be punished and recognized as a crime against humanity so that this story does not repeat itself.
We must fight prejudice against these people with passion.
We must put an end to racist hostilities and violence, such as those that took place in Hungary the year before last, with civil courage.
Freedom and equality and solidarity are not the privilege of the individual, but the right of all, because human and civil rights are indivisible.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, from my point of view it is now a question of really putting the possibilities of the law into practice.
We are in favour of stimulating strong financial supervision in Europe, and we have doubts as to whether these possibilities are really being stimulated institutionally.
We see flaws in the procedure, we have not yet received the list of candidates in advance as a Parliament, but only the finished result.
It would be easy to send them to us now for the executive directors.

We clearly have a lack of gender equality in the appointment of posts, and we have doubts in the process because of certain incidents that the Member States really occupy these institutions in the European interest.
I think that and the other points in our letter legitimize asking a fundamental question.
But beyond that, of course, it is a matter of the suitability of the individual, and then each person must be judged individually and according to his or her competences.
There we see two big problems.

We have seen in the hearings that one of the candidates has denied that it is a European institution, but has spoken of a network of supervisory authorities and was not prepared to correct it even on request.
On the question of whether they are prepared to make all lobbying contacts with the financial industry transparent, we have not received any clear statements.
We have sent a letter to all three candidates, and for us the outcome of the vote depends on whether we get clear and comprehensive answers to it.
Mr President, we as the Social Democratic Group have the same request to make.
However, I would like to recommend to Mr Mauro and the House of Lords that we be a little more precise.
We're dealing with a very large influx.

Today, like every other country in the Mediterranean, Italy is certainly overwhelmed to deal with the current problem alone, and surely Italy will not be the only country faced with the massive influx of refugees.
We can assume that Malta, Greece and Spain will also be faced with the problem in the foreseeable future.

That is why we would ask that the title of the debate be very precise, namely a statement by the Commission on the European Union's immediate measures to support Italy and other EU countries affected by the influx of refugees.
Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I very much welcome the outcome of the conciliation procedure.

With the implementation of the regulation, it will now also be possible to ensure that, in the field of powered bus transport, a high level of protection comparable to that of other modes of transport is in place for all passengers, including those with reduced mobility.

Secondly, a high level of general consumer protection is ensured and, thirdly, account is taken of the specificities of a transport sector predominantly dominated by small and medium-sized enterprises.

Thus, the extreme demands which would have made bus traffic almost impossible because of excessive demands are as far from the table as those in which the majority of Member States would have fallen completely out of the scope of the regulation.
Bus services that benefit citizens in general must also offer high quality to people with disabilities and people with limited mobility.
They should be entitled to help, and in the interest of social integration it should be free of charge.
Madam President, I would like to congratulate all of you, especially Mr Kanchan, on his efforts in the difficult and lengthy process of drawing up a compromise on this difficult dossier.
There were successes that have already been listed, but there were also disappointments, such as the scope and other shortcomings that have already been presented.
With this compromise for bus traffic, we have covered the passenger rights for all modes of transport.
The next necessary step is to create a common, coherent and efficient framework programme for all passenger rights.
Fair and clearly defined rights are of particular importance for the credibility of the EU among European citizens.
And in order to be credible, it is therefore essential to respect the coherence of the rights of the various modes of transport.
It is not the case that the rights of air passengers are fundamentally different from those of, for example, train passengers.

That is why it is particularly important in the development of a framework programme not to focus on the lowest and weakest standards, but to ensure that we do not lose sight of ambitious objectives in the minds of citizens.

Madam President, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are in the midst of a major economic crisis, we have been talking about it for months, that is all right, but we usually talk in headlines and then decide here cheerfully as if nothing had happened.
I believe that the reason is that we in Parliament are not behaving in a concrete and honest way enough, but that is what happens in the headline policy.
What do you really do to promote growth and stability?
Let us help ourselves to deal with finances more orderly and wisely!
Do we really have a critical examination of whether we are making the right expenditure, or does not each of us have a new idea every day where we can still spend money?

If we don't have the power to concentrate the funds on future projects, that is, disputes and disputes and decisions, then there's no point in talking about innovation and research, but not in providing the funds for it.
It's relatively dishonest.
And if we want to stimulate the economy, then we also need to make a policy that stimulates the economy and does not think from morning till night about how to disrupt industry or the economy.
We are still making resolutions, and we are still calling for new resolutions that are disrupting the development of the economy.
Does anyone believe that the question of binding energy efficiency targets, to give just one example, contributes to the advancement of the economy?
Do you really think that with our decisions, which we have often made in the context of energy, we have stimulated the economy?
Or did we disturb them?
I would like us to talk about this a little more honestly and then make a few fewer decisions, but maybe the decisions that really make a difference.
This is more effort, more effort, will also mean strife, but that is the meaning of democracy.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the demand for a financial transaction tax is not new, and for many years now opponents of globalisation have been calling for such a tax.
But five years ago, hardly anyone would have believed that it could be enforced in the foreseeable future.
But this week it is on the agenda in the European Parliament together with a CO2 tax and Eurobonds, and I think that is a good thing.
I can only welcome and support the financial instruments proposed by Mrs Podimata in her report, and I think we will vote accordingly.
There are urgently needed instruments.
The consolidation of public budgets has so far focused solely on cutting expenditure.
But the reduction in public spending affects first and foremost workers, pensioners and the poor, those who are dependent on the welfare state.
The revenue side of the public sector has so far been completely overlooked.
It is the second pivot on which to turn to consolidate public budgets.
But above all, the main causes of the public debt crisis and the repayment of public debt can also be adequately involved through the revenue side.
An increase in tax revenues is simply essential to consolidate public budgets.

In fact, the high level of public debt is mainly the result of the nationalization of private debt, namely the takeover of private bank debts and the financing of the following financial crisis by the public sector.
So the responsibility for the debt crisis is by no means the responsibility of the states alone.
It is therefore not only obvious, but also politically necessary to ask the financial sector to pay.
With the financial transaction tax, this sector would finally be involved in the repayment of this debt as the main cause of public debt.
This is an important political signal that comes from this report if it is adopted as it has been presented.
But we also consider Eurobonds to be a useful and therefore necessary instrument.
They contribute more to the reduction of debt than all sanctions or more or less well-intentioned advice.

On the other hand, the complaints of some surplus countries that their interest burdens are rising through Eurobonds are unacceptable, because at the same time these surplus countries are also earning through their exports to the deficit countries.
This can then be criticized as a transfer union.
But if you want a social Europe, if you want the EU to stay together in the future, you must at least agree in principle to a transfer union.
In conclusion, I would like to say to the Commission that I hope that it will finally present the proposals for a financial transaction tax which have been requested for over a year.
Mr President, Madam President, the rescue shields should protect the EU Member States from insolvency.
But they are overwhelming people with brutal austerity programmes and leaving the polluters unharmed.
Mr Hahn, it is absurd, and it makes one cry when one hears this formal argument here, that all this would not have been sociopolitically intended.
This position is completely unacceptable, wage policy is not a matter for the EU, and this Commission policy is in stark contradiction to the idea of this European Union.
The European Union has never been a project for downward wage competition and social dumping.
There is talk of reading about the rigidity of wages, which should be reduced.
To put it bluntly, wages should reflect market conditions.
Ladies and gentlemen, there are blind people talking about the colour, people who formulate something like that have no idea of collective bargaining systems.
They intervene in the tariff autonomy and lead the much-vaunted autonomy of the social partners and the social dialogue ad absurdum.

I want to make it clear that this Parliament is called upon to ensure the preservation of the autonomous collective bargaining policy, to protect social dialogue and to prevent further reductions in social security.
We need measures against counterproductive austerity and criminal action.
Mr. Barroso, you are a clever man, but you didn't answer my question.

That is why I ask again, when Mr Oettinger says that we have the present suspicion that certain installations which are on the network will not survive our stress tests, I interpret this in such a way that you are aware that these installations are so poorly secured that they do not meet the criteria.
Why don't you step in today?
Because in my eyes, that's a real danger.
I would like to ask the two representatives of the Council and the Commission why they think they have to make a big deal out of this.
I do not think it will help anyone if it is not said very specifically that, in preparation for the Istanbul Conference, the Member States of the European Union and the European Union
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter, and if so what is the Commission's position?
It is unacceptable that a billion people are still starving every day and that most of them live in the poorest countries in the world.

It is unacceptable that a large part of our development aid is not going to support and build up agricultural structures, but that this share has declined rapidly in recent years, that one billion people are starving.
And then to talk about it, we hope that the LDCs will become more shock-resistant, which I think is slowly happening.
I call on you to address the problems in a concrete and clear way and to make concrete commitments to actually help the LDC.
In the context of the internal market, public procurement is an essential part of the public procurement process.

Mr Barnier, if you say that you also want to promote social integration in this context, then I have to ask you: I have heard little about the protection of social rights, I have heard little about the protection of collective agreements.
That is one of the basic rules that you say you do not want to question yourself.

If you want to protect the basic rules, in the future you have to ensure that basic social standards are protected in the award of public contracts, that tariff agreements are not undermined and that wage dumping is put on a footing.
This is part of a modernised public procurement law.
I say explicitly that social fundamental rights must no longer be subordinated to economic freedoms and free competition.
Either we want a social Europe or we want a permanent conflict with the people who are turning away from this Europe in which they do not see their life interests being safeguarded.
Madam President, Commissioner Kroes, radio frequencies are a precious and limited commodity to be managed with care, foresight and in the context of society as a whole.
That is why the radio spectrum policy programme is of particular importance.
Radio frequencies must be used efficiently, taking into account economic, social and cultural aspects.
To this end, the technical capabilities in all band areas must be used to the fullest extent in order to achieve the greatest possible efficiency.

The basis of radio frequency policy must be the telecom package adopted last year, because it has also been stated here that radio frequency management must be equally compatible with the cultural, social and economic interests of the EU and its Member States.
This must be taken into account in particular in the harmonisation of frequency use in the EU.
In this context, I would like to point out that the implementation of Digital Dividend 1 is being implemented at very different speeds in the Member States so far.
A further opening of the UAF band, especially below 800 MHz, should therefore only be considered in the light of the experience gained in the release of this band.
Many technical and financial issues have not yet been resolved.

And it is precisely the problem of interference and the question of cost compensation for cultural institutions and local authorities in the field of technical refurbishment, for example in the field of radio microphones, that have not yet been satisfactorily resolved.
In the distribution of frequency bands, the different interests must be responsibly weighed against each other.

On the one hand, the comprehensive provision of mobile broadband is a basic requirement in the interest of European citizens, but at the same time development in the field of public and private broadcasting must continue to be taken into account as an important instrument for information and cultural diversity.
We must correct the course for technical development, Europe's position in the field of digital information technology and cultural diversity.
Mr President, Mr Rehn, I would first like to say that you have described the situation as having worsened.
The eurozone, the gap between countries that are recovering and countries that are weaker.
And the cost of supporting the weaker countries keeps rising.

In this situation, I have a few questions for you. As Commissioner for Finance, I ask you: on the two-day accounts of the ECB system, liabilities and claims between the central banks have risen to over EUR 400 billion.
This is because banks are still not sufficiently financed by the capital market.
How do you assess these commitments not provided for in the euro system?
Then the big problem with why we're not moving forward with the restructuring of the debt is that the banking system, as Mrs. Ford has also said, is not set up properly.
The proposal for a European restructuring system has been delayed.
When does the Commission propose this?
And how do you, as Commissioner for Economic and Monetary Affairs, assess this delay?
What do you do to make it go faster?
Then we saw, as we Greens have long predicted, that the measures against Greece and Portugal will not work as long as macroeconomic conditions in the euro area are not better.
We still have absolutely rising interest rates macroeconomically for these countries.
We have increasing capital exports and capital flight in some of these countries.
And we still have a lack of demand from a number of European partner countries, especially from the strong euro countries.
And we have rising resources and food prices, at least if you take into account the latest ups and downs.

I wonder, in addition to the bailout for these countries, in addition to the aid on the financing side, what measures are being taken to ensure that the weaker countries are macroeconomically relieved of these fronts, of the demand from the outside, of the interest rate.
And in the
I would therefore encourage you to propose a strong package that improves the macroeconomic conditions of these countries in the euro area.

And finally, in my view, the measures have hit the weakest in the countries of Greece, Portugal and Spain against the spirit of the EU Treaty, while the stronger, the wealthier have not been brought to bear any of the burdens so far.
What measures are you taking to get the wealthy involved in the costs of this crisis?
Mr President, Mrs Kinger GÃ¶ncz is a Member of my group.
You can be against Ferenc GyurcsÃ¡ny, you can be for Ferenc GyurcsÃ¡ny.
You can reject King Gons as a politician or be for her.
It is certainly free and independent for everyone to determine whether one is for or against a person's political beliefs.
The debate we are having here is about the last dictatorship that exists in Europe.
And we are leading them through one of the most brutal and bloody dictators on the European continent.
I find it absolutely unacceptable that a freely elected democratic member of my group should be compared to a bloodthirsty dictator.

I think that Parliament must also reject this, in particular the representative of a party which, for its part, is characterised by the fact that it overwhelms the Roma minority in Hungary with hatred and persecution, which is looking for its counterpart in Europe.
If one person here does not have the right to criticize Mrs Kinga GÃ¶ncz, then it is Mrs.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, the cultural diversity of Europe is an important asset that must be preserved and developed in the future.
To make this possible, we must face the challenges of the digital age not only in the information and knowledge society, but above all in the cultural and creative sectors.
Cultural diversity is not only an ideal value, it is also an important economic factor.
In the EU, about five million people are employed in the cultural sector.
This corresponds to about 2.5 per cent of total employment.
The cultural sector is a growth sector that is developing faster than many other sectors of the economy.

The development of information and communication technologies is driven by the content offered by the cultural sector, just as the type and quality of content has been changed and further developed by technology.
We therefore need a framework for the cultural and creative industries to develop sustainably in the face of the challenges of the digital age.
We need a modern, accessible and law-abiding system in which everyone can develop equally.
The cultural and creative industries are a driving force for Europe.
That is why we must also pay attention to this area in the field of school and vocational education.
We need to impart cultural and creative skills to young people, including in the lifelong learning offerings.
But we also need to strengthen the entrepreneurial skills of cultural creators, and not only the entrepreneurial skills, but also a good media competence in the field of new technologies.
We need a framework in which cultures can secure their livelihoods.
That is why we will have to deal intensively with the issues of copyright, social security and intellectual property, but also with open access to information and content in order to develop the
to safeguard the creative and cultural industry in a digital environment in the future and to preserve Europe's cultural diversity and heritage as an essential feature of the European Union.
Mr President, Mr Kallam, ladies and gentlemen from the Baltic countries, ladies and gentlemen, today we commemorate in a special way the expulsions and mass deportations from the Baltic countries.
These expulsions are among the darkest events in European history.
In fact, the last century has been called, not only and not least for this reason, and not unjustly, a century of expulsions.
And we all bow today to the victims of these inhuman acts.
In this context, we call for a complete enlightenment of Soviet history and in particular the atrocities of Stalinism.

Today's Russia should not see this as a political attack, but as support for the processing of its own history, which, like the history of the other countries of Europe, is marked by suns and shadows.
But just as we think of the victims from the Baltic countries, we think of the Armenians who were expelled from Turkey at the beginning of the following century.
We commemorate the so-called population exchange between Turkey and Greece.
A particular highlight was the deportations to Europe in the middle of the century by the Nazi regime and the Communist regime of the Soviet Union.
The post-World War II expulsions also inflicted deep wounds, as did the expulsions during the Yugoslav War.
But we must also not forget that many colonial empires were characterized by expulsions.
We must demand a serious debate on the various forms of expulsions and the pretence of justification.
And that includes clearing the guilty and punishing the guilty as far as possible, as is the case now, for example, in the Mladic case.

But the decisive answer is European unity, especially through and with the independent Baltic countries, and a clear commitment to the continuation of the European unity process, which has not yet been completed.
This historic task is what we owe not only to ourselves, but also to the victims of the many expulsions in Europe.
Many politicians from all the countries of Europe, from East and West, have worked on this.
For example, consider the Danzig Declaration signed by Polish President Wojciechowski and German Federal President Raul.
And because we want to learn from the past, we must also be vigilant about the first steps of expulsions, such as in the case of the Roma.

We must reject all statements such as that the Arab immigrants should be sent back to the Mediterranean in boats, and we must defend ourselves if some want to lift Europe's achievements without borders and return to a new narrow nationalism.
Let us bow in reverence to all the victims of expulsion and deportation, but let us unanimously commit ourselves to the continuation of European unity as the only real guarantee against
It is a policy which has brought so much misery to the people of Europe in the last century, but it has also brought so much misery to Europe.
They have lost none of their validity, and it is best to abolish them in a common Europe.

Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I had the opportunity, as an observer of the elections to Parliament, to witness the referendum on the independence of South Sudan, and I was impressed by the great support of the South Sudanese for the future of their country itself.
I also saw the great expectations of the people who saw their country's independence as liberation from slavery.

Thousands, perhaps tens of thousands, of so-called internally displaced persons, who drove the decades-long fighting in the South into the refugee camps of the North, made their way to their former South Sudanese homeland.

And of course, the people of South Sudan, in addition to the independence of the country, especially living in peace, want to make a way for a happier future after all the decades of war, in which millions of South Sudanese had to give their lives.
On 9 July, the new state of South Sudan will officially become independent and expand the family of states of our world.
The starting conditions are unthinkably bad, and there's been a lot of talk about that here.
Seventy percent of the people live as urbanizing livestock farmers, eighty percent are illiterate, and the conflict over Abyei is expanding into a military conflict.
There were already dead and wounded.

If that were not enough, the rivalries between the tribes and armed groups in South Sudan are also increasing, and according to observers, more than a thousand people have already lost their lives since January.
The wounded and the damaged are hardly counted.
Sudan was already one of the failed states.
There is a danger that the state of South Sudan is already starting as a failed state.
I am firmly convinced that there is a great commitment on the part of Europe to this region.
In view of the colonial past of the countries there, together with the UN and the African Union, the common European foreign policy is required here, and it can be proved here as well.
It is not just about money, but also about supporting the delicate, emerging civil society.

And we must negotiate hard with those in whose hands the fate of the country lies, namely the tribal leaders, led by the military groups, so that they do not disappoint the hopes of their people in the country.
Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I am very grateful to Mr Bartolozzi for taking the initiative in making Mongolia the subject of a debate in the European Parliament.
While the former Soviet states of Central Asia are now being dealt with from different points of view in Parliament, Mongolia and its situation here have received very little response.
It was very unfair that Mongolia, as a state of the former communist bloc, took advantage of its independence quite early and embarked on a path to democratize its society.

Already in 1992, the Mongols gave themselves a democratic constitution, and since then several elections have taken place, which, according to observers, have had an all-out democratic and correct course, which is long since taken for granted by the states of this region.

The Mongolian government has been trying to fight corruption by law for several years and in 2010 imposed a moratorium on the death penalty, which even some large democratic states have not succeeded in doing until today.

Nevertheless, the three million inhabitants of this large country, dominated by extreme climatic conditions, are still suffering from the consequences of a transformation process that is still taking place.
This is how a rural population that is still predominantly nomadic is pushing into the few cities that are not infrastructurally prepared for it.
The country's soil resources are not being mined in an environmentally friendly way.
Energy problems are making civilian and economic life difficult.
Forced between the great neighbours Russia and China, Mongolia threatens to become even more dependent on these countries than before.

The efforts and successes of Mongolia, and here I see the glass half full and not half empty, in democratizing society should be recognized as exemplary for this region and show what is possible despite a difficult past.
Mongolia should continue to receive our support not only in the framework of aid programmes, but also in the European Union's direct presence in the Mongolian capital.

I would like to thank the representatives of the European Parliament for their presence in Beijing, as a sign that the fate of Mongolia is not indifferent to us Europeans and that the European interests are not still being perceived by the representatives in Beijing.
I am very sorry that the Conference of Presidents was not prepared to give this request additional emphasis with the adoption of a resolution by Parliament.
But, Mr President, of course I recognize this right.
I only assume, and I hope you also recognize, that the position of the Dutch Government is not proclaimed ex cathedra, but is set free for discussion in a multinational democracy.
I have absolute respect for Mr RÃ¼te, who is in favour of an increase of 2.7 in the EU budget.
I have taken note of this and I am pleased that you have listened to me carefully, because in this Parliament the positions of all governments are openly discussed.
In this respect, I did not quite understand the meaning of your question, but what I thought I heard was that you too were committed to democracy.
That's a step forward after all.

Firstly, I reacted so excitedly because I am still upset that we have not been able to reach a common security resolution here, because the absolutization of a position was more important than commonality.

Secondly, I explained in the debate at the time, and I will explain this again, that I too have learned and see today that we need to do more in the area of more safety regulation for European nuclear power plants, we need to put more pressure, we need to show more initiative.
That is why I am in favour of the joint resolution, and that is why I am in favour of strengthening the Commissioner's back and not attacking him permanently.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I could have certainly imagined other solutions at the outset, Mr Pieper, after, for example, the regions which have the highest demand so far and which will not have it after 2013 have received a transitional regulation.
However, the discussion showed that we need to take into account other regions, especially those affected by the crisis.
We are talking about 51 regions at the moment.
And in the face of so many affected regions, it would be downright negligent not to establish an intermediate category.
This is the only way to provide a reliable framework for the responsible promotion of these regions, which have to reduce their development backlogs on their own.
Otherwise, there is a lot of light and a lot of shadow in the PIP report.

We criticize, among other things, the fact that there is no clear commitment to a much more decisive fight against poverty and consider the formulations contained here to link cohesion policy with conditionalities which force the Member States to carry out reforms to be unclear and very widely interpreted.
Point one Cohesion policy must remain an instrument of social balance and solidarity in all regions.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues, internal regional cooperation is becoming more and more important in the future.
Cross-border cooperation and macro-regional cooperation are extremely important in a growing Europe for the achievement of the 2020 targets.
Border regions still face particular challenges today.

Cross-border concepts and projects, such as in the areas of infrastructure, business cooperation, research cooperation, labour market development and training, are the driving force for large parts of the European Union.
We need clear and simplified structures for the implementation of interregional projects.
Different national requirements for project partners often make it difficult to cooperate and implement concrete sustainable projects.
It is an important step that the PIPE report includes the call for an extension of the share of interregional cooperation to target 3 to 7 and I would like to support this strongly.
Madam President, Mr Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, after almost three years of intensive work, after far more than three amendments, after countless conversations and discussions,

After the most difficult technical negotiations and political trilogues, the political package, the major compromise between the European Parliament and the Council of Ministers on the future labelling of foodstuffs, is now up for vote.
This regulation is intended to give the consumer more and better information on food so that he can make a targeted purchase decision.
But that is not all. The European food economy should also benefit.
The aim is legal certainty, de-bureaucratization and better legislation.
This is particularly important for small and medium-sized enterprises, and it should be noted that the food sector in the European Union is made up of more than 80 SMEs.
At the same time, this labelling must be appropriate for all food and all non-alcoholic beverages, from basic foodstuffs to processed finished dishes.
That is why it is not possible to have a compulsory labelling in traffic lights, because this labelling does not apply to basic foodstuffs.
Despite all the difficulties, despite all the political and ideological differences in Parliament, despite all the national selfishness of the Member States, the compromise now reached can be seen.
Allergens will be detected at first glance.
The plant origin of plant oils is indicated.
There is a country of origin label for pork, poultry, sheep and goat meat.

For further products, an impact assessment will show whether and how the origin can be indicated, for example for milk and dairy products, i.e. products consisting of a single main ingredient, meat in processed form.
Imitations will have to be clearly marked on the front, and the same applies to minced meat and minced fish, put together, glued together in small pieces.
Nor should a packaging give the impression that something is in it that is not in it.
If there's a picture of fruit on a yogurt, there has to be fruit in it, and not just dye and fragrance.
In addition, there is a mandatory indication of the most important nutrients, always per 100 grams or 100 millilitres, for reasons of comparability.
Additional water for meat must be indicated, the date of the first deep freeze for meat and fish and many other details.
But most importantly, all the information must be readable.

We have defined readability, we have set a minimum font size and we have instructed the Commission to establish binding rules for other factors, such as the contrast between the font and the background.
At the same time, we protect the craft from too high costs and bureaucracy.
Fresh products not pre-packaged may need to provide the allergen information, but not the complete nutritional information to be determined by expensive analyses.

The Commission originally wanted this, but it would have destroyed our national and regional peculiarities and specialties, it would have led to the European unity brew, and that is why we have prevented it.
But now we have all agreed, and the serious consumer advocates are quite satisfied with what has been achieved.

I would therefore like to thank all those involved, the Commission's shadow rapporteurs, in particular Commissioner Dalli, for their statements, which he will hopefully make shortly and which will break the knot that has been formed in our political discourse.

And I am particularly grateful to the Hungarian Presidency of the Council, which has achieved something that was almost unexpected, namely the quadratization of the circle, the agreement on this regulation.
Mr President, Mr Commissioner, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, allow me to join in your thanks to the rapporteur, Mrs Ayala Sender.
As has been noted, since 2008 the Council has blocked progress on this dossier until a compromise could finally be reached under the Belgian Presidency.
As I said, improved data exchange between Member States will make it possible in the future to pursue cross-border criminal prosecutions for various traffic offences throughout Europe.
The ultimate objective must be to increase road safety and reduce the number of road deaths and injuries.

Together with the initiative report by Dieter Koch on road safety, which makes a number of very concrete proposals, this directive can also contribute to better compliance with these rules through its repressive nature.
I do not need to go into the rules, they have already been positively presented here.
The change in the legal basis from European transport policy to police cooperation has finally enabled the Council to formulate a common position.
However, this means that some countries, such as the United Kingdom, Ireland and Denmark, are excluded.
Once again, not all European citizens are on an equal footing.
Citizens need to be aware of the rights they have in terms of data protection.
We have tried to strengthen this aspect so that access to the data collected, its transmission and storage are regulated as strictly as possible.
We were also very interested in the information.
Although the current text does not fully meet Parliament's expectations, I am nevertheless optimistic that this is a first step in the right direction.
I hope that in the coming years we will be able to build on this basis in order to take a step towards greater harmonisation of European transport rules.
The revision clause added by Parliament would in any case allow such a procedure.
I very much regret that this text has now been thrown into the whirlwind of the institutional conflict between the Council and Parliament over the correlation tables.
We agreed during the trilogues to find a comprehensive compromise on this subject with the Joint Declaration.
I would like to remind you briefly that tomorrow the European Road Traffic Association
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank Mrs Mac Matthias very much for this report.

I would also like to thank my colleagues who have made reports before, Mrs MÃ¶rkis and Mrs Carvalho, and this is a consequence, and the day is now approaching when we will not only make political decisions.
We must not only understand this, but also prove that we are serious about it by pointing out that research and innovation is the decisive question for the future of the European Union.
That is why I am very grateful that the representative of the Committee on Budgets has also pointed out that adequate and good financial equipment in this area is an important issue.
We will soon have to settle this dispute as to whether we have the power to provide the necessary financial resources so that this area of research and innovation also really becomes a central one.
It is of central importance for the question of whether and how Europe will develop in the future.
By the way, it is no longer enough to have small and large Sunday speeches, but facts must be provided.
Secondly, we will not get past it ourselves, and this has been very well worked out in the report, and we will also have a close look at whether we can use our resources more effectively.
How do we simplify the process?
Where do we get the speed?
We're going to make research funding more effective.
How do we get out of the partly still unclear labyrinth of different research funding stronger structure, stronger simplification?
Sometimes less is more, little projects, but a lot of money invested has a higher effect in the end.
That is why I am grateful that we have taken another step forward in this report.

Of course, the European Research Council, the European Institute of Innovation and Technology will play a special role, and of course the area of small and medium-sized enterprises is an important one.
We also need a solution for those countries which, in terms of excellence, must remain the only principle, which is correct, compulsory and also in the future.
And in this report there is also the idea of a possible competition, with which new leading research centres in neighbouring regions can perhaps also be promoted.
And that, I think, is an important task that still needs to be solved.

Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in view of the current extraordinary situation resulting from the financial, economic and budgetary crisis, decisions at European level should focus on urgent and essential issues.
This is the only way to restore confidence in the seriousness of our actions among our citizens.
My report deals with the strategy for avoiding endless human suffering, resulting in about 35 deaths a year and more than
2.5 million often serious injuries as a result of road traffic accidents, as well as the avoidance of an associated economic damage of EUR 130 billion annually.
The number of deaths alone is equivalent to that of the crash of 250 full-fledged medium-sized transport aircraft.
What wouldn't we do to prevent that?
The costs of accidents far exceed the annual total budget of the European Union.
That is why I am sure that we are well placed to work sustainably in this area.

Thanks to the constructive cooperation of all the shadow rapporteurs and many colleagues, we have succeeded for the first time in developing a uniform, comprehensive and coherent approach to improving road safety.
It takes into account the content of the UN Road Safety Charter 2010 as well as the content and objectives of the road safety work of the EU Member States and the wider civil society.
Firstly, it contains ambitious but realistic targets for the period up to 2020 and, with the vision of zero, for the period beyond.
So by 2020, the number of fatal accidents should be reduced by 50%, the number of children killed by 60%, and the number of seriously injured by 40%.
This is in the best interests of each and every one of us, but also in our economy.
We recommend that Member States break down targets and methods into their own territory and expect their own road safety action programmes.
Secondly, it includes who is responsible for the individual activities and measures.
This is by no means the only European Union.

In the sense of subsidiarity, the holistic approach means that the Member States, regional or municipal responsible companies, and even each individual road user, must also take responsibility in the sense of their participation obligation.
And thirdly, it includes how, i.e. with what instruments, activities and measures the objectives are to be achieved.
Legislative proposals at European level are just one strategy.
We cannot and do not want to do without guidelines, recommendations and orders.
Particular attention has been paid to subsidiarity, which means that responsibilities and responsibilities have been clearly defined, even where they are shared.
We appreciate the Commission's diverse activities.

But since they come from the most diverse general directorates such as transport, economy, consumer protection, environment, communication, research and development, the internal market and others, they are not always coherent, often uncoordinated, they are sometimes contradictory.
That is why we are proposing the appointment of a road safety coordinator within the European Commission.
This avoids the establishment of a road safety agency in the long term, but increases the efficiency of the European Commission enormously.
Both the choice of measures and their evaluation require a scientifically based approach based on comparable, qualitatively high-quality data, definitions and statistics.

We therefore call, among other things, for a harmonised analysis of the causes of injuries and accidents and for the EU-wide exchange of data while maintaining a high level of personal data protection.
Six main fields of action have been identified.
They concern people as road users, road traffic regulations, vehicles, infrastructure, their intelligent networking and the special consideration of weaker road users.
I ask your consent tomorrow.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, yes, we should concentrate on urgent and essential issues in road safety.
I am very convinced of this, and from my point of view it concerns first and foremost the two biggest distracting factors in traffic, namely alcohol and speeding.
The European Union must also say something about this and not just propose technical measures which, in my view, are good but far from sufficient.
Especially in cities, the lack of attention is particularly dramatic for the problem of inattentive drivers.
That's why the speed has to be reduced here.
I was very pleasantly surprised that there was a broad majority in favour of the recommendation on the 30th.
I think it is important and good that weaker road users are finally getting the attention they deserve, and I hope that these measures will finally be implemented.
It seems pointless to me, but I would like to make an invitation to you.
I have never seen him in the discussions on Rio or on other major global conferences, but I have always heard him speak here in the plenary.
I would really like to ask you, Mr President, to come to the committee.
They sit down with us, they offer us their offers, and then we talk to them about the message.
And the speech that you just delivered, you can't do anything about it.
Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your fundamental statements.
However, these fundamental statements are not an answer to the questions that have been asked.
Because the questions are aimed at ensuring that we get results quickly.
The industries that we want to exclude from these additional burdens here, or where we want to create fair conditions, need planning certainty.
We therefore need decisions soon.
We need quick decisions, reliable decisions and also clear statements from the Commission.
This process has been going on for a very, very long time.

We all knew that this was a very complicated procedure that we had to deal with, but we also said in the compromise on the Emissions Trading Directive at the time that we were doing this with the Emissions Trading Directive.
This is on the condition that the industries in Europe which are overburdened by this can experience a relief because otherwise they cannot compete with other sectors of the world.
And I expect that what was the basis of business at the time, the basis of decision-making in Parliament, with the Council, with the Commission, will also be realised in this way.
I'm a little worried that along the way the circle of those affected by this is getting smaller and smaller, that you're getting smaller and smaller in terms of looking at more and more areas.

But it's not just about steel, it's about aluminum, you know, it's about many other areas of chemistry and so on, and that you just don't actually implement what was the political basis of the decision at the time.
Commissioner, you have rightly pointed out that the situation for industry in Europe has not become easier since this decision, but has become more difficult.
We have a whole new situation, we have a much bigger competitive situation.
We are all fighting for this and we are declaring here in our speeches on Sunday that industry is a very important area for the future development of Europe.
Yesterday we heard clever talk again.

I expect Parliament to expect, I believe it, that what was agreed at the time will now be implemented, in favour of the industries, not the industries, but the people who work in these companies, the jobs and thus also the future opportunities of Europe.
Do you know of any example that would actually justify the expense of spending millions, that's billions, to develop these body scanners?
Are there examples that prove that this has increased safety?
Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the representative of the Council for his very clear description of the current situation.
We have heard repeatedly in this debate that it is about improving the situation for women in the workforce who are choosing to have a child.
In my view, the directive is too much focused on increasing maternity protection to 20 weeks.
But do we really believe that the decision for one child can be reduced to 20 weeks of maternity leave?
As a mother of three, I know very well that overall concepts and good offers for families are necessary to positively influence the decision for a child and to create opportunity for women.
The present draft directive is not roughly in line with the various, sometimes very good, supply concepts and overall concepts in some Member States.
We need flexible solutions that meet the situation in the Member States and societies and the resulting needs of the families.
Maximum requirements and wishful thinking do not lead to a solution here.
That is why we here in Parliament must first develop a solid and realistic basis for negotiations.
The comprehensive protection of mothers and the welfare of children are of the highest priority.
This can be ensured in different ways with different models.
If you want to get your head through the wall, you don't necessarily get there faster.
Lack of willingness to compromise does not open doors and build bridges.
A moderate proposal would be a better solution and more maternity protection to get ahead of this.

I believe that we really need to look for an approach, on the basis of the Commission's draft directive, with more flexibility for different concepts in the individual Member States, to significantly improve maternity protection for women and also protection for children in the first months of life.
This does not work with the draft that is before us today, and it certainly did not have the large majority that some colleagues have tried to make clear today.
I would like to see a little more flexibility and a little more realism and a little better insight into what the Member States have already done today without questioning our basic demands.
Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to make a few remarks on the tax agreement between Germany and Switzerland, as others have already done.
Instead of pushing a barrier to tax evasion, which would make sense instead of filling loopholes for tax evaders, a Swiss cheese with large holes has been produced here.
The planned five-month transitional period leaves taxpayers plenty of time to transfer money from Switzerland to other tax havens.
Since foundations and trusts are not covered by the agreement, it is also sufficient to convert the assets housed in Switzerland into a foundation asset.
The corresponding forms are available in Swiss banks.
The tax evasion in Germany has recently been played with information about a number of taxpayers who keep their assets hidden in Switzerland.
The agreement now grants amnesty to these persons, and taxpayers are no longer allowed to use the information available to them.
What kind of agreement is this that puts tax evasion on the back burner?
In a promotional video by Swiss banks, it is said that this agreement will also benefit customers even better in the future from the value of the Swiss financial market.

This agreement obviously lacks not only the necessary vote at EU level, but also the EU's efforts to create more transparency on tax issues, to make tax collection in the Member States more efficient and, above all, to combat and curb tax fraud.
That is why, from our point of view, this cannot be acceptable.
We welcome this agreement and we ask the EU to be strong in the event of doubt.
Mr President, in accordance with the rules of procedure of our House and in agreement with the political groups, I ask that this work be referred back to the committees.
Madam President, I am pleased that we have succeeded in putting together a sustainable and effective directive with the report by Roberta Angelilli, and I would like to thank her for that.
The directive represents a significant step in the fight against child abuse.
However, we must not lose sight of the fact that the vast majority of crimes still take place in the most social environment for children.
The perpetrators are found in family schools and in the circles of acquaintances.
And here we are at the beginning of our enlightenment work.

That's why our children need to be made strong, strong enough to have the courage to trust a close person in case of an emergency, but also strong enough to recognize dangers like grooming in dealing with the Internet.
We must therefore work together to ensure that media accountability plays a greater role in the education of our children.
In this context, education is of the utmost importance, as many teachers and parents do not even know what can be done with their children's computers or mobile phones.
And I think there's a great need for retrieval.

It is therefore welcome that this report also attaches great importance to prevention, since the authorities, but also schools and families, must do everything possible to prevent such heinous crimes from occurring in the first place.
As a result, better EU negotiation strategies with third countries, such as the United States and Russia, are also needed.

And pages stored outside the EU can only be effectively and quickly deleted if we also work closely with these countries in the investigation of the perpetrators and together send a clear signal to stop sexual abuse of children.
Unfortunately, until now, the legislator has often been surprisingly lenient and has only exposed the bulk of the crimes to probation.
In the future, the severity of the crime should be taken more into account.
Overall, however, it is important that the public debate continues, as the subject has the most diverse dimensions.

Prevention, protection of victims, technical development, as well as the removal of barriers, litigation, information and intensive scientific documentation of the case must also be further promoted after the vote tomorrow.
It's just that we can't put our hands in our pockets.
Rather, we must accept the mandate of action from all of us, each of us, and provide prevention and education.
Mr President, for years the volume of the EU budget has been at about the same level.
The EU's tasks have been steadily expanding and the financial need has increased significantly.
In this way, new institutions necessary for financial market supervision have been created.
However, in order to be able to carry out their tasks effectively, these institutions need good financial equipment.
As a result of the financial and banking crisis, the economic weaknesses of some EU Member States have become unpredictable.
A comprehensive economic recovery programme would be needed to strengthen the economies of these countries.
Some economic experts even speak of the need for a Marshall Plan for the EU countries in crisis.
The EU does not need growth-destroying austerity programmes, but a growth-enhancing spending programme that provides jobs and income for young people in the EU.
But what does the Council do in this situation?
It shortens the Commission's proposal, which is already far behind the requirements.

If, in the current political situation, an appropriate increase in the budget is not feasible, Parliament and the Commission should do everything possible to at least avert the cuts proposed by the Council.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, right now in the midst of the crisis, it is becoming clear which European Union we really want.
Do we want a Union in which, as a member, we actually say that we do not care whether people have to live in poverty in any country, in any Member State of the European Union?
We see ourselves in the common responsibility to fight poverty and social exclusion.
Or shall we choose a Union, as has just been outlined by the colleagues from the far-right groups in this Parliament?

Sometimes I think that with the attitude of the Member States and in particular of some of the governments of these Member States, we are dangerously close to this vision of a European Union, as it has just been formulated by the right-wing extremes.
It is simply not possible to do anything together, to set no common instruments, to set no common indicators, to make vague statements wherever possible.
The Derrida report makes this very clear on many points, and I believe that we must become much stronger here.
What we need is an immediate halt to the sale of public goods, the sale of social security systems.
We need social and ecological minimum standards.
In view of the forthcoming winter, it must not happen again that people are put on the streets, deported and eventually frozen to death because of rising energy prices.
Here we have a common responsibility, the responsibility of the European Union.
That is what we must stand for, not for this nationalist rhetoric that we have heard from the right.

What would we have advised our colleagues in 1931 or 1938 when there was a depression, when the financial markets had already overthrown democracies at that time, and when they were leaning towards wars?
I think two things would be necessary, two emergency measures.
Do what you have to do quickly, don't let yourself be slowed down, regulate every product, every institution and every player like that.
But a transitional government alone, which enforces the financial emergency programme, cannot have a future if there is no democratic emergency programme.

And that means in this case, of course, we need a new European Community, of course, we need other treaties, of course, we need a work that works, but that only gets legitimacy and legitimacy when there are referendums.

And for that we must now advertise that the situation has become so dramatic that there must be a great deal of rethinking before the right, before the nationalists get the upper hand over something that has already been built.
Madam President, there is no doubt that this House is committed to transparency and openness towards the citizen.
Of course, my EPP group does the same.
But this report goes far beyond the actual objective.
Existing legislation and interinstitutional agreements are ignored, and the protection of competitive procedures, sensitive and personal data is disregarded.
This is a massive violation of the data protection that we are always so committed to elsewhere.
Should we now reveal the privacy of the world's public?
This is precisely the danger of this report, because administrative procedures and decisions, which for example also include personnel questions, are to be published.
The same applies to the protection of trade secrets and sensitive information in the context of authorisation procedures, court proceedings and competition proceedings.

With its vague, vague and far too broad definitions, the report also allows public access to such documents, because as a document all data and content are defined in any context with the policies, measures and decisions of all EU bodies and institutions.
This includes, to a large extent, preparatory, confidential and secret documents and all related information.
And so this definition includes not only documents, but also information.
Information from ongoing interinstitutional proceedings, such as informal trilogue negotiations, should also be published.
Do you really know what that means, Mr. Rapporteur?
It means public access to the procedure, it means public influence on the decision-making process, then we could immediately put the lobbyists to the table and let them negotiate.
I can't imagine that.
In addition, documents in connection with non-legislative procedures, measures by internal administrative organisations, etc. should also be published.
Or would it not rather hinder our work?
I think this report is not in the interests of our citizens.
It would lead to a flood of useless information.
It would make our work impossible, and above all, as you have heard from the Commissioner, it is unacceptable to the other institutions because it violates the rules and laws in force.
You know that, Mr Rapporteur, and basically you are working against further transparency and against the citizen.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, on such an important and comprehensive subject as the White Paper on the future of transport, there is always the risk of ending up with a Christmas tree where everyone tries to accommodate his two or three wishes.
If you look at the result, which will be put to the vote tomorrow, you can undoubtedly congratulate our rapporteur, Mr Matthieu Grosch.

He has succeeded in producing a good, coherent and transparent result from several hundred amendments, which puts the main emphasis on safety, environmental protection, energy and technology for the transport of the future.
I expressly welcome the fact that such important issues as the social, health and labour law conditions of employees are also appropriately mentioned here.

This is particularly important in view of the threat of a shortage of skilled workers in the transport sector, which must be actively addressed if we are to prevent future bottlenecks for well-trained skilled workers.
Further opening of cabotage in road transport only on the condition that social dumping and unfair conditions are prevented.
I also welcome the fact that the aspect of improving road safety is given an important place here.
Road safety is an issue that we will have to deal with in the future.
I find other points rather critical.
So I would have liked a statement on modern shifts, where more traffic would be put from the road to the railway and to the waterways.
And for that reason, I do not think that the discussion on the gigaliners is the best solution for more sustainability.
Equally critical should be the further liberalisation of the railway sector and the opening up of national passenger transport.
There is still technical harmonisation and fair competition to be solved.

But as I said in this report, I hope that Parliament's expectations will be expressed here, that there will be no pious wish list, but that by 2020 a goal will be achieved and our proposals will have become a reality.
Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is only 20 years since the Central Asian states gained their state independence as a result of the collapse of the Soviet Union.
Coming from a dictatorship, the construction of democratic and rule of law structures in these countries remains a constant challenge.
Nevertheless, these countries are important trading partners of the EU and its Member States because of their wealth of natural resources and raw materials.
It is therefore only logical to regulate the EU's relations with these countries within the framework of partnership and cooperation agreements.
Partnership and cooperation agreements are intended to serve cooperation and to lead to partnership action, but not to one-sided stigmatisation.
Child labour, and especially forced child labour, is unfortunately still a widespread evil in many countries of the world that must be fought.

However, I would point out that it was common practice in many agricultural regions of Europe to extend the school holidays of children during the harvest season and to give children from peasant families the opportunity to help in the harvest, which no one today would call forced labour.
However, if there are signs of child labour in Uzbekistan during the cotton harvest, consequences must be drawn.
But the same must apply to all other countries where child labour still exists, including those countries where we pursue economic interests of a very different magnitude than in India or China.
We should not measure here with two measures.
Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Mr President-in-Office of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I can only join the ranks of those who have congratulated the Presidency of the Council.
You were not only an honest broker in difficult times, but you were also a European broker.

I think it was very pleasant to feel this in these difficult times, when we have political currents in a number of Member States which suggest to people that one could achieve more alone than together.
And you've put the common good at the center.
It was also very refreshing to see that you also found support among the people of Poland in the internal political debate on this clear European agenda.
It wasn't easy in this context.
And also the utmost respect for what you have done.
We have been able to do a lot in this half year, especially in the area of financial market regulation.

If I may just mention one area which I was allowed to discuss myself, namely the question of the regulation of short selling and uncovered credit default swaps on government bonds, where the Commission has not dared to propose a strict regulation, where we are all

Member States have been told that they will not prevail, and that thanks to the Polish Presidency of the Council it has been possible to sanction a highly speculative instrument in this way and, where necessary, to ban it in order to contribute to greater stability in the financial markets.
I would like to express my gratitude to your Minister of Finance and to the Secretary of State who initiated this in a difficult discussion process between Parliament and the Council.
This is an example of what can be done together in the interests of security and stability in Europe.
Thank you very much for that.
Since yesterday, the new monitoring mechanism for economic imbalances has entered into force.
In the meantime, there are also the specific regulations on content.
What developments does the Commission now see as dangerous, what economic problems does it want to correct?
A growth in wage costs in the euro area countries of more than 3% per year is considered a problem by the Commission.
However, a threshold for falling wages is not provided for.
Cheap, dear Commission, does not mean good.
It is not enough to try to get the Member States to prosper at the expense of their trading partners.
Without investment in education, health and energy efficiency, we can exploit our workers to the bone, but we will not write economic success stories like this.
Another example from the scoreboard is the loss of export market shares to be reviewed and sanctioned.
This is unfair.
With increasing world trade, Europe's shares are statistically bound to decline.
The indicator therefore punishes those countries which are already involved in world trade.
That is why we believe that the Commission should withdraw this body and undergo a general review.

Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking our rapporteur and all those who have contributed to the report, because it is not routine, even if we are dealing with competition policy for the 40th time on the basis of a Commission report.
I should like to thank the Commissioner very much, because 2010 was the year in which he was for the first time fully responsible for competition policy, for the very comprehensive presentation.
But I would like to ask you, and you have just mentioned this in your contribution, that we should, in the area of aid, in the area of public aid, in the banking sector, do some work.

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the European Parliament's Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and Industrial Policy has already adopted a number of amendments to the Commission's proposal.
And I don't think that all of this contributes to the stability of the banking system, if on the one hand we have a lot of unanswered or unfinished old cases.
We have, and in fact there are already new cases arising from the fact that the pressure is being put on to increase the equity ratio, especially in the private banking sector, accordingly.

So here I really ask you, Commissioner, to come up with a quick solution which will also contribute to stabilising the banking sector so that it can also face the challenges of the international environment.
The second major issue, diffusion control, will also move us further in the coming years.
Here again, I can only call for the clear and transparent way forward that has been taken by the Commission so far in the context of merger control.
I believe that it is in the interest of all concerned, especially consumers, that we ensure that competition is possible in the area of merger control, even in larger or other structures.
In this sense, I would like to thank all those who have worked with me here, and I hope, Commissioner, that we will soon come to a solution, especially in the banking sector.

Commissioner, you have just struck a chord with us all, in that we are able to start a third industrial revolution in Europe if we understand that we are perceiving the sustainability opportunity as an industrial opportunity.
Then you also talked about resources, and that brings me to a thought that I totally forgot today.
I forgot about the human resources in my office.
And, Mrs. Philipp, please allow me, you've been working like a horse, you've been doing wonderful work, you've been a very leading person on this issue.
I'd like to thank you for that.
Mr President, when it comes to freedom of speech in Parliament, we also need a microphone system that works.
I broke the button to turn on the microphone.
I would ask that a technician restore freedom of speech.
Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I am surprised that we have to repeatedly remind ourselves of what is meant by structural and cohesion policy.

Cohesion and structural policy is one of the central policy areas of the European Union and is intended, by definition, to serve the consolidation of economic and social cohesion in the Community and, in particular, to promote growth and employment in the underdeveloped regions.
The need and success of cohesion and structural policy has been demonstrated in the years of the crisis.
In many regions it looks even more difficult, but as far as economic development is concerned, these funds would not be available.
The implementation of the Structural Funds is carried out on the basis of operational programmes, as has already been pointed out, describing the funding strategy of the respective regions.
The European Union, the Member States and the regions are working together in partnership to create a true European added value.
The success of cohesion and structural policy also depends on the reliability of the programmes and the available and existing resources.
That is why I am very surprised that Member States, but also the Commission, are constantly trying to use the Structural Funds as a savings box for all possible current policy approaches.

This is not in line with the purpose of cohesion policy and furthermore uncertainty for the actors in the regions, who are already working on the basis of long-term strategies and treaties to achieve the objectives.
Certainly, the fight against youth unemployment and the pursuit of economic growth is an important objective.
But this will only be achieved if partnership cooperation between the regions, the Member States and the Commission is maintained and if the actors in the regions are involved and remain.
Because only they know what needs to be done in their regions.
Cohesion and structural policy is the unifying, partnership, solidarity link between the different policy areas of the European Union.
It shows the solidarity of Europe on the ground in the regions, and it should not be given up lightly because of political hurdles.

Mr President, Commissioner, I support the compromise reached in Clio, which is intended to strengthen the negotiating power of dairy farmers vis-Ã -vis the processing industry, although I know that in some Member States it does not solve all the problems facing dairy farmers at the moment.
Commissioner Manzolt had already envisaged preferential measures for the creation of producer communities 50 years ago within the framework of the GAP.
In my country, Luxembourg, too, the dairy industry is the mainstay of our agriculture because of its high share of greenland.
Our farmers and our farmers have long understood that the best solution is to join a cooperative which takes over the processing of milk itself.
Five Member States voted in the Council against the compromise for precisely this reason, which does not meet its purpose as a soft lending instrument.
