The European Commission has the right of initiative as regards legislative proposals, and I would therefore ask it to submit a legislative proposal to the Council and the European Parliament after 2012 to correct this obvious and costly error in the system.

A linear reduction of the super levy for each kilogram of milk delivered by 2015 or the abolition of the fat correction could at least mitigate the negative effects of the expiring scheme without harming the non-affected Member States.
However, the present milk package is also seen as the final report of the high-level group, which is intended to bring the milk quota to a smooth landing.
It is astonishing that milk quotas are not mentioned at any point in this report.
The young and ambitious farmers in Luxembourg and four other Member States are trying to prepare for the liberalisation of the milk market and to expand their production.
If you want to be able to compete in the world market after 2015, you can only do so by buying more quotas even now, just before the end of the minimum quota system.
This is an enormous additional and unnecessary capital expenditure which disadvantages them compared with their colleagues in 22 Member States.
Question: Are you aware that we have long been community bonds?
And that the resolution does not speak at all of Eurobonds, but of very different options.
And are you aware that not all of these options require a contract amendment?
I find it questionable that you have again singled out generalities about Eurobonds.
We should not give up exactly the differentiation that we have achieved with the good proposal from Mrs GÃ¼ller.
I would like to hear a little more differentiation in your statements and I am curious to know what you think about this.
I will just say briefly, Madam President, that this is not the assessment I have made here.
I just want to point out that the last Italian government bond before Italy went into the euro was 10 percent.
And there was no outcry in Italy, and no one said that other countries should take over.
It was self-evident that you paid high interest rates.

And now, suddenly, because you've had low interest rates for ten years and you've become over-indebted, because money has become cheap for investment as well as for public hands, you want to extend it through Eurobonds.
This is a trap we can't get out of, and I'm in.
Mr President, Commissioner, your answer has really disappointed me in some respects.

They obviously want to stick to the old system of having to negotiate complicated deals per country and, in turn, not being given any more access to literature, which means that there are no more opportunities for the blind and the visually impaired.
This is all the more sad for me because now the European Union is blocking a step forward in the VIPO, while all or many other contracting partners would be willing to go forward.
There's a huge opportunity being missed here.

They are not fighting for more rights for authors, but they are fighting against people who are guaranteed equal access to cultural goods by the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and who can also participate fully in these cultural goods.
I appeal to you to please remove barriers and agree to a binding treaty.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the debate here in this House shows that we are actually representing the whole bandwidth, on the one hand, those who do not want any restrictions, on the other hand, those who associate any form of immigration with the danger of mass immigration.
These are the two extremes within this House.
I think we have to look at family reunification with a great deal of reason and also with rationality.
On the one hand, there are indeed problems in Member States where too restrictive measures are taken.
Because family reunification cannot be accompanied by so many obstacles that in the end no one can be reunited at all.

On the other hand, it is entirely justified that Member States, for example, require language skills, that they require integration, but also that they require the willingness to integrate within a state.
Secondly, of course the Member States have the right, and we should not put aside these problems, to formulate the problems that arise in family reunification.

If countries like Greece or Malta or Romania or Italy are no longer allowed to say what problems they have in this context, then I no longer know whether we are democratic if we simply ignore problems.
I don't think we're going to have a new directive now.
I think we should discuss the problems carefully and then think about how we can solve the problems.
The constant re-production of directives does not lead to an improvement in the implementation of the directives.
We currently have some implementation problems.

But I also fully understand that we must first of all deal with the fact that we are not going to make a new directive and put something on it again before we have discussed the old directive in any way in its problems.
I am in favour of listening to the Member States and at the same time respecting the fundamental right to family reunification.
And if you do it with reason and understanding, then I also believe that we will come to a good way.
Mr President, think before you think, demands the Polish aphorist StanisÅaw Jerzy Åez, and this recommendation would sometimes do us good in this Parliament too.
A few weeks after the resolution on the Central Asian strategy adopted in this House, in which the Central Asian states were censored, strikes are now taking place in Jana Ozen.
This is reflected in Kazakhstan, without waiting for the results of the ongoing investigations, which are being carried out with international involvement.
As much as the dead are to be mourned, the injured and the imprisoned have the right to recount the events as a result of these events, the background remains opaque.

Even Vladimir Kozlov, chairman of the unregistered opposition party ALGA, said that this was a group of other people, and that the unrest is not in the interest of the strikers, because it only provides the reason to act violently against them.
The Central Asian expert Arkady Dubnov also said that it was not excluded that parts of the Kazakh opposition living abroad also mixed in.
On the other hand, however, it might be a good idea for someone in the Kazakh capital of Astana to maintain the tensions.
Finally, the power elites of Kazakhstan are already fighting for the succession of President Nursultan Nazarbayev.
We had the opportunity to speak to the Kazakh opposition in the presence of the Kazakh ambassador here in Parliament.

UN Special Envoy Miroslav Jenscha announced today that he is impressed by the Kazakh government's attention to the events in Janna Ozen and that it is necessary to uncover the true background of UNRWA.
We should take the Kazakh authorities at their word, we should measure them by their actions, but we should not come to reflexive prejudices.
What I have understood correctly is the statement you made today that the Commission is fighting for the continuation of the food programme for the most deprived people in the European Union.
It will do everything possible to put forward concrete ideas in the foreseeable future on where exactly the programme will be based and how funding should be provided.
I think this is urgently necessary, and I think we have a shared responsibility to ensure that this food programme actually becomes a reality.
Not because I think it's the ultimate ratio, but because it's a signal from my point of view to show people that we still have a basic sense of the necessary solidarity with the

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the European Parliament has not yet been consulted on this matter, and if he is aware of the fact that the European Parliament has not yet been consulted on this matter.
I am thinking here of Greece, I am thinking of Spain, I am thinking of other countries where exactly what we are doing as the European Union is primarily at the expense of the poorest of the poor.
We're setting a mark, but unfortunately it's not anymore.
I therefore think it is urgently necessary that we not only deal with the 18 million people in the European Union who are currently dependent on food.
We want to continue to put the fight against poverty, or at all, at the top of our own agenda.
We haven't sent that signal yet.

But this is, in my view, the decisive point if we want to move forward here and if we also want to gain the trust of the citizens of our European Union in order to really create a social and solidarity union.
In that sense, you have our support.
But we ourselves, ladies and gentlemen, are also called upon to do something to ensure that the governments that have been blocking this attitude until now have to give up.
I think that's a bit of a self-imposed obligation for us.
Mr President, Mr Dohl, I have listened to you carefully.
What you are proposing, in parallel with the subsidiarity test, is to provide for a growth test for all expenditure, which means narrowing the targets to growth.
I would like to know from you how you combine this with the demands of a Christian-democratic group which probably still knows goals beyond growth.
It should be well known that the economy does not give birth to children who do not grow up and cannot allow them to live in an intact nature.
So this is a call for the priorities to be changed by the Commission and also by the Council, to be reconsidered.
We as a group will be examining very carefully whether what you have presented this morning actually corresponds to a change in priorities.
Until now, the motto has been "First the economy, it needs functioning financial markets".
And that was the first thing to do, to restore public finances, to reduce debt and to keep the markets calm.
And Mr Daul, who is unfortunately not here at the moment, I just wanted to say to him that I would do the same as Georges Macha.
I didn't understand his answer, but I'd disagree with him.
I think the measures that have been put in place were just wrong.
It was not right to focus exclusively on the recovery of the economy and to ignore completely what was happening to the people.
It was not right to put the stability of the euro above everything and to say that we do not care what happens to people.
But it has to be the other way around. First it's about the people, then we can talk about the euro stabilization.

The speculative attacks on Spain brought interest rates on Spanish government bonds to over 6 and more, and thus also close to the interest rate level at which other countries such as Greece, Portugal or Ireland have taken up support from the rescue fund.
The austerity policy imposed by the EU, the ECB and the IMF on the Member State with the drastic reductions in public spending of all kinds.
The reduction of wages and pensions, the increase in VAT and much more has just burdened the citizens and not prevented the new spiral.
Strict cuts in government spending exacerbate the downturn, drive up the debt ratio of states, and that must be our common understanding.
If Mr Draghi has recently said that the European social model is coming to an end, then I am glad, Mr Barroso, that you are saying no, we in the Commission do not think so.
But then I also expect you to go to Greece, to send your people to Greece, to Portugal, to Ireland, and to record exactly what happens there.
What happens to the people who are currently struggling to survive?
So what happens, or what do we do together, to finally stop this spiral of suicide, which has been used, especially in the most affected debtor countries?
It can't be that we're staring at this place in silence.
And we don't benefit from social policy programs that will ever work if other measures are taken.
We must act now. Where are your objectives from the 2020 strategy to combat poverty?
What has become of the European poverty platform?
It's been set aside.
That was before the crisis.
But it is now, in the midst of the crisis, that people need help, they need support, and they need the action of the European Union.
They don't need empty promises.
We need concrete ideas of what should be done now.
If you do that, you will get the support of my group.
I would like to ask you to support all those who, even within the Commission, have recognised the signs of the times and want to change things.
But please don't just go on and say it's going to be
But it will not be anything more if it continues like this. I ask you to put forward a concrete project, a concrete programme, on how we can really help people in the countries concerned now.
Do something about it!
We will have to do it in our countries so that it is not blocked that the funds for the ESF 2013 or 2014 to 2020 or for the other programmes are also cut.
Member States must live up to their responsibilities.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the current state of public finances and the economy in Europe leaves no room for a tax-policy fairy tale.
The situation in the Council is simply that there is little progress on tax policy proposals.
Why?
Because some countries are against further tax cooperation.
They benefit from aggressive tax planning, they are themselves tax havens.
And the treaties clearly stipulate unanimity on tax matters.
That is why the EU Commission has suffered shipwrecks on several occasions in the past with its proposals.
That is why they are being watered down, they are not moving forward as in the interest rate directive, and in recent proposals, in the rush to obey, nothing demanding has been proposed.

I therefore ask you, Mr Schmetter, I know that your job is not easy in this respect, to change the strategy, to take sharp measures and then to focus on enhanced cooperation to put an end to the blockade position in the Council.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with this proposal on risk-sharing instruments, no state bankruptcy can be prevented where it should occur.
But it's still better to do something than to do nothing.
And extraordinary situations sometimes require extraordinary measures.

The budgetary and debt crisis in some countries has led to such an extraordinary situation that important projects and measures can no longer be implemented within the framework of cohesion and structural policy because the banking sector is failing as a financial sector and private investors are no longer available.
I see an extraordinary measure in the present proposal for the creation of risk-sharing instruments for the further financing of projects in the field of structural policy.
Cohesion and structural policy funds available to countries wishing to use these sharing instruments can be used to finance already ongoing projects.

I am very grateful to the rapporteur, Mrs Danuta HÃ¼bner, for her great contribution to the clarification of the Commission's proposal and for her clear indication of when and how these instruments should be used.
However, I also believe that these risk-sharing instruments should only be due to the current situation and cannot be a prejudice to the future funding period.

Madam President, the fact that an amendment to the 2009 Biometric Passport Regulation was called for to carry out a review after three years and to present four studies has been supported by our group.
This is also because it has repeatedly raised serious concerns about data protection law and the overestimation of the use of biometric data in passports.
The belief in perfect identification, the overestimation of this means and, as a result, the underestimation of other parts of the security chain are really problematic.
The handling of biometric data is still subject to this great error, namely the assumption that it is unchangeable and most trustworthy.
And that's exactly what's wrong with us.
These data can also be changed over the course of a lifetime.
In children, they look different from those in old age.
And that is why reliable and serious studies and conclusions are necessary.
Falsity is still being used.
We have now been able to establish
As the events in the UK and other countries have repeatedly shown, the chips are not safe from abuse at all.
They are happily cracked and can cause permanent damage to those affected.
The standards within the EU are also extremely different.
The error rate is very, very high, as in France and the Netherlands.
And again and again the question must be asked what is the use of biometric data if documents are forged and in circulation?
So if one link in the chain is forged, the source documents are inconsistent, biometric data should not help us.
One last thing, the Chaos Computer Club in Germany only took a few minutes to demonstrate a forgery.
To do this, the friends of the Chaos Computer Club needed the lid of a plastic bottle, a second-hand sticker, a digital camera and a little bit of wood glue.
We expect the Commission to present the studies and, of course, the results and the consequences that follow.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission is unfortunately not sufficiently represented today, as I would have liked it to be, in respect of Parliament.

As a Member of Parliament from a region which is heavily affected by the planned changes, namely the Eifel, I am forced to ask, after careful follow-up of the debate, whether the unfortunately inadequate attempt

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the difficulties faced by the Member States in implementing the common fisheries policy, and if he is aware of the difficulties faced by the Member States in implementing the common fisheries policy.
Above all, I wonder if there has really been an adequate impact assessment.
We need, in order to be fair to farmers, not only biophysical criteria, but also socioeconomic criteria.

That is why I call on the Commission to review this important aspect in due time, separately from the overall package of the CAP reform and, above all, after presenting the necessary documents and carefully analysing the impact on the criteria.

I do believe that we must also work together with the Asylum Support Office and the Greek authorities to identify more quickly which persons who have come to Greece could possibly actually be in Greece.

They must also be transferred to other countries of the European Union, because firstly, they can definitely never return to their home country, and secondly, they may also bring with them potential and qualifications that can be meaningful and useful to all.
But it is also essential to help the Greeks to register and identify more quickly in order to speed up the process of assistance.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter, and if so, what is the Commission's position?
Mr President, Mr Minister, Commissioner, thank you very much, and also to the rapporteur for her always very committed and exemplary work.
I can share much of the criticism that Sophie Infelde has voiced, and I support it or have supported it in part.
But then there's always the point where you have to take responsibility.
And for the EPP, or for myself, I therefore also claim that we must now deal with the realities and not be able to retreat to ideological or theoretical points of view.
The fact is that the United States has been collecting this PNR data for ten years, and there hasn't been a single complaint.
The fact is that we don't all want data traffic, even with a negative attitude, that we can stop data traffic at all.
You just did that.
The fact is also that we do not want air traffic between Europe and the United States to stop.
And the fact is, the U.S. has a right to know who's coming into their country.
And the fact is, in my view, that the legal services have all told us orally that this agreement is better than the other agreements than the alternatives.
That's why you have to take responsibility here.
And that's what we're elected for.
Responsibility for the citizens, who would otherwise be left alone and with less protection and rights.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter, and if so, what is the Commission's position?
But also responsibility for the EU as a contracting party on data protection and security issues and also responsibility for a balanced relationship between security and data protection.
That is why we are, in sum, also taking into account that this agreement is not perfect, but in the consequences, in favour of agreeing to this agreement.
If you want to protect citizens better and if you also want to give citizens better data protection, you also take on this responsibility and agree to this agreement.
Mr President, Commissioner, those were informative remarks you gave us.
Thank you very much for that.

The figures sometimes say more than big words, and to date, the European Parliament, you mentioned it, the European Patent Office, has granted almost two thousand patents on plants and almost twelve hundred patents on animals, which were created with and without the use of genetic engineering.
Two outstanding examples I can mention are the granting of patents for genetically modified and breeding-modified barley, which applies to the entire chain from seed to plant.
Our farmers are therefore affected as much as our brewers, producers and consumers.
And this example, in my opinion, shows a devastating extent of patenting.
The second example is the so-called long-life tomatoes, not to be confused with the long-life oil they have in their diesel engines.
With this trick of the applicant US company Arcadia, this patent was circumvented by the valid EU rules.
It's not the tomatoes that have been patented, it's their genetic material, namely selected enzymes.

This shows the tricks that are being used, and this is despite the fact that, as you said, Commissioner, in the 1998 Biopatent Directive, Article 4 clearly states that plant and animal species are not patentable, and in essence biological processes for the breeding of plants or animals.
We believe that this definition needs to be clarified, it needs to be clarified.
Technical procedures used to support conventional addiction must not lead to overall patentability.
We specifically say no patent on life.
And we need a clear signal here for more ethics and for more honesty in dealing with the creation, again against patentability of life throughout Europe.
And so, Commissioner, we call for the Commission's clear statement that patents on breeding material and genetic resources are and will remain prohibited in Europe.
Secondly, we call for a clear position on Article 4 of the Biopatent Directive No patent on life.
Thirdly, Commissioner, on behalf of many farmers, many breeders in Europe, we call for a clear establishment of the breeder and farmer privilege in all legislation.
Madam President, I take the view that Europol and Eurojust should be dismissed.
As far as Europol is concerned, there is little to complain about.
The annual report reflects the financial situation in 2010 in all its essential aspects, and all transactions underlying it are regulatory and therefore lawful.
All that stands out are the high transfers in relation to the overall low running costs.
Europol attributes this to the move to a new headquarters, which is understandable.
But Europol says it will take further action in the future to avoid such high transfers.
In addition, Europol intends to commit itself to monitoring the implementation of the budget every month from 2012.
I recommend that we keep an eye on whether this is really happening.
Against this background, I recommend the discharge of Europol.
The conclusion of the year also reflects the financial situation in 2010 in all its essential aspects.
All transactions are legal and regulated here.
But here, too, high operating expenses were transferred to 2011.
According to Eurojust, this was mainly due to an organisational structure project, a new computer infrastructure and costs related to data processing.
It is announced that all this will be improved in the future, including better compliance with tender requirements.
I also recommend that we check this in the future and, above all, check whether all open positions will actually be filled in the future.
That's been improved.
But if these positions are not filled soon, then we would almost have to consider withdrawing funds, and that would be negative for Eurojust.
I recommend relief. Thank you.

Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, what we have to fear and panic about is not the sheer number of young unemployed in Europe alone, but the development of the European labour market.
From 2008 to 2011, the number of young unemployed increased by 26.5%, according to the International Labour Organization.
It is this development which urgently requires action, because we are not only separating an entire generation from the labour market, we are separating an entire generation from a viable future.
If we give young people the feeling of absolute uselessness, we need not be surprised that young people are turning away from this EU because they do not have a reasonable work and life perspective.
Commissioner, I urge you to ensure that decisive countermeasures are taken, I know that a lot, but please make sure that the long-standing mental silence does not turn into operational hecticism.
If I read that the Commission is launching a programme to provide financial support for young people applying abroad, then we are organizing a travelling circus which does not solve the problem.
On the contrary, it becomes counterproductive, and then technicians, doctors, engineers and nurses are recruited from the richer countries that are not in this crisis.
It is now necessary, in this crisis which is the cause of this development, to take offensive measures, namely to break down this savings trap which is strangling the economy in Europe.
We need a targeted growth policy, we need strengthening domestic purchasing power, public investment in education, research, alternative energy.
That would be the way.
With the combination of European funding, it would then be possible to develop an integrated concept that would provide young people with a perspective on life.
Last remark This youth unemployment does not tolerate the folly of wanting to raise the retirement age for people to 70.
We need a different policy to give young people access to the labour market.
That's why I'm asking you urgently.
Madam President, you have just said that everything that would speak for the financial transaction tax is speculation, and then you yourself have come up with very speculative examples.

I would like to know from you what you think of these investigations by the Commission and the Commission study, which very clearly states that the real economy has so far been involving far too little in its dependence on
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has already made a number of proposals to the Council and the European Parliament on this subject.
Is this just speculation for you, or would you say that such a well-founded and broad-based study by the Commission is already justified and a strong argument?

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the financial transaction tax is certainly not identical to the Tobin tax, which has been discussed and debated for many years, but I think it takes up essential elements of the Tobin tax.
It at least takes up the idea of involving the financial markets in taxation, of taxing them and, above all, of involving them in the costs of the crisis.
I think this is a very important signal to the financial markets.
But it is also a very important signal to the citizens, to our voters.
There have been a number of actions, petitions and written undertakings in a number of Member States to introduce a financial transaction tax at European level.
I think that Parliament has achieved a great success with the majority that is voting in favour of this report, in favour of this tax.
It is certainly not enough to stabilise and restrict the financial markets, as might be necessary, but I think this is a really important step that has been taken.
I would like to appeal explicitly to the Council to take the votes of the citizens, the voters, seriously and to commit itself to this.
I hope that there will be a real introduction, that the introduction of this tax will not be blocked in the Council because of the British position or other positions.
I think it is clear that the citizens of the European Union want this tax, and I think it is a great responsibility.

It is now up to the Council to take action here, and I would like to use my speaking time to appeal to the Council to do everything possible to ensure that this tax is actually implemented and becomes a reality.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I think that with all the detailed problems that can be discussed and that can still be discussed in the further legislative procedure, we should talk about one in particular.
Financial markets cannot function on the model that if everything goes well, the banks will withdraw the profits, and if something goes wrong, the taxpayers will keep their heads down.
And that's why it makes sense to tax financial transactions as well.
And it makes sense to do that across borders.

In Europe, or at least in the euro area, we will not have rejection, but we will make a permanent contribution to getting a stable financial position that generates what financial positions are actually intended for, namely that the companies

We need to have access to capital, so that the saver has the opportunity to save something or to save for the pension system, and so that the financial markets can once again fulfil the task for which they were created, namely to provide added value for the real economy.
All that has driven us into the financial crisis have been products that have created no value for the real economy.

That is why it makes sense to make a contribution through a tax to ensure that this is punished severely, that this is sanctioned, that this is controlled in the sense that capital fulfils its task again.
That is why I am voting for this proposal today by a large majority.
Mr President, the reform of the general preference system was certainly necessary.
It is now good that there are longer running times and that there is more security for exporters.
However, the criteria are too vague, as the Development Committee has already said.
Unfortunately, the Commission refers only to the World Bank's classification.
In the past, Parliament has repeatedly and very critically considered gross domestic product to be the only criterion.
The definition of countries with high average incomes can refer to countries with a gross domestic product of $4,000 or up to $12,000.
So this is a huge and far too large range, and it's not in any way consistent with the realities on the ground.
We certainly don't find it worrying that countries like Saudi Arabia and Kuwait are flying out.
So the reform in this respect was good.
But these countries are high-income countries anyway.
Russia and China, on the other hand, are countries with high average incomes, and we certainly do not have to worry about their falling out of the GSP.
But this category of countries also includes much poorer countries, such as Namibia and Ecuador.
So far, the Commission has at least also used the linkage criterion, i.e. countries that export little or very little goods.
This, after all, avoids the fact that countries that are less dependent on exports and are very, very vulnerable have been over-rated.
Why, then, has the Commission deleted this criterion?
Countries such as the Dominican Republic, the Fijian Islands, Gabon and Botswana will thus fall out, although their economies fall under the criterion of vulnerability.
Why has the Commission not continued to apply the old criteria, which were already somewhat inadequate?
There is a suspicion that the Commission is trying to force poorer countries into free trade agreements that are less favourable to them.

However, the preference system is an instrument for promoting development and cannot be replaced by pure trade instruments in which the development path of a country or a region no longer plays any role at all.
Fortunately, however, colleagues in the House will still have the opportunity to vote in favour of our amendment, which takes vulnerability as a criterion.
However, the new regulation also leads to the separation of trade regions.
Neighbouring countries in customs unions will soon have to follow different rules when exporting to the EU.
This has nothing to do with our objective of regional integration.
The Commission should take greater account of developing regions rather than individual countries.
Here, too, we Greens have tabled an amendment which will hopefully be widely supported.
It is also problematic if countries that also benefited from the APS yesterday are to be excluded from the programme from today to tomorrow.
There must be transitional periods, and we see in our own countries that not just a few months are enough to develop the economy.

In the end, however, we Members must also consider whether we should focus on speed in all legislative proposals and then work with windswept compromises, or whether we should not rather involve the whole House.

I think that for legislation the whole of Parliament is important, and for democracy too, and it is not the speed that is important, but the time and democracy needed to enforce and to pass laws properly.

Mr President, Madam High Representative, I was also a member of the European Parliament's election observer committee in the Democratic Republic of the Congo and was able to see how much hope and expectation for a better future the people at the polling stations had and were waiting to cast their votes.
We know today that these expectations were not met.
Although the Congo calls itself democratic, these elections were not fair and not democratic.
We must address this offensively, as Mrs Delcheva has done in her report.
The previous president, Joseph Kabila, has appointed himself as the leader of the opposition.
In the east of the country, violent clashes between government troops and so-called rebels have flared up again, and it is unclear whether third countries such as Rwanda are involved.
In any case, the civilian population, which has not been able to live in peace and quiet for decades, is the most affected.
The country's wealth is being thrown into a swamp of corruption, and the Congo remains one of the last places in all international assessments.
The international community of states, especially the European Union, must use its powers to increase pressure on the President of the Republic of the Congo to allow real democracy in his country.
And that the Congolese army is not only dragging the civilian population, but is finally catching and bringing to justice internationally wanted criminals against humanity, such as Bosco and Dangan.
Internationally, all states should finally commit to no longer supplying weapons to the Congo.
Without external pressure, human suffering and poverty in this country will not end.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the two-pack is intended to create further rights of intervention against crisis countries in the euro area.
The European Semester, which was created as a framework for necessary and better coordination of financial and economic policy, is to be condemned.
According to the Commission's wishes, Member States should be able to be forced to accept financial aid.
The six pack has already created far-reaching sanctions against euro countries with financial problems.
Mr President, the European Semester is already perceived by citizens more as a means of undermining democracy than as a meaningful instrument of economic policy coordination.
At the same time, the German government is openly threatening Greek citizens with expulsion from the eurozone if they make the wrong decision in Sunday's elections.
Why don't we stop with these humiliating and undemocratic threats?
In a situation where the euro crisis has escalated dramatically again, I am thinking of Spain and Cyprus, we cannot continue to blame the Member States in the crisis for being in the crisis.
We should finally be developing solutions, and the rapporteurs of the two-pack have developed very sensible approaches to this.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter.
But so does the proposal by Jean Paul Gausset for an orderly state insolvency.
But the central thing is that Europe is making a joint and solidarity effort to get the eurozone back on track.
The strong countries in Europe must stop pointing their fingers at their partner countries with self-satisfaction.
They have to start doing their homework, investing in growth and taking responsibility.
The one-sided austerity policy of Angela Merkel has simply failed as a crisis solution.
Mr President, Mr Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in June 2010 the EU Heads of Government finally realized that the European Community needed a better coordinated financial and economic policy.
At the summit, you invented the European Semester, so to speak.

It is absolutely right that the members of an economic and monetary union should not be allowed to pay attention to the impact of their policies on companies, workers and consumers in their own country.
A European perspective is needed.
A single market without coordination in economic, wage and social policy presents the Member States with a great temptation to create short-term growth and jobs at the expense of their neighbours.
Such imbalances can break the monetary union economically, but also politically.
And that is precisely the situation the EU is facing at the moment.

The German economy has been digging up the water for its neighbours for years, no impulses through investment and wage growth, instead Berlin has almost ruined the eurozone with a decade of aggressive export policy.

It is therefore very gratifying that the Commission is now slowly coming to grips with this core problem of the euro crisis in its country-specific recommendations and making appropriate recommendations.

The Federal Republic is rightly called upon to invest more in education, research and childcare, and the Commission is rightly called upon to stop the abuse of mini-jobs and to adapt wage growth to productivity growth.
That is a late but important discovery.
I hope, Commissioner Rehn, that you will vigorously defend this demand to the German Government, even if there is no formal procedure for surplus countries.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank the Commission, in particular Commissioner Barnier, for the very simple reason that the experience of the last parliamentary term before 2009 has shown that the Commission is not alone.

It is clear that, with the exception of a very brief moment of awakening when the proposal of the European private company came, the predecessor of Commissioner Barnier, Commissioner McCreevy, actually put corporate law to sleep, as in these five years in this important issue which is also important for the internal market.
They've come a long way.
Thank God that has changed fundamentally.

In the meantime, there are a number of consultation documents from the European Commission, an expert group which has dealt with the question of the further development of company law, and we now have a consultation which we are of course dealing with as a Parliament.
The Committee on Legal Affairs has decided that we do not want to do this in the form of a report, simply because a report requires additional time and is of course also a little more detailed.

We have chosen the means of oral question to the Commission in order to be able to discuss this subject with the Commission, with Commissioner Barnier, and at the same time, in a subsequent resolution, to make clear our position to Parliament on what is about to happen.
I believe that it is necessary, as we had about ten years ago, to develop a new action plan on European social law for a number of reasons.
There are gaps within European corporate law, real gaps, which basically mean that the single market is not being created.
I would like to give the example of the absence of the 14th Directive on the relocation of seats, which in my view is a very typical example of such a gap.
Parliament has called for this twice in its legislative initiatives, for concrete proposals from the European Commission to be put on the table.
There is also the expert group set up by the European Commission itself, which also has the same opinion.
It is simply one of the fundamental freedoms of the internal market that a company must be able to move in the internal market also in terms of its registered seat.
This possibility does not exist today, or only under extremely difficult conditions.

But at the same time I have to criticize the fact that the European Commission's previous opinion on the 14th Directive is actually far behind Parliament's expectations and, in our view, does not meet the standard of a qualified response to a legislative initiative.
But we are of good courage that in the course of further work, if it comes to the action plan, this proposal will hopefully be found in the action plan.
Another important point in corporate law is the question of the further development of corporate law with the aim of reducing burdens for companies.
We already have very concrete proposals from the Commission on the table, for example on the subject of the
But I believe that there is more to be done and that there are other aspects which will now be clarified in the context of the consultation.
We are also expecting further proposals from the Commission.
I would also like to ask the Commission to revive the issue of European private companies, which is currently stuck in the Council.

If there are individual Member States, I may say this from my own point of view, if there are individual Member States in the EU which are unable to eliminate the deadlock on their own due to a lack of determination.

If we are to move Europe forward, then, as in other projects such as patent law or family law, we must also think about using the instrument of enhanced cooperation so that at least all other Europeans have the opportunity to take advantage of this opportunity.
I would ask the Commission to think more carefully about this question.
Another open problem is the question of applicable law, a kind of Rome regulation for cross-border problems in corporate law.
I also believe that this issue needs further investigation and discussion and I would ask the Commission to do so.
And that's also in a very close context.
We have the right to insolvency, but it has already been announced that we will receive a concrete proposal from the European Commission in the near future.
You see, there's a lot of work to be done in corporate law.

I am grateful that Commissioner Barnier has taken the initiative again and that it is clear that in the second half of this legislature we will have significant proposals which can then also represent a step forward in shaping the internal market.
I believe that Parliament supports this in principle and in approach.
Of course, we'll have to discuss the details.
But that is why I would like to thank the Commission.
And now, of course, we would be delighted if the Commission would actually take up our initiatives and turn them into concrete proposals.
Mr Commissioner, I very much appreciate your proposal for a productivity-oriented wage policy.
But you have been very clear about the minimum wage with Mrs Merkel, and I do not believe you about the question of job creation in healthcare.
How can new jobs be created there if the Commission has already forced southern and eastern Member States to reduce their hospital capacity by up to half?

How is employment in the health sector to be created if the Commission, in its new country-specific recommendations for the European Semester, requires some Member States to further reduce their health spending?
I fear that this point in this plan is pure announcement policy, not a real initiative for new work.
On the contrary, it is already today that there is a shortage of medicines and medicines, not only in Greece, because of austerity measures.
I think that those who are constantly putting up new lifelines for banks must now work for a lifeline for people, in particular for the security of medical care in the countries in crisis.
Mr President, the mood among countless pro-Europeans like me is one of frightened horror at what is happening in Europe at the moment.
It is gratifying, after all, that what we are dealing with is now being spoken of much more clearly and that the eyes of Italy are not being closed either.
You yourself know that you are caught in a series of traps, not only in that of debt and growth, but also in that of trust and in the power trap, dear Commission and also addressed to the Council.
Unfortunately, they have so far failed to address the central question of the removal of the financial economy from the real economy.
Everything we have decided here will be evaluated again and again in the opinion of experts as continuing to be the shadow banking industry no serious limit.
We are still dealing with systemic risks, the question of too big to fail is still not addressed appropriately, and there is hardly any need to lose a word about the rating agencies.
I can only urge you, if you are now working towards the Council summit, to restore credibility in Europe by seriously putting this question of power between the real and the financial economy.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter, and if so, what is the Commission's position?

Mr Fermi, you come from a country which has rejected the euro, albeit with the central rationale that it is precisely for reasons of social policy instruments that it wants to maintain the flexibility of devaluation.

In the light of the experience you have now gained in Sweden, would you recommend that the Greeks also leave the euro area in order to be able to actively use this social policy instrument of devaluation?
Mr President, I would also like to thank the shadow rapporteurs and the rapporteur very warmly.
We adopted this report in the Committee on the Environment by a large majority of 62 votes to 0 and no abstentions.
This shows that we are actually very, very close together there, also in terms of compromises.

And the top priority, of course, in this legislative process must be a high level of protection, a high level of consumer protection, especially for the little ones, our society, for children in need of protection.
And as far as gluten intolerance is concerned, this is a problem, especially in kindergartens.
If you look around, I have two children at this age, and there's allergies and intolerance, I think we're right there.
And we should discuss this with each other in the second reading, with the Council, with the Commission.
And I think we're going to get a good result.
Mr President, a report on a road accident over the weekend involving a truck driver who fell asleep from exhaustion and drove into a ditch has confirmed to me again how necessary it is.

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the difficulties faced by the Member States in implementing the directive, and if he is aware of the difficulties faced by the Member States in implementing the directive.
The digital tachograph means a certain innovation, it has new problems, but also old problems.
The new problems arise with new possibilities for manipulation, which we also have to deal with technically.
The old problems are those which we can already observe, so to speak, in the absence of control in various Member States.
What we are now re-regulating has, in my view, to take into account the fact that not every time a ride is recorded, there is automatically a break.
Because a lot of drivers have to load and unload, and that's also, of course, to be considered working time.
The second problem is that the records of speed have been deleted from the file.
I think that's wrong, because there's a lot of risk of accidents here, too.
We also want to have weight sensors, and we also want to have a hotline so that you can report fraud that is anonymous and that can be tracked.
What I am also going to bring up is a request that animal transport control be included in this regulation.
I think this is important because it is also a very central element of our legislation.

Madam President, many thousands of people could still be alive today or would not have any permanent disabilities if, after their accident, professional medical assistance had been provided quickly enough, that is, within the first so-called golden hour.
We'd be a lot closer to Vision Zero.
Well, the eCall system we're talking about today can't avoid accidents, and it doesn't exempt you from the first aid requirement.
It is only used in the event of a serious accident to automatically inform a call centre.
It must also establish linguistic contact with the vehicle in order to avoid abuse and overload by minor accidents.
Only when the emergency call is confirmed or no one else responds are emergency doctors, equipped with little but life-saving information, sent to the scene of the accident.
Responsibility for the functioning of this rescue chain lies with the Member States.
As long as the sensors installed in the vehicle do not detect an accident, the eCall system is asleep, so it does not send any signals or data and is also not in place.
It is therefore far superior to a mobile phone in terms of data protection.
Only with the automatic, sensor-controlled awakening or the conscious manual triggering does the system become active.
It then sends an agreed minimum set of data of information to a rescue helpline.
Europe-wide uniform standards and specifications will ensure that these data are recognised, assessed and treated as an emergency call upon arrival.
That is why the Member States must also equip and expand their rescue service chains accordingly.

We want this eCall emergency call system to be based on the EU-wide emergency call number 112 and to be free of charge for the user, to work throughout the EU and to be compatible with the emergency call systems of neighbouring third countries.
It is to be based on an interoperable, technology-neutral, open system architecture.
These can later be used to offer other intelligent public transport services, such as real-time traffic information or the availability of parking spaces.
In recognition of the great achievements of the automotive industry in providing private emergency systems, these should retain their right to exist in parallel with the public 112 e-call.
Users can also choose such a system on the basis of detailed information.
This may be accompanied by the cost of the project.
the mandatory use of the data for workshops, insurance companies, towing services or other service providers.
A small village in the Franks is known for its good beer, and this rhyme shows a small problem that we have created for ourselves today.

Because if this brewery or the liquor merchant is 107 kilometers from my home, I have no chance of him continuing to offer me his goods in the future without having to buy a new tachograph, without having to create a new bureaucracy.
And that is why, ladies and gentlemen, I voted against this resolution today, because I believe that we should not burden our small and mediumsized enterprises too much.
It was planned to take 50 kilometres only in the vicinity of a regional provider at all.
That was completely absurd on the part of the EU Commission.
So maybe 100 kilometers is still possible.
But what if it goes beyond that?
So I think it's an exaggeration.
And one last aspect, as a representative of a workers' organisation in the CSU, I also say that we are creating a complete control of workers with this regulation.
Why?
Because, for example, the person who offers his goods for construction or for drinks, for breweries, is completely controlled by GPS throughout the working day.
So I also consider, for reasons of data protection, that what we have decided today is highly questionable and I emphasize again why I voted against it.
Yes, thank you very much for that question.
Why am I not waiting for this decision?
I have been waiting in the Legal Affairs Committee for the approval of the European People's Party when we raised the necessary questions on legal certainty in relation to ACTA during the process.
And there was silence in the woods and denial.
Now it is obvious that the ECJ is to be used for delay, that is clear.
That's why I said that with the wide range of interpretation.
Because you asked two questions, I have to answer both of them.
Because you can read and interpret everything from these broad formulations, the surveillance of the Internet, the auxiliary police officers, the ISPs.
And that means legal uncertainty, legal uncertainty does not help our economy either, dear colleague.
Mr Leichtfried, I would like to ask you whether you are in favour of discussing the modernisation of copyright at European level.
Or are you completely opposed to the rejection of all intellectual property?
And how do you envisage the e-commerce directive being adapted to modern conditions in the future?
I take it from your statement that you reject a debate on these matters at all and do not stand for intellectual property.
Is that true, or how do we see it?
Mr President, it turns out that these are not individual facts that we have to discuss, but the fundamental question: how do we deal with democracy and freedom?
And if we look at the ACTA, we find that it is, in a way, symbolic of transparency, of a lack of democracy, of a violation of fundamental rights, because it was secretly invented.
And it was kind of undemocratic, because the free use of the Internet just couldn't be possible after that, and neither could the freedom to use generic drugs to the extent that it has been so far.
These are the reasons why millions of people have taken to the streets and voted on ACTA a long time ago.
Yes, ACTA has been voted on the streets, on the Internet, in relation to the Committee on Petitions in many countries, not just within the EU.
We are also outside the EU, and I believe that we must not ignore this vote, which is a vote for the direct democracy of many citizens who have elected us.
I can only tell you to put ACTA on the files, that would be decent.

Mr President, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, as rapporteur for the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Budgetary Control, I have concluded two procedures under your presidency: the budgetary procedure, which provides a set of rules for the forthcoming MFF period, and the OLAF procedure.
Since November 2008, this regulation has been on hold in the Council, and you have concluded this procedure on the basis of the results of the Polish Presidency.
I would therefore like to thank you for two very, very committed financial officials who have worked on these dossiers and also for Mr Ambassador.
I'm going to miss him, his efficiency as a negotiator will be missed.
You have really earned the financial interests of the European Union.
Thank you very much!
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am speaking here as a representative of my group and I would like to support Mr Fjellner's motion.
Ladies and gentlemen, we do not have many raw materials in Europe.
The raw material we have here is our brains and our creativity.
Firstly, it requires careful consideration of the issue of intellectual property rights.
The European Commission has submitted this proposal to the European Court of Justice with a request for an opinion in order to clarify still open questions.
I believe that it is only by respecting the Supreme Court of the European Union that we can wait for this decision.
There is no reason at all to make this decision today.
No one is prevented from voting against it when the Court of Justice has submitted its decision and its opinion.
But the decision that is then made takes place in a different consciousness and in a different awareness than today.
I do not mean that the ghost drivers on the Internet highway should determine our policy, and that is why I ask you to support this motion.
Mr President, as always when Mr Turmes speaks, this is very wise, and one would wish that what he says had much more influence on European politics.
I wanted to check it out.
Of course, these project bonds are a bit clever, but only if they are sustainable and if political foundations are created for this.
We are in danger of taking risks through guarantees that we have no political control over.

Specifically, the energy transition in Germany would require a network of 8 kilometres, but only 100 kilometres of these corresponding telecommunications networks have been built because it also fails to resist the citizens, by the way, the very ecologically oriented citizens.
We have to think of something about politics.

The idea would be to create common corridors, not just the high-speed lines on the railways and broadband networks, but perhaps above them, also next to the motorway, to construct the wiring networks accordingly.
This, however, requires much more comprehensive planning than has been envisaged so far, but I would like to suggest at least this.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I consider Schengen to be one of the greatest achievements of the European Union, but on the contrary, I also know that the borders of a country are always a very sensitive issue for our Member States and will always remain so.
I am aware that the problems between the Member States in relation to Schengen cannot simply be ignored.
There are various problems.
By ignoring, you don't make the problems better, and you don't solve them better.
I live on the border with the Czech Republic, and no one would think of closing the border again just because we have problems.
But I also ask the Commission for support in this area and not for restrictions and corrections.
The veil has been lifted because we want to ensure security while ensuring freedom of movement.
And if we successfully negotiate the closure, I am talking about the borders, also to the Czech Republic, where one or the other drug traffickers, not only in a few cases, but in many cases,

If we are trying to make a transition in these cases, then I think it is good for the German Federal Minister of the Interior and the Czech Minister to come together to solve the problems at the border together.
And the Commission should not act in a regulatory way, but in a positive way, with support.

We want to put the populists at a disadvantage, but we want to solve the real problems together, which is why I also ask the Council to work with Parliament to find a solution so that we can successfully adopt the Schengen dossiers so that we have freedom of movement and at the same time guarantee the safety of citizens.
Mr President, the cases of disproportionate border controls listed by Parliament in its question also show why the Council actually wants to leave Parliament out of Schengen.
The Council wants to continue to undermine freedom of movement without Parliament being involved or without any form of parliamentary control, without any form of publicity.
No wonder you'd rather tap your shoulders in the back room instead of asking uncomfortable questions.
No wonder the German government wants to completely exclude an evaluation of the internal borders without an evaluation and thus does not want to look at how much freedom of movement is restricted.
But Schengen does not belong to the governments, it belongs to the people of Europe and therefore to the European Parliament.

Mr President, Mr President of the Council of the European Union, Mr Dimitris Christofias, it is a special moment for me and for my group to welcome you here in your capacity as President of the Council of the European Union.
And we are also pleased that for the first time in the history of the European Union, a man is at the head of the EU, whom we consider to be part of our political family.
You are taking over the presidency at a time when the European Union is facing enormous challenges, and it is time to put an end to them.

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the European Parliament has not yet been consulted on this matter, and whether he is aware of the fact that the European Parliament has not yet been consulted on this matter.

I know from the conversations we have had with you, with the representatives of your government, with the chairmen of the political groups and parties in your country, that you are very much aware of this.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the European Parliament has prepared an excellent presidency and that it is also aware of the scope of its task.
But you have made it clear here today that you want to deliberately draw the attention of the rulers to the living conditions of the people.
I can tell you here that after all I have heard in recent years, this is the first time that a President of the European Union has done exactly that and announced and said this tone.

That is why I have long missed the fact that in official speeches it is said that it is about the people, it is about those who are not responsible for the fact that we are in this crisis, but who have the most burdens to bear.
It will be difficult to implement this approach as well.
I think it would have been a great victory, and you will do the same, I am very sure, if you encourage people with your presidency and the way you do it.

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Council has not yet taken a decision on this matter, and if he is aware of the fact that the Council has not yet taken a decision on this matter.
We keep talking about the euro and its stability, about the necessity, which I also see, that it is important for the functioning of the European Union and the euro area.
But this is an instrument.
There have been political conditions for this, they have been defined.

It can never be the aim of the European Union to accept that the euro is working, that people in the European Union are starving, that health systems are collapsing, that municipal administrations are having to stop working.
Something's wrong here.
It is not what we can call the objective of the European Union.
I very much support your call for social cohesion, for solidarity between the individual Member States, but also between the most diverse groups of the population.
The European Union must not be used as a mere instrument or as a spokesman for a small, specific segment of the population, or even present itself as such.

And one last point that I would also like to make, of course, to emphasize that everything that you have mentioned in your priorities is important to us and that we will also support the points that go in this direction, as I have just defined them.
Please do something to make sure people are no longer afraid.
Fear is the worst advisor to democracies.
And I think that some of the decisions in recent weeks and months, especially in the elections in Greece, in the votes for the referendum in Ireland, have also been shaped by fear.
And if the rulers of the European Union are helping to make people afraid to make their own free choices, then that is not a good sign for the future of the European Union.
Good luck with your work!
Ladies and gentlemen, I believe that we have a very important responsibility here, also as co-rapporteurs.
It will be very important for the honourable Member to work quickly and reliably on this dossier in the coming weeks and months.

The eyes are currently on us and on the Council to take this step of overcoming the crisis of the banks in Europe by taking another step of Europeanisation, namely by establishing a European banking union.
It must be said that Parliament has demanded this with a large majority two years ago.
We have conducted 26 trilogues.
We have taken a step in this direction, but unfortunately not as far as it would have been necessary.
This has led to billions more.
It is good that the Council has now drawn the consequences and wants to deepen this step for the euro area.
It is commendable that the Commission has drawn up the proposals so quickly.
However, there are some difficulties with the Council's proposal that the ECB should become the place of the euro area supervisor.
In the Council this leads to unanimity and it leads to Parliament not being involved in this dossier.
According to the experience of the supervisory package, this is not acceptable.

And that is why it is important that we work quickly here, but that we also negotiate this proposal for changes in the ECB with the necessary changes in the existing supervisory regime as a package and thus actually produce the principle of democratic participation of Parliament.
There are other democratic challenges as well.
The ECB is independent in monetary policy, but not in fiscal policy, for which it has no tasks so far.

If it is now to be responsible for banking supervision, Parliament needs full budgetary rights, full control rights, question rights, appointment rights, and I am sure that Parliament will also be able to enforce these rights by a large majority.
The complicated questions beyond the internal market, consumer protection and the balance between European power and financial responsibility will be thoroughly discussed in the coming weeks.
Mr President, with the proposal to exclude developing countries from preferential market access, the Commission is trying to force these countries into free trade agreements.

Firstly, they are free to abstain, as the term 'economic partnerships' suggests, but they are only concerned with the interests of the EU and not with the development interests of the partner countries.
This is completely contrary to the EU's objective of reducing poverty and aligning all external policy instruments to it.
Countries such as Cameroon, the Ivory Coast and Namibia would be severely affected by this restriction.
Regional integration projects such as in East Africa would collapse if Kenya engaged in such an agreement.
South-South cooperation would be over.
We cannot advertise free trade in the world and thereby only mean that other countries should buy our goods.
If the Commission really believes that trade can promote development, it should not block it.
The Committee on Development of this House has recommended that the Commission's proposal be rejected.
And we should join that in the plenary.
Mr President, both in Central America and in Peru and Colombia there are an enormous number of human rights problems.
And we as Members of the European Parliament cannot simply close our eyes to it.
In the case of Colombia and Peru, the roadmap for human rights called for by the EP will be thoroughly examined when it is drawn up.
It must be substantive and binding and must include first results, such as the conviction of criminals and the safe return of displaced persons to their country.
And, of course, it must also be present before the vote on the agreement.

We Greens think it is right that the Committee on Trade and Social Affairs calls for environmental and social standards in the draft regulation on the protection clauses, and not just tonne restrictions for bananas.
The trilogue must then confirm this, otherwise the regulation is worthless.
In general, the EU needs to do much more to take account of the situation on the ground and, above all, of the impact on the local population.
That is why we Greens, even before any negotiations, call for a proper impact assessment which examines not only the economic impact on the EU but also the impact on human rights.
Mr Barroso, I had already made clear in the first round what I wanted to put at the centre.

I am concerned about the expectation of my group that the Commission will fulfil its responsibilities in the relevant bodies, such as the Troika, in order to make it clear that we, as the European Parliament, are not the only ones who are responsible.
As the Commission, as the European institutions, we stand for people not to be driven further into poverty, for working hours not to be reduced, for ecological and social standards to be lifted.
That's your job.

And if we succeed in making this clear, then we will also send a signal to the thousands, hundreds of thousands of people who are protesting these days, who have taken to the streets and with whom we as a group also express solidarity, whether in Thessaloniki or in Barcelona.
I heard the news this morning that in Greece the cancer patients are protesting and striking.
Where have we gotten to where people who are in deep social and personal distress can no longer get any help or support because the health system has collapsed?
We must finally get active here!
And I say one more thing, an approach that in the minds of many responsible people is that the people of Greece and other countries have lived through their circumstances.
They must be punished for this today and must bear sanctions.
It is unsuitable to strengthen a European community, a community of solidarity.
I do not suggest that to you, Mr Barroso, but this is an approach which is also being adopted in many countries and which, unfortunately, is also being used in my approach, for example.
Mr President, I confess I have been mistaken.
I do not want to make a statement on this report, but on the Moreira report on the agreement on immediate autonomous trade preferences for Pakistan.
I'll call you back.

Madam President, the new directive creates a basis for dealing with books, newspapers, works of art, films, music, TV productions which are protected by copyright but for which the copyright holder cannot be identified or identified or can be found.
Accordingly, books, films, photographs or other intellectual creations for which no copyright holder is available should also be made available to the public.
And that's how a cultural treasure is raised.
It was particularly important for us in the Committee on Culture to emphasize the special importance of the diversity of the European Union's cultural heritage in this legislative initiative.

In the archives of our museums, libraries, publishing houses and radio stations there are countless unused works, and only because their rightful owners are not known can they not be made available so far.
That changes with the directive.
It will make it possible to use this cultural asset in the future, if a careful search is also made for publication.
This is a very important point, so that it is not said lightly that we do not find the rights holder.
Because a balance had to be found with the real rights of the creators of works and the need of the public to be able to use such works where the legal situation is not clear.
A particular focus for us is also that we had to ensure that both the known and the unknown rights holders were fully protected.
And where the rights holders are not available, the draft makes it possible to use the digitisation of the orphaned works.
Projects such as Europeana and other major European digitisation projects, but also our museums, archives and educational institutions and public broadcasting will be launched.
In the future, however, it must also be a matter of opening the orphaned works in the archives of private publishers to the public.
This draft directive and the compromise that has now been found are, in my view, a real compromise and a first step in the right direction.
I believe that the cultural treasure that is so high holds enormous potential.
And we should continue to work on this in the revision of the directive in two years' time.
Mr President, Commissioner, President-in-Office of the Council, I would be delighted if we could make a clear statement in the 2013 proposal.
We would see the Council's signals on how we can expand the potential for growth and competitiveness in Europe and, above all, how we can give young people back jobs.
Could you please tell us in which budget lines you intend to promote youth employment and put entrepreneurship and small and mediumsized enterprises at the centre?
We know that the CIP programme is the essential prerequisite for this.
Or the Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs programme, or the media pluralism programme, there are only cuts here.
Do you think we can overcome the crisis in Europe by cutting back on those points which guarantee growth and employment?
I have heard that a growth and employment package is to be proposed by the Council.
Where is this to be found in this budget, which has been presented by the Council?
Mr President, Nordseewerke Emmen had to declare bankruptcy last Wednesday because a guarantee from the Lower Saxony state government was surprisingly not extended.
This company with 700 qualified jobs is in the process of transforming from a shipyard to a supplier of offshore wind energy.

And now the idea is that this company can be saved by a mass loan and that the jobs can also be saved, because the 700 colleagues at Siak and the North Sea Works have already had to make substantial cuts in wages.

That is why I ask the Commission to examine this procedure in a timely manner, so that these 700 jobs are not put at risk, because these 700 jobs are needed to organise the energy transition and to organise future-proof energy on the seas of Europe.
Please do not let the colleagues there suffer from the bad crisis management of the state government.
Goods from the villages often look harmless, but in the hands of authoritarian regimes they can be as dangerous as machine guns or tanks.
We are undermining our foreign policy goals by sending surveillance technologies to authoritarian regimes that can control and suppress democratic movements.
It was European mobile software from Nokia Siemens Network that played into the hands of Iranian security forces in the suppression of the Green protest source.
Protesters were dragged away en masse, arrested, tortured and sentenced to death.
And that's just one example of many.
In addition, the Commission is promoting these dubious dual-use goods with the action catalogue for innovative and competitive security sectors, as it is called.
The aim is to create a better use of the synergies between security and defence technologies.
We are in danger of selling out human rights, but also our security interests, in the name of a questionable industrial policy.
That is why I would ask you to agree to the amendments tabled by us and the Social Democrats and ALDE.
I would like to ask Mrs Regner what do you think the trade unions could do to combat youth unemployment, for example in Spain and Portugal?
Demonstrations will be too little.
What active policy could the internal market be conducting here?
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I think that with today's debate on MiFID we are moving into the core area of financial market regulation in Europe.
It is a question of regulating the financial markets and not just looking at individual products as we have done in the past.
I just want to mention a few keywords.
We didn't make it very easy for each other to work together last year.

We have conducted a hearing in the committee, we have conducted a questionnaire to all stakeholders, to all interested groups, and on the basis of this, we have drawn up a result with various processes, working documents and the like, which we will present to the plenary for a vote today and tomorrow.
I want to make a few points.
The number one issue is market structure.

On the one hand, of course, we have to note that a lot has been done in the financial markets in recent years, but it is in our interest as a Parliament that any trade in financial documents that takes place takes place within the MiFID rules of the game, which is why we are also under many conditions of a new category.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter, and if so, what is the Commission's position?
I think we are making an important contribution to ensuring that the whole area of OTC securities traded within the MiFID world is traded.
Another major issue that was not taken into account in the last MiFID is the so-called algorithmic trading or high-frequency trading.

Here, too, we were concerned with establishing clear rules of the game, so that this area, which can be very dangerous, which can also be used manipulatively, is subject to strict regimes with minimum stop-and-go periods.

With trade suspension possibilities, with the possibility of testing algorithms, with the possibility of looking at the supervisory structure of algorithms, with the introduction of a so-called tick size regime, a minimum price size and corresponding fee systems.
Another subject I would like to address is the area of van term markets.

I believe that we already have a special responsibility here when it comes to limiting the speculative share of commodity markets so that we do not contribute to the fact that people in the Third and Fourth World can no longer buy food.
That is why we have chosen a two-pronged approach with the aim of curbing speculation but not damaging the real economy.
With position limits, with strict upper limits on the number of contracts or positions, we want to achieve this.
But we also want to ensure that those who can prove that they really need a product with a so-called position check system do not suddenly also intervene speculatively in this market.
Another issue that concerns us very much is the area of investor protection.
I would just like to point out that we have chosen a very broad approach when it comes to ensuring consumer and investor protection.
It is a question of identifying the needs of certain customer groups.
Not every small saver has to have access to all the highly complex papers.

It is a question of defining appropriate products for target groups, carrying out product reviews, telephone recordings, appropriate consultations, disclosure obligations, but I would also like to briefly indicate this in the area of subsidiarity in commissions.
Member States should be able to make appropriate adjustments in accordance with their structures.
I think we're on the right track.
After my time is up, I want to thank everyone who has contributed to this.
I think it's a pity that you only get four minutes of speaking time for such a difficult dossier.
I would like to thank all the colleagues who have contributed to the Commission for their very constructive role in the last few weeks and months.
I hope that with a strong vote in plenary tomorrow we will be able to enter into negotiations with the Council in order to conclude this important dossier as soon as possible.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, thank you very much for the overall good cooperation on this report.
