We have been able to improve on a Commission proposal in key areas which has already taken major steps in the right direction.
In the area of market structures, there will be more transparency, there will be more comprehensive transparency, especially in the area of derivatives.

Under the framework of MiFID, the decisions in the field of high-frequency trading of our compromise go much further than what the Commission originally proposed and deserve the support of Parliament as a whole.
And even on the issues that have provoked great public criticism, the report is pointing in the right direction.

In the area of commodity and food speculation, after large and difficult debates, it must be said that it is now much stronger than the Commission's decisions, because position limits are now set as binding.
However, we still need further changes in this area in order to close the gaps.
I also hope that this will be supplemented by a plenary vote and, finally, by a trilogue vote.
It is gratifying that Mr Barnier has already signaled his support for Parliament's further proposal.
However, where the report has weaknesses is in the area of consumer protection.
We now have the possibility of banning products, which is a step forward, but we still have no change in the area of commission-driven consultation.
The distribution of financial products is still not primarily oriented towards the interests of customers, but is strongly dominated by which product has the highest commission.
Especially in Germany, but all over the EU, consumers have lost a lot of money.
Think of the open real estate funds.
For the citizens of France, Italy, Spain and Germany, for example, our compromise will unfortunately not change much.
The basic principle will continue to be provision orientation.
It is a bit easy to refer to subsidiarity here.
I wish there were stronger rules here.
Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, what lasts a long time, finally lasts well, I can only say.
The report on type approval of L-category vehicles has finally become a good report.
The work as a whole took longer than we all thought and especially than we had hoped, and there were many more pitfalls than we would have liked in the end.
But at this point I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Van de Kamp, once again for the really cooperative and good cooperation.
Together, however, we have been able to achieve a great deal in the negotiations with the Member States.
As rapporteur for my group, I recommend that this report be adopted, but it could have been much better.
And with better, my dear colleagues, I mean safer.

For us Social Democrats and Social Democrats, the safety of vehicles and thus the safety of drivers was at the forefront from the outset, especially the safety of roller-coaster drivers and motorcyclists.
The number of motorcyclists who have been injured has remained constant for years.
In general, the number of fatal accidents in Europe is decreasing, but not in motorcycle accidents.
Reducing the number of motorcyclists and roller coasters killed is indeed a matter of the heart for me.
Fewer deaths on Europe's roads, that was, and that is my goal.
Every dead man is one too many.
It is precisely in a regulation which is so beneficial to the internal market that this subject must be dealt with intensively.
I am still convinced that this can be done by means of effective technologies of anti-blocking systems, i.e. the ABS.
And I am equally convinced of cost-effectiveness.
It's not true that ABS is too expensive.
Nevertheless, we have achieved that from 2016 all new and from 2017 all existing types of engines must be equipped with ABS from the manufacturer's 125 cubic cubic capacity.
In the case of motor rollers, the manufacturers may optionally equip ABS or the combined braking systems.
On this point, unfortunately, it must be admitted that we have not achieved any improvement in the Commission's proposal.
I would have liked much more, but the Commission and the Member States have, to put it mildly, shown themselves to be very difficult.
Nevertheless, we have achieved that in 2019 the Commission will present a report.
The report must be fed with data on road accidents from the Member States and should examine the mandatory installation of ABS for motorcycles.
It is also sent to Parliament and the Council.
On the basis of this report, the Commission should then consider making the installation of ABS in rollers compulsory.
You see, the subject remains very, very vivid.
We will therefore try to close the binding gap in legislation from 2019.
I'm sure the data I've collected will prove me right.
I am convinced that this is indeed a good day for two-wheeler drivers in Europe and that the number of accidents will decrease in the future.
Mr President, Mr Mathias Groote, there is no technology without risks, there is no perfect energy production technology.
And I think that applies to what we're discussing here today.
I'm very much in favor of discussing this rationally.
What we are currently experiencing is a new access to the energy markets through unconventional resources, both in gas, mainly in gas, but also in oil.

I think it is neither appropriate to fall into great euphoria, the great gas future, nor is it appropriate, as some of my colleagues on the Green and Left have done here, to paint on the walls great horror and horror scenarios that have nothing to do with reality at all.

I think we have to keep in mind that these unconventional resources have the ability to change all the energy supply relationships that we know between suppliers and demand, and that the economies of scale of previous energy suppliers have also been called into question.
We should be aware of this.

So I think we should take note that this can also be an opportunity for Europe and not just a risk, we should also prepare ourselves to use and use new technologies in a positive way, to weigh opportunities and risks fairly and not to fall into ideological debates.
Commissioner, for your answer, you do not satisfy me entirely.
Because I think it's a very, very long time, a year between the notification that the complaint has been received and possibly getting an answer so late.
I believe that a complainant who makes the effort and has usually gone through the whole legal process in his Member State deserves more.
We are counting on citizens to commit themselves to the European Union.
If they do it in this form, we should treat them accordingly.
And I believe that it is necessary and indispensable in the long term that we have a procedure here which is clearly formalised and which clearly regulates rights.
On another point, I have no objection, if it serves the purpose, to trying to bring about a kind of unanimous clarification with the Member State.
But that won't always be enough.
We observe that, for example, in economic matters, it is relatively easy for one company to sue another for a breach of EU law.

But when it comes to environmental issues and similar issues, where very, very many citizens are calling for the activities of the European Union or also for social rights, this is a little more difficult.
I believe that these facts must also be taken into account.

And I hope that in your next report we will have, so to speak, a clear formalisation of the rights of the complainant to the Commission, which are also very clear and which are also very well communicated.
Once again, if we really want European law to be applied after we have done so much work here in the European Parliament, in the Council,
If we have decided together, then we must inform those who are concerned about this, who are really engaged in Europe, as well and as precisely as possible.
That's a very, very big concern for me.
And I'll be watching closely next time to see what's going on here.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, five years ago the EU's Central Asia Strategy was launched.
If you ask today for the balance sheet of this strategy, the assessment is ambiguous.
We see how the Member States individually strive for good economic relations, particularly with the resource-rich countries of this region, while on the other hand the efforts do not go ahead.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the European Parliament has not yet been consulted on this matter, and if so, what is the Commission's position?

Nevertheless, or precisely because of this, the European Union and the Member States must more strongly express their influence in this region together, especially vis-Ã -vis Kazakhstan, which has now become a major supplier for several EU countries.

An isolation of Kazakhstan by the EU would only lead to competition for influence in this geopolitically important country, where the insistence on respect for citizens and human rights is not so important, and could bring its influence even stronger than before.
The linking of economic interests with the commitment to the protection of civil rights is the core of the Central Asian strategy.
This should also be the basis for further negotiations on a partnership and cooperation agreement with Kazakhstan.
This report provides a good guide to this.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen of the non-existent Council, perhaps you will follow us on the Parliament's video stream, since you obviously have neither the capacity nor the desire to speak to us live.
I regard the Council's absence here and now as gross disrespect for Parliament.

Instead of pushing for this debate, you should rather air your secret, which is why you refuse to adopt a directive on any improvement in the protection of personal data in the field of police and justice.

Police and the judiciary have been, as we know, for years an eldorado of violations in the area of data protection, not only in SWIFT, but in the day-to-day, for example, in which data from citizens who demonstrate against the Nazis, for example, is illegally collected and stored.
We need equal standards of protection for the public and private sectors and for the police and the judiciary, that is what it is all about, to be able to guarantee civil rights.
If you, the Council, ask Parliament to take a constructive part in data protection regulations such as the EU PNR or Europol, then the Council must do the same.
That is why I call for an end to the blockade policy in the field of data protection.
